column2: CLEVELAND, Dec. 1--The new National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. today pledged itself to combat every political system that was "nourished" on materialism and called on the church-goers of America to exercise calmness, self-control and courage at a time of growing peril.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The establishment of a "genuine peace" as against "the phony peace of Soviet Russia and her satellites" was described today as one of the principal objectives of the International Federation of War Veterans Organizations.

The use of "performance incentives" through merit bonus plans has been tied in with a companywide plan of decentralization, Merle Hale, director of salaried personnel activity for General Motors Corporation, told more than 500 members of the finance conference of the American Management Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has refused a loan of $38,000,000 to the Kaiser-Frazer Company, but is willing to negotiate for a $25,000,000 credit provided the company meets its conditions, W. E. Harber, chairman of the agency, said today.
Fordham's football Rams will close their season this afternoon in a game with Syracuse at the Polo Grounds.

Ocean freight rates for bulk cargoes are skyrocketing, and a shortage of tonnage is definitely in prospect unless reserve vessels are broken out of lay-up bases, according to shipping reports.
A veteran Brooklyn detective who was being questioned by the holdover grand jury in a "new phase" of racketeering filed his application for retirement Thursday night, it was disclosed yesterday.

Howard Kyle of 173 West Eighty-first Street, veteran actor, who had appeared with Helene Modjeska, Julia Marlowe and Mrs. Minnie Maddern Fiske, died yesterday in a nursing home here at the age of 89. He had acted for more than fifty years, retiring about ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--President Truman accused the Chinese Communists today of assaulting not simply the United Nations troops in Korea but all the free world "to further the imperialist designs of the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--President Truman, urging speedy action today on his request for greatly increased military funds, moved to get a defense force of 2,771,000 men who would have the guns, planes and ships needed for at least the opening phases of an all-out war.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 (AP) --Mrs. Charles S. Howard's Noor today defeated Palestinian and Assault, who followed him in that order, in a tune-up for the $100,000-added Hollywood Gold Cup on Dec. 9. Noor raced the mile and one furlong in track-record time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The Defense Department asked Selective Service today to draft 50,000 more men into the Army in February. This raises to 300,000 the number of men already inducted or scheduled to be inducted into the Army since the Korean war began.

Although steel warehouses had anticipated yesterday's rise in steel prices, most distributors will not announce new warehouse price schedules until after studying the mill announcements in detail, trade sources said here yesterday.

As if there were not enough explosive ingredients in the inflation mixture already, we are now witnessing the first effects of one more of these at work. This is the so-called "General Motors formula" for the automatic adjustment of wages at regular intervals.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Dec. 1--Charles Engelhard, president of Baker Co., Inc., a large refiner of precious metals at 30 Church Street, New York, died at his home here this morning at the age of 83.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)--The Canadian Pacific and Soo Line Railroads were accused today of retarding reorganization of the Wisconsin Central Railroad for the purpose of buying it at a low price.

LONDON, Dec. 1--A large part of Prime Minister Attlee's last day in London before his departure Sunday for the United States will be spent in coordinating British and French attitudes toward Far Eastern and European problems.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America yesterday authorized for payment Dec. 25 an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share. With these declarations, dividends will amount to $1 for 1950. In previous years the company made a single annual disbursement of 50 cents a share in December.

Foster, E.C.A. chief.

New York food writers had luncheon yesterday in a candy kitchen, the only one in a New York department store. On the fifteenth floor of Gimbels they chose roast beef, avocados and kirschwasser-spiked coffee from a delicious buffet.
Commodity futures displayed a mixed price movement on the Exchanges here yesterday. Rubber, copper and zinc moved lower, while tin, lead and wool advanced. Coffee, sugar and hides were irregular.

Hope runs high in the gas industry that "Federal encroachment" on regulation is being curtailed. The Association of American Wood Pulp Importers has elected Stanford G. Blankinship president, Albert Blattmann vice president, Richard F.Kist secretary, V. Ramsay treasurer and James Donaldson director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Capital outlays for new plant and equipment will reach record proportions in the first quarter of 1951, the Securities and Exchange Commission and Department of Commerce predicted today in a joint forecast.

The Kelvin Medal, a high honor in the field of engineering that is given by a special board consisting of the presidents of eight engineering societies in the United Kingdom, has been awarded to Dr. Theodore von Karman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche and other Americans who won Nobel prizes do not have to pay a United States tax on the monetary awards, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Bureau said today. The spokesman said the Nobel Prizes were not considered taxable income.

The second anniversary of the acceptance by the United Nations General Assembly of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was celebrated last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, A large invited audience attended a program that consisted mostly of music, but also included two speeches and readings from the declaration.
The Christmas season is reflected in New York art galleries by the number of group shows that offer all kinds of paintings and sculpture in a wide price range.

Gray iron foundries are now working close to capacity in the New York district, with some on six-day week schedules. Overtime rates and around-the-clock operations loom large in production plans being set for next year. Price boosts in castings are being studied...
BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 10--The Pacific Maru, the first Japanese ship to use the Panama Canal since July, 1941, sailed early today to Cristobal with a cargo of 6,000 tons of scrap steel for Philadelphia.
OIL CITY, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP)-- South Penn Oil Company today increased Pennsylvania grade crude oil prices 15 cents on the barrel.

Only a few buyers were in the Wholesale markets here last week as stores concentrated on Christmas retail volume, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Retailers felt they had sufficient inventories...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A minimum emergency program to combat Communist influence in the trade unions of Southeast Asia has been partly adopted by the executive board of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

The 100-year-old Portland Oregonian has been purchased by Samuel I. Newhouse, publisher of newspapers in the East, it was announced jointly last night by Mr. Newhouse here and E.S. MacNaughton in Portland. Mr. MacNaughton is president of the Oregonian and represented the four owning groups who are heirs of the newspaper's founders.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 10--The Netherlands and Indonesian delegations were seeking a formula tonight to avoid a breakdown of the conference on Western New Guinea at tomorrow's session.

The license plate on a stolen automobile used by two prisoners after their escape Saturday afternoon from the Federal Detention Headquarters on the lower West Side led to the capture of one early yesterday morning at Conowingo, Md., by state policemen. He was Charles R. Perry, 25 years old, a plumber's helper, of Memphis, Tenn.

TRENTON, Dec. 10--Six Negro men who won reversal of their conviction for the murder of a Trenton shopkeeper at their first trial, which attracted nation-wide attention, will face a new trial here on Jan. 15. Defense attorneys were notified this week-end of the date by Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley.
Toni and Rosi Grunschlag, duopianists from Vienna, gave a concert in Carnegie Hall late yester day afternoon. It was their fourth appearance as a team since they came here in 1938.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Benchley Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., on Nov. 25 in the New York Hospital.

Thirty Christmas trees given as memorials to American service men who lost their lives in World War II and on the battlefields of Korea were lighted yesterday shortly after 6 P. M. on Park Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Ninetysixth Street.

The need for more medical schools in New York was stressed last night by Mayor Impellitteri and former postmaster general James A. Farley, who praised plans by Yeshiva University to organize a medical school here.
The City Fusion party called yesterday for legislation to establish a state rent subsidy fund to take care of rent increases granted to landlords because of hardships or inequities.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 (AP)--North Korea's Premier Kim II Sung today predicted a Communist victory with the aid of the Soviet Union, and called for a battle of annihilation in which "not a single enemy can escape."

MOSCOW, Dec. 10--Both the Soviet Union and Communist China, according to the Soviet press, support a peaceful settlement of the Far Eastern crisis but the divergence in viewpoint of Washington on one hand and that of Moscow and Peiping on the ...

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 10--Prices on the Amsterdam stock market during the past week followed the New York trend but the reaction and subsequent recovery was less abrupt. Internationals and shippings gained up to seven points but Indonesian issues tended to lag.
Two new fabrics for casement curtains are available at the Artcraft Weaving Corporation's showroom at 20 East Fifty-third Street.

DUBLIN, Dec. 10 (Reuters)-- The archbishops and bishops of the Anglican Church of Ireland protested today against the new Roman Catholic dogma of the bodily assumption of the Virgin Mary. The protest, in the form of a pastoral letter read in churches throughout Ireland, declared that the dogma rested "on no scriptural or historical evidence."

Lauritz Melchior, operatic tenor, received yesterday an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Wagner Lutheran Memorial College at a concert of its a capella choir in the institution at Grymes Hill, S.I. The singer was introduced by the Rev. Frederic Sutter, head,of the board of trustees. The degree was conferred by Dr. Walter C. Langsam, president of the college.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 10 (AP)--Fred Kovaleski of Detroit and Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt gained the final round today in the Asian lawn tennis tournament. Kovaleski defeated Iftikhar Ahmad, Pakistan's No. 1 player, 6--4, 3--6, 9--7, 6--3, and Drobny ousted Irvin Dorfman of New York, 6--3, 6--3, 6--3.

For the third time in ten months, Brener Lewis, Inc., brokers, have negotiated a sale of the four-story store and apartment building at 635 Second Avenue, near Thirtyfourth Street. The latest deal was arranged for the Creston Glass Products Company to B. Dejian for cash over mortgages amounting to $24,000.

Up and down the Atlantic seaboard, wherever-heavy marine construction work such as the building of the Delaware Memorial Bridge or the Severn River and Chesapeake Bay bridge is under way, two squat and unprepossessing barges are likely to be in attendance.

Suspension of the time-and-ahalf for overtime provision of the Wage and Hour Law and the Walsh-Healey Act for the duration of the war production emergency was urged yesterday by Homer D. Sayre, commissioner of the National Metal Trades Association.

The unsettled problem of Germany is like a latent fever which goes up every time the international temperature rises. While Mr. Truman and Mr. Attlee were arguing over what to do in the Far East, the American, French...
PARIS, Dec. 10--Gen. Charles de Gaulle, in a speech today at Lille, urged the United States to make certain that without abandoning Asia it would "give a priority to the defense of Europe."

PANAMA, Dec. 10 (AP)--All activity was halted for twelve hours in this country today while 11,180 enumerators took the 1950 census. The 1940 census gave the country a population of 622,576; the 1949 estimate was 746,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP)--The veteran Roy Conacher and his line mates were big gunners tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks pulled into a 3--3 National Hockey League tie with the New York Rangers before a crowd of 12,008. It was the tenth deadlock of the campaign for the New York skaters.

Miss Betty Arnoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Arnoff of 983 Park Avenue, was married to Herbert Prashker, son of Prof. and Mrs. Louis Prashker of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in the Roof of the St. Regis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, who was assisted. by the Rev. Dr. Sidney Tedesche.

The New York Chiefs defeated the Philadelphia Panthers, 20--19, in the feature of a roller derby double-header at the Twentysecond Engineers Armory before 5,218 fans yesterday. In the opener the Chicago Westerners topped the Washington Jets, 21--17.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP)--The New Haven Eagles of the American Hockey League, disbanding because of an inability to win games and influence people to buy tickets, skated through their last contest tonight in characteristic style.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 10 (AP)--The Rev. Perry J. Convoy, president of Niagara University from 1906 to 1908 and superior at the university from 1938 to 1941, died today after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
Few men talk any more of military glory, but this does not mean that the qualities of courage, endurance and calmness under terrible affliction have passed, or should pass, from the language.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Navy's sailing team won the fourth annual Frostbite Regatta in a swirling snowstorm on the Potomac River today, edging out Harvard University by 6 points.

A symposium on "American Foreign Policy and the Soviet Union" will be conducted by Columbia's University's School of International Affairs today at 7:45 P. M. in Harkness Theatre on the campus. Among the speakers will be Nathaniel Peffer, Professor of International Relations at Columbia, and Henry Bamford Parkes, Professor of History at New York University.

HUNGNAM, Korea, Dec. 10 (AP)--A United States Navy frigate rescued twenty-five terror-stricken Korean refugees adrift in the Sea of Japan today. Their wave-battered sampan was found by the Bisbee about thirty-six miles southeast of this east coast port.

PARIS, Dec.10--Jacques Duclos, interim secretary of the French Communist party, said in a speech tonight on the sixth anniversary of the treaty of alliance between France and the Soviet Union that the rearmament of Western Germany would be a violation of that treaty. M. Duclos said that Article 5 of the treaty bound each of the contracting parties not to adhere to any alliance or coalition that was directed against the other.

Milton Hanauer retained his lead yesterday in the championship finals at the Marshall Chess Club with a score of 6 -- ,followed by Bernard Hill, 6--1, and Anthony E. Santasiere, 5--1. The following results were recorded: Goldwater 1, Dr. Mengarini 0; Hanauer 1, Foster 0; Hill 1, Mrs. Gresser 0.
The New York Commodity Exchange has announced that Philadelphia has been named a delivery point for lead under futures contracts traded on the exchange, effective on Dec. 13.

Robert Wersba has been appointed vice president and West Coast manager of Artcraft Hosiery Mills. He has resigned as Western division manager of sales and assistant treasurer of the Delaware Corporation and will take up his new post on Jan. 1.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 10--An extensive realignment of Western Allied policy in Germany that would replace the Occupation Statute with a security treaty and give the Bonn Government almost complete politica1 and economic sovereignty is winning increased support among American and British officials in Germany.

Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of the Cooper Union, in his annual report yesterday, declared that colleges must be assured of enrolling the most talented and intelligent youths--and not merely those with personal financial backing.

OTTAWA, Dec. 10--A more reassuring estimate of the Korean and world situation than has seemed possible for some weeks past has been given to the Canadian Government and people by Prime Minister Attlee of Britain and Field Marshal Sir William Slim, following their conversations in Washington.
Women's Chinese robes, jackets and lounging pajamas may now be ordered here to customers' measurements to be handmade in Hong Kong of fine tribute silks and brocades.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 10--Baseball's trading mart, dormant for a week, suddenly came to life with a loud bang today as the Red Sox and White Sox announced a deal involving five players.

SOMERS, N. Y., Dec. 10--Edmond C. Van Ronk, 46 years old, of Kent, Conn., a New Haven Railroad laborer and a constable of the town of Kent, was killed at 11 P. M., yesterday when the car he was driving went out of control on Route 100 and struck a tree about...

The New York Yanks made their farewell appearance of the season an impressive one yesterday when they rode roughshod over a hapless Baltimore Colt eleven to register a 51-to-14 triumph at the Stadium. Unfortunately, this awesome display of strength was accounted for in comparative privacy, a scant 6,836 witnessing the proceedings.

Ralph H. Van Houten, 60 years old, a passenger conductor on the Long Island Rail Road for more than thirty-five years, was found dead on the kitchen floor of his home at 100-24 201st Street, Hollis, Queens, late Saturday night.
The following instructions on what to do in case of an air raid have been issued by Arthur W. Wallander, Director of Civil Defense. It is suggested that they be kept handy.

Ground was broken yesterday for a new 200-bed, $4,000,000 Long Island Jewish hospital at 75-59 263d Street, Bellerose, Queens. Participating in the ceremonies, at which 300 persons were present, were J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County Executive; Queens Borough President Maurice A. FitzGerald, and Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals.
The Cunard liner Britannic arrived here yesterday with 765 passengers from Liverpool and Cobh. The vessel docked at Pier 54, North River and Fourteenth Street, at 9 A.M.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10.--The steel industry was able to make a great comeback last week in those areas which had been hit by storms the week before, The ingot rate last week was up 17 points to 100.5 per cent of rated capacity --compared with a revised rate of...

LONDON, Dec. 10--Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther of the United States is expected to be chief of staff to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower when the latter is named commander of the integrated military forces of the North Atlantic alliance.

LONDON, Dec. 10--The Financial Times index of thirty industrial ordinary shares using as a basis for 100 the level of July, 1935 stood at 113.2 at the end of last week, and compared with 114.4 a week before, 116.8 a month before and 104 a year ago. The bond index, based on 1928 as 100 was 122.77, compared with 123.06, 124.01 and 121.65 on the respective dates.

Year-end condition statements to be published by the large New York City banks at the end of this month are likely to show an increase in earnings during 1950 of approximately 5 per cent. As usual, however, performance will vary among the individual banks, ranging as high as almost 15 per cent in some instances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A total of 6,529,615 television receivers were produced in eleven months of 1950, according to preliminary industry estimates released today by the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association.

The Polish liner Batory, only Russian satellite passenger ship in North Atlantic service, left Pier 88, North River and Forty-eighth Street, at noon yesterday with 265 passengers bound for Southampton, Copenhagen and Gdynia. Lashed to her masts were large Christmas trees. Officials of the Gdynia America Line, operators of the vessel, said that a Yuletide program would be held at sea.

The thirty-fourth annual meeting and dinner of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association will be held at the Commodore Hotel on Jan. 9. More than 1,200 representatives of steamship, rail and airlines, marine insurance and other groups involved in transportation problems are expected to attend.

PARIS, Dec. 10--Official circles here strongly deny that the position taken by France at the customs conference at Torquay is an obstacle in the way of a new step toward tariff reductions. They protest against stories in the British and American press to the effect that the French delegation took a protectionist stand.
The Italian Historical Society of America, 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, has opened a national memership drive.

The Rev. Dr. John Hess McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church at 114th Street, declared in his evening sermon yesterday that the reverses in Korea were a warning from God not to trust in military might or the United Nations, but "in God Himself."

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 10-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Murray Wilshire of the engagement of their daughter, Susannah Boyer, to Douglass M. Bomeisler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bomeisler of Greenwich.

Top honors in the fourth annual tasting of fruit cakes just held in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen went to two of the most reasonably priced products on the market. Sixteen others were rated high by three judges, who sampled forty-six of the cakes now in the stores. The judges were blindfolded, the loaves identified only by number.

After shooting himself in the head while driving in Central Park with his estranged wife, George Keith, 34 years old, of 5 Blacksmith Road, Levittown, L, I., died in Beth David Hospital yesterday at 10:20 A. M., the police reported.

Leonard Sarason and Aaron Bodenhorn were the composers on Saturday evening's Composers' Forum at MacMillin Theatre, Columbia University. Some familiar tunes turned up in both men's music, but there the similarity ended.

Shipments of all types of hosiery during October amounted to 15,728,048 dozen pairs, compared with 14,579,682 a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

The Soviet agricultural revolution of 1950 has apparently run into trouble. At the beginning of this year Moscow ordered that small and medium-sized collective farms be combined into new super-collectives, promising that great gains in production and efficiency would result.

A trap set for a gang of safe crackers resulted yesterday in the arrest of five suspects after the thugs had spent nearly six hours ransacking five floors of a twelvestory loft building at 232 West Eighteenth Street. A sixth suspect escaped.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 10--The international situation dominated deliberations at the American Farm Bureau Federation today on the eve of its thirty-second annual meeting.

Johann Strauss' operetta, "Die Fledermaus," will be presented on Wednesday evening, Dec. 20, at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time there in forty-five years. The entirely new production was staged by Garson Kanin, with lyrics by Howard Dietz, scenery and costumes by Rolf Gerard and choreography by Antony Tudor.

George Spieler has been elected controller of the Barclay Manufacturing Company, Inc., manufacturer of plastic-coated panels. He was formerly associated with R. H. Macy Co. as corporate accountant for more than fifteen years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--All deliveries of lard sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade last week, removal of hedges against sales of 13,000,000 pounds to the Government for shipment to Yugoslavia being the dominating influence, although there was...

HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 10 (AP)--Delegates of six youth organizations agreed today that West Germany must contribute to the mutual defense of Western Europe against communism, but only on a basis of equality.
Angelica Schuyler Freeman, John A. Bogart, Joseph Gelabert, Henry H. Dahlman, Albert H. Vela, in 7 Lexington Ave--William A. White Sons, brokers.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 10-- Thirty-two young men were named today as recipients of Rhodes Scholarships. The winners, announced here by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, American secretary to the Rhodes trustees, represent twentysix states and twenty-three colleges.
PHILADELPHIA Dec. 10-- Sudden death overtime periods will be played in the event National Football League play-off games in the American and National Conferences should end in tie, next Sunday.

NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 10--A $7,500,000 earth and concrete dam is taking form rapidly in Mansfield Hollow under a $33,335,000 seven-dam flood-control program ordered for the Thames River Valley after the flood and hurricane of 1938.
PARIS, Dec. 10--Communist propaganda is dropping enough grim hints to indicate that this will be an uneasy winter in Europe no matter how the Asiatic crises develops.
Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., will speak at a meeting of the Young Men's Real Estate Association to be held at noon tomorrow at the Williams Club.
One hundred persons attended dedication ceremonies for the new Brooklyn offices of the Urban League of Greater New York, at 1251 Dean Street, yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10--Maj. Gen. Angel J. Solari was named Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army last night. General Solari succeeds Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Sanguinetti, who was among seven generals to request retirement last month on the ground of seniority.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 10-- Four thousand items have been donated for the Christmas gift shop opened by the American Legion Auxiliary at the Veterans Administration Hospital at near-by Crugers. The patients select items that are wrapped and mailed to their families by auxiliary workers, all at no charge to the veterans.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10--Parks Commissioner James F. Murray Sr., who barricaded himself in his third-floor City Hall office Saturday afternoon after being shorn of most of his powers, still held the fort today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP)-- The Air Force plans to spend about $6,000,000,000 for new planes in the current fiscal year, Eugene M. Zuckert, Assistant Secretary, said today.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings scored three second-period goals to come from behind and beat the National Hockey League leading Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--2, here tonight. It was Toronto's first loss in ten starts.
United States Marines and infantrymen who had been trapped along the Changjin Reservoir reached the safety of Hamhung and Hungnam after a fierce, thirteen-day battle.

Connecticut General Life Insurance Company of Hartford, announced yesterday an offer to purchase at least 51 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Puritan Life Insurance Company of Providence, R.I., at $37 a share.

Archbishop Paul Yu-Pin, exiled head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nanking, China, and listed as a top "war criminal" by the Chinese Communist Government, will address an assembly of students at Manhattan College at 2:30 P. M. today.

"Saint Nicholas," patron saint of parts of the Netherlands and, of course, of all boys and girls under his pseudonym of Santa Claus, paraded in midtown yesterday accompanied by "Black Piet," his traditional Moorish retainer.
Johnny Bright, Drake's running and passing ace, established three major college football marks this season in becoming the individual total offense leader of 1950.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10--Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College, tonight advocated an increase in extension-course facilities as a means of providing higher education for those unable to attend college as full-time resident students.
The Rev. Frederick May Eliot of Boston, president of the American Unitarian Association, warned religious liberals yesterday against the hersey of false liberalism.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 10-- Mrs. Edward J. Jackson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Claire, to Seaman 2/c Patrick J. Cassidy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hughes Cassidy of Watertown.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10 (AP)-- Quarterback Paul Rickards pitched a pair of first-half touchdown passes today which gave the Richmond Rebels a 14-0 victory over the Southern Conference Area AllStars in a football game that started in rain, was pelted by hail and ended in a snowstorm.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP)--The Inland Steel Company and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., announced last night a wage agreement patterned after those between the union and other major producers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10--In a wintry setting today at Shibe Park, where snowflakes big as 25-cent pieces made for poor visibility and a slippery ball, the New York Giants squeaked past the Philadelphia Eagles, 9--7, and concluded their regular schedule with a 10and-2 record, tied with the Cleveland Browns for first place in the American Conference of the National Football League.

Sales of seven homes in the Forest City development in Wantagh, L.I., were reported by Trylon Realty, agents for Housing Associates, Inc., the builders. The buyers are James A. Haislip, accountant for Shell Oil; Lieut. Francis P.McElroy, U.S. Navy;...

Raymond A. McMann has been admitted to membership in the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. Mr.McMann, who is also a member of the New York Curb Exchange, will maintain his offices at Laird Company, 61 Broadway.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 (AP)--Nobel Prizes worth nearly $200,000 and inestimable prestige were presented today to nine men from four nations for outstanding services to mankind.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 10 (Reuters)--The Royal Western India Turf Club canceled today's races owing to a strike of racetrack employes. A total of 1,200 workers, including pari-mutuel operators, is striking for a bonus.

The motto of the Boy Scouts is: Be Prepared. a football scout operates on the same principle. A week ago Saturday the largest espionage agent in the business, Jack Lavelle, scouted Navy for the largest coach in the business, Herman Hickman. That in itself would demonstrate the thorough extremes to which scouting is carried these days.
The Metropolitan Conference of Free Churches (Unitarian) will hold a dinner meeting at 6:15 P.M. today at the Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

Mrs. William G. Higgins of 611 West 163d Street has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mary Jean, to William E. Edwards, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis H. Edwards of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding will take place on Dec. 30 in the Riverside Church.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 10 --The sixteenth annual Community Christmas Concert was presented in Convention Hall here today, with proceeds earmarked for Christmas gifts to the underprivileged children of this area. An audience of more than 3,000 attended the concert, which was directed by G. Howard Scott.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 (Reuters)-- The advance party of the New Zealand force on its way to Korea arrived here today. Five officers and seventeen other ranks, making up the party, were led by the force commander Brigadier R. S. Park. The main body of New Zealanders sailed from Wellington today.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 10 (AP)-- 500 police and 400 demonstrators in Kyoto yesterday afternoon resulted in injuries to thirty-three police and thirty rioters, the newspaper Asahi reported today.

The Brookhattan-Galicia team lost to the Irish Americans, 2--1, at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, and the Brooklyn Hispanos bowed, 4--2, to the Philadelphia Nationals at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, in American Soccer League games yesterday. Philadelphia took first place on its victory.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP) --Lawrence B. Sheppard, master of the famed Hanover (Pa.) Shoe Farms, today was elected president of the United States Trotting Association at the association's board of directors meeting. He succeeds the late Henry--Knauf of Ladd, Ill.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 10--Albert C. Goebel, secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic City Electric Company and treasurer of the New Jersey Utilities Association, died of a heart attack on the Atlantic City Country Club's golf course at...

The American Veterans Committee announced yesterday it would begin its plan to recruit and train civil defense volunteers tomorrow at the Cameron Hotel, 47 West Eighty-sixth Street. Capt. William McDonald of the Twentyfourth precinct with his defense aides, Sgt. William Fenty and Patrolman Bernard Duhan, will be on hand to enroll volunteers.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP)--Dr. Eugene L. Smith, a foreign mission executive, said tonight that "despite all adversities, Christianity lives and even grows" in Communist China.

Women volunteers are asked to participate in a street sale Saturday for the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. The money collected will supplement the Christmas Seal Sale to raise additional needed funds for the prevention and control of tuberculosis in this city. Volunteers will be equipped with identified coin cans, arm bands and identification cards.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP) --This city's second major downtown fire within forty-eight hours was brought under control early today. The four-story Starr Department Store, the upper floors of an adjoining bank and two other buildings were swept by flames. Authorities said damage in the two fires might reach $1,500,000.

Columbia University has begun to put on microfilm records and documents that it hopes to preserve in the event of an atomic bomb attack. The microfilming is only one task of a newly formed university council on civil defense, charged with the protection of life, property and records in case of emergency.
Universal Bible Sunday was observed yesterday in most of this city's Protestant churches and over several radio networks.

A five-day driver education course for teachers in New York State will start this morning at Teachers College, Columbia University. Dr. Clifford L. Brownell, chairman of the health and physical education department of the college, said yesterday that one of the objectives was to help reduce...

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec, 10 --Gen. Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator of Veterans Affairs, speaking at the dedication of a new $12,000,000 Veterans Administration hospital, said today that "we will never lower the standards of medical care to our patients."
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 10 (AP)-- United Nations and United States officials said today they, intended to remain in Korea despite the menace of advancing Chinese Communist troops.

Master plans for transportation, hospitals, schools and libraries are among the city's most pressing planning needs for the immediate future, Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission, told Mayor Impellitteri in an informal report yesterday.
The thirty-ninth annual Christmas appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened yesterday with donations of $36,534.03 from 289 contributors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP) --Southpaw Quarterback Frank Albert led the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 30-to-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers today in the final game of the season for the two National Football League rivals.

The Horn Hardart Company will open a restaurant on Wednesday in the main shopping center of the Fresh Meadows apartment development built by the New York Life Insurance Company in Fresh Meadows, Queens. The restaurant, designed by Ralph B. Benker and John J. McNamara, architects, is located at Horace Harding Boulevard and 190th Street.
The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday plans for the construction of a new ore-carrying vessel, which it said would be the largest ship in the history of inland Water transportation.

Toy sales are expected to exceed last year's $300,000,000, manufacturers' value, in spite of many producers' inability to fill reorders of items containing steel and other materials in short supply. A statement to that effect was made yesterday by Arthur M. Raphael, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc., at a board of directors meeting at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

Several dinner parties will be given before the "Night of Cards" tonight in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Among the prospective hostesses are Mrs. Harry C. Mills and Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler.

KOTO, North Korea, Dec. 10-- United States and British Marines gave first aid, food and water to about fifty wounded Chinese Communist prisoners today and left them in a heated house, to be recovered after United Nations troops left here.

Helen Hayes and her two proteges, Bethel Leslie and John Stix, will address a meeting of the Outer Circle at 7:30 tonight in the ANTA Playhouse. The group consists of drama critics and editors attached to out-of-town papers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Mr. Zuckert said that it would take a year to a year and a half for the effects of the huge Air Force spending program to be realized. The Air Force was at a fortyeight-group level when the Korean war started.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Senators reported today that the divorced wife of an ex-Communist had not borne out her former husband's charges that Mrs. Anna, M. Rosenberg had attended Communist-front meetings.
TOKYO, Dec. 10 (AP)--Release 714, issued by General MacArthur's headquarters at 4 P. M. Sunday (2 A. M. Sunday, Eastern standard time):
CHICAGO, Dec.10 (AP)--Big Ten athletic directors today voted to renew the contract of Commissioner K. L. (Tug) Wilson, subject to discussion of terms of salary and tenure.

PARIS, Dec. 10 (UP)--The auctioning of seventy-two Dutch old masters brought art dealers from all over the world to Paris this week-end. The collection, assembled by a wealthy Dutch dealer at the Charpentier Gallery, brought 72,400,000 francs (about $260,000).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The Defense Department said tonight that casualties had stepped up sharply in the last two weeks in Korea but that many were attributable to such things as frostbite and exposure that would render a man unfit for fighting.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 10 (UP) --The eighth Earl of Essex and his willowy blonde bride, who were roused out of their honeymoon cottage last night with the shattering news that they had not been married at all, breakfasted late today after a midnight wedding.

The Rev. John Summerfield Wimbish, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday that God would judge nations "whose rulers counsel together without reverencing His Holy Name." Mr. Wimbish declared that "every nation that has turned away from God has perished."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A steady decline since 1946 in the amount of United States foreign trade carried in American flag ships was reported today.

Domestic cotton prices fluctuated widely last week, influenced by uncertainty over price controls. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 55 points lower to 6 points higher than the closing levels of the preceding week. The near-by positions registered declines ranging between 20 and 55 points.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP)--George Blanda kicked two field goals in the mud of Wrigley Field to give the Chicago Bears a 6-3 National Football League triumph over the Detroit Lions today and push them into a divisional title play-off with the Rams in Los Angeles next Sunday.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 10 (UP)-- Harry Agganis, former Boston University star, scored three touchdowns and passed for another today to lead the Camp Lejeune Marines to a 32--7 victory over the Keesler Air Force Base Fliers in the first annual Electronics Bowl game here.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Mander of 455 East Fifty-seventh Street on Nov. 26 in the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Mander is the former Miss Diantha Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cannon Lawrence of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street. The child will be named Richard.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10--Myron Field of New York and Sydney Silodor of Philadelphia took the lead in the semi-final round of the National Open Pair Championships at the twenty-fourth annual winter tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here today.

Extremely dangerous fire hazards are involved in Christmas trees and the use of candles, cotton and other flammable substances in Yuletide decorations, Acting Fire Commissioner Nathan C. Horwitz warned yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10--The engagement has been announced of Miss Catherine Carter Middleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Atherton Middleton, formerly of Philadelphia, to Joseph S. Sollers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sollers of Baltimore.
The fourth wind and rainstorm in fifteen days was advancing on the city last midnight.

As the House last week was approving the Administration's version of an excess profits tax with minor modifications, the Senate Finance Committee began hearings preliminary to writing a companion measure.

Fourteen more days till Christmas, Time to whip up some attractive gifts for those who like holiday finery. Nothing could be easier if you wlll follow the instructions that we will forward to you, free of charge, if you write in for them according to directions.

Aldo Ciccolini, young Italian pianist who made his American debut a month ago with the Philharmonic-Symphony, gave his first local recital last night in Town Hall. His interpretations drew prolonged applause and a few cheers of approval from a sizable audience.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Vice President Thomas F. McMains of Western Union, said today recent completion of a $90,000,000 mechanization and plant improvement program doubled capacity of the company's telegraph system and vastly increased its speed and efficiency.

Henry Randolph Sutphen, since 1947 chairman of the executive committee of the Electric Boat Company, 445 Park Avenue, with which he had been associated since 1892, died unexpectedly yesterday morning of a stroke in his sleep at his residence, 876 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old.

After surviving eighteen rounds without defeat, Dr. Max Euwe, Dutch schoolmaster and once holder of the world championship, lost yesterday to Herman Pilnik of Buenos Aires in the international chess tournament, according to a report from Amsterdam.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 10 (AP)--The Prague radio reported today the arrival of a Czechoslovak delegation in Peiping. Its mission is to strengthen cultural relations with Communist China, the radio said.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 10--An American educator who taught Dutch Boy Scouts to carve Indian totem poles received the thanks of Queen Juliana today.
The election of Alexander E. Lapointe as a vice president and trust officer of Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit was announced over the week-end by Charles A.Kanter, chairman.
ROSLYN, L.I., Dec.10--There is at least one school in the New York City public school system that never has an absent or tardy member.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Sentiment swelled in Congress today for quick application of mandatory price-wage controls.

Robert M.Wellwood has been elected chairman of the board of the Sheffield Farms Company, C. R. Roberts, president and chief executive officer, and Edward H. Miller, executive vice president, it was announced over the week-end by L. A.Van Bomel, president of the National Dairy Products Corporation, parent organization.
HONG KONG, Dec. l0(AP)--This British colony virtually has stopped functioning economically as the result of the United States ban on critical exports that might find their way into Communist hands.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade last week with trading broadening. For the first time in months wheat became the market leader with all deliveries except December selling at a new high for the season as did December corn and December, March and May oats, the greater part of the upturn being maintained.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10--In preparation for the first meeting of stockholders ever held on the mainland the Hawaiian Pineapple Company as flown six of its employes, from Honolulu to give an illustrated review of the year's operations.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 10-- The Larchmont Yacht Club's winter dinghy sailors, utilizing improvised and temporary facilities, got back in racing stride today after two weeks of idleness due to the big storm of two Saturdays ago.

"The Bigelow Theatre," a new half-hour dramatic show, had an acceptable premiere at 6 o'clock last night on C. B. S. Television. Its initial presentation was an original short play called "The Sum of Seven," by Robert Meade and Sheldon Osborne.
Moscow, Dec. 10 (AP)--Pravde carried both a word of praise and criticism today for Communist newspapers in Prague and Rome.

Events tonight: "The Magic Flute," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Gyorgy Sandor, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; The Musicians' Guild, Town Hall, 8:30; Ruby Yoshino, soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Special Members' Concert, Hotel Plaza, 8:45.

The New York Wellesley Club's anuual luncheon will be planned at a meeting of committee members on Thursday in the home of Mrs. R. O. Hopkins of 270 Park Avenue. The luncheon will be held on Feb. 3 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Miss Mary E. Chase, executive vice president of Wellesley College, is to speak.

M. Salzman, distributor for Domestic Sewing Machines, received the 1950 certificate of award at the annual convention of the Retail Sewing Machine Merchants Association, Inc., at the Grand Street Boys Clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-sixth Street, on Saturday.

The election of Hans A. Vogelstein, now secretary, as treasurer of the American Metal Company, Ltd., was announced by the company over the week-end. He will succeed William H. Brady, who will retire as treasurer on Jan. 1, after fifty-six years of active service. Mr.Brady, however, will continue as consultant to the company.

LONDON, Dec. 10--The "grievous situation" of the British coal industry was cited today by Sir Eric Young, who resigned last week as production member of the National Coal Board, which operates the Government-owned industry.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,596,210,314. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Dispatches to this newspaper point out a gradually changing climate of opinion in India. There is a growing coolness toward the Chinese Communists and a corresponding sympathetic swing in the general direction of the West. Such a change can be of great significance in the days ahead.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP)-- While fire swept a basement chapel of St. Richard's Catholic Church today celebration of mass upstairs continued without interruption. Fire Marshal George Kington said that the fire was started accidentally by an altar boy lighting candles for a children's mass.

An electronic system for checking freight has been put in force in the Republic Carloading and Distributing Company's depot at Houston, Tex. The system, which is aimed at speeding the processing of freight, employs one central controller who receives reports from every freight car through an inter-com network. If the experiment is successful, said William R.Mote, chairman of the board, it will be extended to other Republic Carloading depots.

A plea for an organically united American Protestantism was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Hugh Ivan Evans, Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., in his first sermon here as titular head of the denomination.
An all-time high of $484,875,000 was reached in heavy construction contract awards reported for the nation in the week ended last Monday, The Engineering NewsRecord declares.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 10-- The first American expedition to Mount Everest has returned to New Delhi after a pioneering investigation into the mysteries of the earth's highest peak that will be a future source of material to mountaineers everywhere.

Santa Claus came to town yesterday and stopped at the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street. With 125 members of the Fire Department's Holy Name Society he distributed a thousand toys among 200 children who live in foster homes.
Marshall Butler, a pianist from Kentucky, made his debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP) --Ohio State University was looking today for its fifth head football coach in a decade.
Little does Broadway realize that 2,000 teachers, members of the American Educational Theatre Association, are employed to inculcate in the next generation the rudiments of the stage.
ELLENTON, S. C., Dec. 10 (UP) --A photographer and a writer for Redbook magazine were roughed up and asked to leave this town today by offended churchgoers they were trying to photograph.

THE island of Manhattan has fascinated foreign visitors for several hundred years. Many of them have written books about it which in turn have fascinated the residents of Manhattan. Some of these books were written by Frenchmen, most of them by Englishmen.

STOCKTON, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) --The San Joaquin River, overloaded by dozens of flooded-tributaries and backed up by high tides, poured through several levees south of Stockton today, driving hundreds of lowland residents from their homes.

CAMP PICKETT, Va., Dec. 10-- Cpl. Huston J. Meadows, 32 years old, of Birmingham, Ala., does not have to worry about a present for his mother this Christmas. He is going to write her a letter in his own handwriting--and he knows it will be the greatest Christmas present he could give her.
GRANTS, N. M., Dec. 10--A Navajo Indian, riding horseback through a forest, has made what, according to incomplete surveys by mining engineers, may be one of the country's richest uranium strikes.

OSSINING, N. Y., Dec. 10--Mr. and Mrs. Moses Myers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ellen, to Edward S. Rosett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Rosett of New Rochelle. Miss Myers was graduated from the University of Wisconsin and Mr. Rosett from the University of Connecticut.

An unusual new free-form coffee table is at Hathaway, 51 West Forty-fifth Street. A thin slice of the trunk of the monkeypod tree is used to veneer a table top that looks surprisingly like a slab of wood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP)-- The United States Olympic Committee is "alarmed" over poor response to its appeal for $200,000 to send 114 athletes to the first PanAmerican Games, scheduled for Buenos Aires, Feb. 25-March 8, J. Lyman Bingham, executive director of the U.S.Olympic Association,said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Push-button flying has caught up with aerial warfare in jet fighters. A new automatic pilot, already in production, is reported able to take jet planes smoothly through good or bad weather, guide them safely to the runway and possibly even fire their guns aimed by radar.
WITH U.S. MARINES, Korea, Dec. 10--United States Marines walked out of almost a fortnight of freezing hell today, full of fight after a nightmare of death in Korea's icy mountains.

VIENNA, Dec. 10--Recent events have thrown new light on the Molotov Plan, or Council for Economic Mutual Assistance. So little of its operations has been heard that the Western world has dismissed it as an empty bluff.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP)-- Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted today that some wage-price controls would soon become necessary.

LONDON, Dec. 10--Although Britain recognized Communist China more than eleven months ago the Chinese Embassy building in stately Portland Place, London, stands empty. The Foreign Office says there are "no plans" for new tenants.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10--The Rev. Harry B. Ansted, former president of Seoul University in Korea, has been elected executive secretary of the Laymen's Missionary Movement,it was announced here today.

Robert D. Witte, a senior at New York University's College of Arts and Science, has been appointed president of Perstare et Praestare, the undergraduate honorary society for extra-curricular activities on the school's Bronx campus. M. Ronald Ruskin was made secretary of the society.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP)--Pete Cooper and Claude Harmon today annexed the $10,000 Miami international four-ball golf tournament by defeating Dave Douglas and Jim Turnesa in the thirty-six-hole final, 1 up.

ZURICH, Dec. 10--By referendum on Dec.3 the Swiss people decided by an overwhelming majority of 515,485 to 226,868 that the provisional fiscal system now in vogue should remain in force until the end of 1954 to allow Parliament time to make concrete proposals, ...

YONKERS, Dec. 10--John A. Brady, superintendent of the Building Inspection Bureau here, reports that in the first eleven months of this year 1,435 plans were filed for $20,505,198 of construction. This was $2,459,683 more than in the same period of 1949.
Bunny Lane, a singer in "Pardon Our French," will be married to William DeWire tonight in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew. It will be the fifth wedding in the troupe.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 10 --Hope Portocarrero de Bayle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nesto Portocarrero of Miami, Fla., was married to Col. Anastacio Somoza Jr., son of President and Mrs. Somoza, in Managua Cathedral this evening by Archbishop Jose Antonio Lezcano of Managua.
The scope and objectives of the program of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey begin to take on greater definition with the Board of Estimate approval of four surveys at a cost of $189,400.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (AP)--Joe Geri broke two all-time Pittsburgh team records while passing and running the Steelers to a 28-7 victory over the Chicago Cardinals today before 18,301 fans at Forbes Field.

Since every writer has to begin sometime, let us agree that Phillip Pruneau has made his Broadway debut. His first play, "The Cellar and the Well," was put on at the ANTA Playhouse yesterday afternoon, and everything he does in the future is bound to be an improvement.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., Dec.10-- The First Army General Prisoner Rehabilitation Center has been transferred here from Fort Devens, Mass. Maj. Marshall J. Smith is the center's commanding officer.

A funeral service for Edward R. Anker, newspaper man and publicist; who died on Thursday in his home, 230 Central Park West, was held yesterday in Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial took place in Bayside Cemetery, Queens.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 10-- Compulsory military training for high school and normal school students' will start early in January in Formosa. Before June it will be extended to all boys above grammar' school grades.

CAMDEN,N.J.,Dec. 10--The very good trick that is turned every once in a great while of the same dog taking top honors at two major all-breed shows the same week-end was completed today in the nineteenth event of the Camden County Kennel Club.

DANVILLE,Va., Dec. 10--Textile industrialists in the South are beginning to feel the impact of the Korean crisis. Growing shortages, have developed in chemical supplies needed in bleacheries and dye houses.

Events last night in Carnegie Hall followed the normal pattern for a Kirsten Flagstad post-war concert--with one exception. No picket line was marching around the front of the hall, nor were there exterior demonstrations of any kind.

Although Caesar Dunn's comedy, "Maggie," was not produced on Broadway, the screen rights were purchased by Paramount at a reported price of $25,000. Trial performances of the play were given in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in March, 1949.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec.10 (UP) --Four children, all members of the same family, were killed here today when flames flashed through an apartment house.

A farmhouse built 110 years ago is being razed on the Baush farm at Hempstead Turnpike and Florence Avenue in Bethpage, L.I., to make way for a colony of 203 dwellings. The development will comprise forty-six acres and will include the Baush farm of thirty-one acres and the former Zorn farm of fifteen acres.
If you read yesterday the stories of the hundred families in the City of New York who are in most desperate need of help and guidance, no further appeal to you is necessary.

The appointment of Vincent H. Jefferds as eastern sales manager of the Nu-Enamel Corporation, Chicago, has been announced by D.C.Plummer, president. Mr.Jefferds formerly was assistant to the president of the Times Square Stores Corporation. The company plans a campaign which will include promotion of the full line of interior and exterior products.
Refusal of the Motion Picture Association of America to approve the movie, "Oliver Twist," was protested yesterday by the National Council on Freedom from Censorship.

Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers snapped a three-game losing streak last night by handing the rugged Indianapolis Olympians a 106-84 defeat in a National Basketball Association battle at Madison Square Garden.

The Save the Children Federation, 80 Eighth Avenue, will give a tea in its headquarters in honor of Mrs. Lothian Small, deputy general secretary of the International Union for Child Welfare, Geneva, Switzerland, Thursday at 4 P. M. She is representing her union at the Mid-Century White House Conference on Children and Youth.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., Brooklyn chemical manufacturer, will enlarge its Croton, Conn., plant and will install new equipment to increase the output of citric acid. The expansion will double the plants' production capacity. Pfizer recently announced a one-year price freeze for citric acid, effective through Aug. 31.

DENVER, Dec. 10 (AP)--Four soldiers from Camp Carson, near Colorado Springs, were fatally injured in a highway smash-up early today and died on the way to a hospital. Their car crashed against a bridge abutment three miles south of Fountain on U.S. Highway 85-87.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10 (AP)--The dread locust plague is darkening the skies over vast areas of Africa and Southwest Asia, threatening millions of impoverished people with famine.

The balance in the State Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund is nearly $78,000,000 higher than it was seven months ago, before unemployment rolls began melting under the combined impact of high-level consumer spending and the Korean war.

CATANIA, Sicily, Dec. 10(AP)-- A massive wall of fiery lava more than 2,000 feet wide and forty-six feet deep, flowing down from Mt. Etna's craters menaced the harassed villages of Milo and Renazzo today.
LONDON, Dec. 10--The first instance in which a shortage of raw materials has caused a curtailment of production in Britain was reported tonight by a manufacturer in Westmoreland, northern England.
A disaster plan for the medical profession in the event of atomic attack was issued yesterday by Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

Pre-Christmas "office parties" that "ignore the sacred character of Advent" and are marked by "an excessive use of intoxicating drinks" were condemned yesterday at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

HAVANA, Dec. 10 (AP)--The Maritime Workers Federation decided last night to boycott sugar shipments to Red China. The decision was taken specifically against the ship Hellenic, originally British, but now under the Honduran flag and undergoing repair work in Philadelphia. She is scheduled to come to Cuba to pick up a sugar cargo for Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (U.P.)-- Allen B. Du Mont, television manufacturer, said today that if Congress passed the pending excessprofits tax bill his company might reduce prices to cut down its tax bill.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP)-- John (Ox) Da Grosa, Pennsylvania Athletic Commissioner, said tonight he is starting a move to bar Joe Louis from boxing in this state and will petition the National Boxing Association to do likewise.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--The Chicago Crime Commission, a frequent critic of the top administration of the Chicago Police Department, has drawn up a tentative program involving pay and promotion policies for the department.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Every state in the Union now has adopted civil defense legislation or established a civil defense organization by executive order, the Council of State Governments said today.
MADRID, Dec. 10--Generalissimo Francisco Franco demanded the return of Gibraltar to Spain in an interview published today in Arriba, official newspaper of the Falange party.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 10--Ferdinand A. Gerhardt, 59-year-old former automobile agency executive, was arraigned in First District Court here today on a felony charge of drunken driving as a second offender.
A three-year wage agreement embodying basic features of the General Motors labor-peace formula was signed yesterday by American Airlines and Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C.I.O.

Miss Fern Ledgerwood, Y. W. C. A. secretary on leave from Bangkok, Thailand, is scheduled to speak at a meeting of the eightieth anniversary division of the Y. W. C. A. building and program fund tonight at the "Y" Studio Club, 210 East Seventyseventh Street.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 10-- Robert Barr, with an 80--13--67, topped a field of fifty-five as qualifying play started in fortythird annual Snowbirds' golf tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club today. Thomas Sheehe, with 28--8--70, and Ken Benta, with 81--11--70, deadlocked for runnerup honors.

Schubert's Octet, Op. 166, which takes almost an hour to play, was the featured work of yesterday's concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. Although it was placed at the end of the program, no one seemed to get restless.

Harry Mayer, pianist, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. His program consisted of the Bach-Liszt G minor Fantasy and Fugue, two Bach-Busoni Choral Preludes, an Intermezzo by Brahms and the B minor Rhapsody, Beethoven's D minor Sonata (Op. 31, No. 2), the Sonata No. 3 by Maxwell Powers and pieces by Debussy, Satie, Poulence and Chopin.
William L. Lewis, president of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, has been elected a director of the First Bank and Trust Company of Utica, N. Y.

The Right Rev. William Wallace Horstick, bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Eau Claire, Wis., in a sermon here yesterday stressed the importance of fellowship to Christian survival. He preached at the Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, at Broadway and 155th Street.
An appeal for funds to hire more personnel to work as appraisers to relieve congestion at the Port of New York has been sent to Washington by the National Council of American Importers, Inc.
ATLANTA, Dec. 10. -- William R. Elsas of this city, president of the Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills, died yesterday of a heart attack at Tryon, N. C. He was 45 years old.

The Women's National Republican Club is sending Christmas gifts to veterans' hospitals in eleven states. Mrs. Frederick S. Ely is chairman of the club's hospital service committee, which includes Mrs. Paul Milton and Mrs. Edward F. Wood.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10-- The marriage of Miss Mildred Fenton of New York to William Goetze of San Francisco took place here this afternoon in the Swedenborgian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Othmar Tobish. A reception was held at the Bohemian Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10-- American, men are still dying off faster than women, figures released by the United States Publice Health Service showed today.

The Displaced Persons Commission is finding itself besieged with requests from employers for skilled factory hands and farm workers to relieve labor shortages in this country, Harry N. Rosenfield, a member of the commission, reported yesterday.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 10--A series of earthquakes rocked Peruvian cities and Northern Chile last night, killing at least five persons and injuring thirteen.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP)--Fels Institute for Study of Human Developments at Antioch College announced today perfection of a "revolutionary" artificial heart-lung so simple any laboratory technician can build it. Institute scientists say that "it is ready for use on human beings."

DARLINGTON, S. C., Dec. 10 (AP)--Johnny Parsons of Van Nuys, Calif., the favorite, today won the 200-mile championship big car race at the Darlington International Speedway at a speed of better than 10 miles an hour.
Louis H. Bean, political analyst, declared yesterday that the results of the recent election were not nearly so unfavorable to the Democratic party as generally believed.

"It is no wonder the world can't straighten itself out with diplomacy when everyone thinks the other is telling lies and that only he is right," John Haynes Holmes declared in a sermon yesterday at the Community Church.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 10 (Reuters)--The South Korean legislative system faced complete breakdown tonight as panic-stricken Deputies fled southward and left the National Assembly without a quorum.

Attorney General J. Howard McGrath pledged his efforts yesterday toward liberalization of the nation's immigration laws, but at the same time emphasized that the Government would continue to take every precaution to prevent the entry of subversives.
Daniel F. Rice Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and other principal exchanges, have announced the removal of their offices from One Wall Street to 521 Fifth Avenue.

A revival of "Dark of the Moon," opening Dec. 24, will be the first attraction at the Sheridan Square Arena Theatre. It will be staged by Jose Quintero. The cast will be headed by Mary Ann Weller, James Ray and Jason Wingreen. The choreography will be directed by Charles Curtis.
PARIS, Dec. 10--Theodore Steeg, former Senator, who was a Minister many times and, for a brief time, Premier of France, died here today at the age of 82.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Givath Washington, a youth village made possible by funds raised principally in the Washington area, was dedicated today in the presence of United States Ambassador James G. McDonald and high Israeli officials.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 10--Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Kathleen Sharp, daughter of Fell Sharp and the late Mrs. Sharp, to Capt. William A. Montgomery, Maritime Service, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Motgomery of Belmont, Mass. The wedding will take place in April.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 (UP)--Georges Metaxa, Rumanianborn actor and singer, died Friday night in a Monroe (La.) hotel, friends here reported today. He was 51 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--With Otto Graham completing passes almost at will, the Cleveland Browns today snowed under the Washington Redskins, 45--21, in the last twenty minutes of a furious contest played in a driving snowstorm before 30,706 at Griffith Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Spokesmen for sixteen nonoperating unions who bargain for 1,000,000 railroad employes are expected to file a demand soon for "mass" mediation in their dispute with the carriers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10-- Jack Benny will return to the screen after an absence of five years in "A Story for Grown-ups," a film adaptation of the 1948 Broadway play, "Time for Elizabeth," which Jerry Wald and Norman Krasna will produce at R.K.O. next summer.

Adolf Gobel, Inc., has announced the acquisition of the meat processing plant and equipment of DeAngelis Packing Company and the inventory of meat and supplies of DeAngelis Packing Company, Inc., in North Bergen, N. J. The consideration given included cash, notes and 260,000 shares of Adolf Gobel, Inc., common stock.

DALLAS, Dec. 10 (AP)--The head of the nation's wool-growing industry said today that America played into Russia's hands by failing to stockpile woolen cloth.

Fenimore Cooper Council, Boy Scouts of America, with offices in White Plains, and Hendrick Hudson Council, with offices in Ossining, have been consolidated into a new council to be known as Washington Irving Council, the National Council announced yesterday. Offices will be in White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Committee for the Nation's Health issued a statement today denouncing the American Medical Association's "new multi-million dollar drive against Federal aid to medical schools to train more doctors."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 10-- Work under way on United States and other foreign assistance projects for Thailand calls for an expenditure of nearly $35,000,000 during the next few years. This sum is likely to be augmented by new United States appropriations during 1951 and in subsequent years.

"The Hayvens of Demeret," a historical novel by Katherine Bellamann, is planned for spring publication by Simon Schuster. It is described as a romantic novel of the ante-bellum South and of the struggle of twin brothers for the same woman.
MANHASSET, L.I.,Dec, 10-- Philadelphia won the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament today for the first time since 1939 in the Greentree court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney.

ROME, Dec. 10 (UP)--Pope Pius XII will hold a secret consistory tomorrow to name cardinal legates to seal the Holy Doors of Rome's great basilicas Christmas Eve, officially closing the 1950 Holy Year. The Pope will seal the great door at St. Peter's Basilica.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Murdock of Sierra Madre, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan, to Robert B. Philipp, son of Mrs. Ruth M. Philipp of Eatontown, N. J., and Frederick B. Philipp of Middletown, N. J. Miss Murdock is a senior at Scripps College in Claremont, Calif. WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The Interstate Commerce Commission today announced the election of Commissioner Walter M. W. Splawn of Texas as its chairman for 1951. He is a Democrat.

The Metropolitan Edison Company, which serves the Reading, Pa., area, sold new issues of firstmortgage bonds and preferred stock of $7,250,000 principal value yesterday to banking syndicates at competitive bidding.
Television's bugaboo--the fear of forgetting lines in front of cameras --has been virtually ended by an electronic prompter.
Audience participation--at no extra cost to the customer--is an important factor in the development of "Let's Make an Opera," opening at 8:15 this evening at the Golden.

WASHINGTON Dec. 12--Brig. Gen. William preston Wooten, Army Corps of Engineers, retired, and former editor of its official publication, died today in Walter Reed Hospital, after a two weeks' illness. He was 77 years old.

The second of two prisoners who escaped Saturday from the Federal Detention Headquarters, 427 West Street, was picked up at 3 P.M. yesterday by Federal Bureau of Inestigation agents on Thirty-fourth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

A year ago yesterday the water in the city's reservoirs reached its lowest level of the 1949-1950 shortage. On Dec. 12, 1949, reservoir storage was only 84,638,000,000 gallons, 33.4 per cent of capacity.

Because the United States is outnumbered by its "potential enemies" in terms of manpower, in any future mobilization it will have to use every man who possesses no major disqualifying defect, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of a comprehensive study of the nation's manpower, declared yesterday.
A television Series designed to instruct New Yorkers on what to do in case of an atom bomb attack will be initiated early in January by WJZ-TV, local station for the American Broadcasting Company.

Suspension of partisan politics and complete national unity to meet the threatening international situation caused by the war in Korea and the aggressive policies of Communist Russia were urged last night by Senator Herbert H. Lehman and William M. Boyle Jr., Democratic National Chairman.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina expressed the opinion yesterday that the Government's civil antitrust action against seventeen major investment banking houses would fall if opening arguments by defense counsel were supported by the evidence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--President Truman will create a central war production agency and declare a state of emergency by Friday, informed sources said today.

Ceramic or stoneware vases to hold a branch, in blossom, delicate flowers or one perfect rose may be a last minute thought to complete the Christmas shopping gift list. Many of these new vases are beautiful enough to be decorative pieces even without flowers or leaves.

Mystery last night surrounded the whereabouts of Fireman Hugh P. Moran of 24-32 Twenty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, one of seventy-five firemen and policemen questioned about the reported theft of electrical appliances Saturday night at the scene of a twoalarm fire in Flushing, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The Army tonight moved its manpower requirements sharply ahead and asked Selective Service to order 160,000 recruits into training camps in January and February.

The stock market was highly indecisive yesterday. Fluctuations in prices were irregular most of the session, with few net changes in excess of a point. The composite rate fell 0.67 point. However, more issues-advanced than declined.

The city's Bureau of Smoke Control believes that fuel dealers can make their contribution to cleaning up New York's air, and it has been our own observation that some of these dealers at least are eager to cooperate in any way they can.

The City of San Antonio, Texas, sold yesterday $26,300,000 electric and gas system revenue refunding bonds due on Feb. 1, 1952 to 1972 to a banking syndicate headed by the Union Securities Corporation at an interest cost of 1.7856 per cent. The bid was 100 for 2 s, 2s and 1 s.

Prices of cotton futures closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final quotations were 33 points lower to 19 points higher.

The trustees of the Boy Shore Public Library have sold the onestory building on a plot 66 by 99 feet on the west side of Third Avenue, 200 feet north of East Main Street, in Bay Shore, L. I., to South Shore Associates, Inc. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12--The National Production Authority has undertaken a materials conservation program to be administered in connection with its system of allocating critical commodities, H. B. McCoy, assistant administrator of the authority, said today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12 (AP) --A twenty-five-week Grand Circuit harness racing schedule for 1951, to start in New York in May and end in California in December, was announced today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 (UP)-- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission held up today the $500 reward Jimmy Walker won for risking his life twenty months ago to pull a taxi driver from his burning cab.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Acts of "naked aggression" by Communist forces have brought the hour when this country must mobilize its manpower and resources on a huge scale, including two years of universal military service for all young men of 18, a newly formed Committee on the Present Danger announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 12--In a continued recovery in the stock markets here today, the brightest sections were those for the gold mining and oil shares. "Bear squeeze" at the end of the bookkeeping account and a more favorable interpretation of the political and military situation brought firmness to nearly all markets.

Abbott Court, a ninety-two-family apartment house in Radburn, Bergen County, N. J., has been sold to Abbott Court, Radburn, Inc., a New York investment group, through Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers.

PARIS, Dec. 12--Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, told the Assembly today that "we are on the eve of a four-power conference." His reference was to a meeting of the foreign ministers of Britain, the United States and France with the Soviet Union, which is under discussion as a result of Moscow's proposal for a conference on Germany.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12-- The name of the late Carr V. Van Anda, former managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, praised as "one of the dominating figures of American journalism so long as the United States has a free press," was enshrined in the Ohio Journalism Hall of Fame at Ohio State University here tonight.
Reports from Caracas, Venezuela, indicate that the first shipments of high-grade iron ore from that country will start on their way to the United States next month.

Wholesale egg prices dropped 12 to 15 cents a dozen in New York yesterday. Leading grocery chains announced almost immediately that retail prices would be cut 12 to 14 cents, effective today.

Dr. John J. Donovan, surgeon and general medical practitioner, died yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a brief illness. Dr. Donovan, who was 71 years old, resided and had his office at 413 East 139th Street, the Bronx.

A West Point cadet, children who saved their pennies, a resident of Havana, Cuba, doctors and patients in hospitals were among those who contributed yesterday to the thirty-ninth annual Christmas appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP)-- The National Association of Food Chains, in a telegram to President Truman today, pledged full support in the national emergency and the maintenance of the orderly distribution of food "at the lowest cost possible." The association is composed of more than 200 companies operating more than 15,000 food stores.
AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 16 (AP) --Dartmouth's basketball forces poured in 10 points during the last two minutes tonight to beat Amherst, 59--49. It was Amherst's fourth straight setback.

WINNETKA, Ill., Dec. 16--Miss Helen Clayton was married to Alfred A. Rossin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Rossin of New York, this afternoon in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Clayton. Judge Robson, Chief Judge of the Superior Court of Cook County, performed the ceremony.

The continuing appeal of the annual Christmas programs of the Trapp Family Singers was demonstrated again yesterday, when an audience of 1,400 assembled at Town Hall in the late afternoon to hear the talented members of the family give one of their familiar programs.

ALBANY, Dec. 16--The appointment of Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley as special counsel to the State Division of Veterans Affairs at an annual salary of $16,000 was announced today by Leo V. Lanning, director of the division.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 17--United Nations forces pulled back yesterday from the wrecked industrial city of Hamhung on the beleaguered northeast Korean beachhead to form a tight perimeter around the seaport of Hungnam.

DALLAS, Dec. 16--Wartime eligibility rules for athletes were returned to the by-laws of the Southwest Conference today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP)-- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, pledged today that the federation's 8,000,000 members would forego strikes during the national emergency if President Truman asked them to.
