TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP)--The Japanese Government thanked the United Nations today for its proposed investigation of Japanese war prisoners still held by the Soviet Union.

NEWARK, Dec. 16--Cost-of-living salary increases for 3,000 employes of Essex County were approved last night at a special meeting of the Essex County Board of Freeholders. It is expected that the increases will add $900,000 to the payroll budget of $9,000,000. The increases become effective immediately.

Miss Isabel Macy Harwood was marned to John G. Van Deusen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Deusen of Geneva, N.Y., yesterday afternoon in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Harwood of Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)-- The Defense Department identified today 584 more United States casualties in the Korean area, including 60 killed, 450 wounded, 30 injured in accidents and 44 missing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)-- Action to keep raw materials supplies and prices in line is being taken as a direct result of the recent conversations here of President Truman and Prime Minister Attlee.

GENEVA, Dec. 16 (AP)--A United Nations-sponsored seven-nation conference on alcoholism recommended today that special clinics be set up in general hospitals throughout the world for the treatment of alcoholics. CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP)--Most grain contracts punched their way into new high ground in a broad, active market on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans, soybean oil and lard raced upward with cereals.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur has been named "Man of the Year" in a poll conducted by The London Daily Express, which says it has a circulation of more than 4,200,000. The poll named Winston Churchill "Man of the Year in Britain."

Cecilia Marin, Mexican soprano, made her New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Times Hall, The singer donned a Spanish costume and played castanets for her performance of de Falla's seven Canciones Populares.
Customs collections at this port continued their upward climb last month, again setting a new high for the year by totaling $31,818664.

This year, in the fourth annual judging of plum puddings in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen, highest scores went for the first time to two English entries. In a blindfold tasting just held, twenty of the puddings now in the stores were sampled; four domestic varieties plus the two from Great Britain received the best grades.

A new three-year contract for 85,000 dress industry workers in the New York metropolitan area, providing for an 8 per cent wage rise and a pension fund increase costing altogether $15,000,000 annually, has been formally ratified.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)-- The Senate passed and sent to President Truman today a bill permitting Government agencies to waive navigation and vesselinspection laws in the interest of national defense. The Senate Commerce Committee said in a report that "the desirability of permitting waivers of these laws for the purpose of expeditious movement of troops and supplies needs no emphasis in these times."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 17--New democratic reforms will be introduced soon in Yugoslavia. The reforms include referendums for local government affairs and the establishment of town meetings of citizens. The idea for referendums was presumably inspired by the successful use of this method in Switzerland. The town meeting was probably taken over from the United States.

The volume of commercial paper outstanding in November rose an additional $13,000,000 to $325,000,000, the highest level since May, 1942, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The Edwards L. Cleaveland Day Care Center in the Albany houses at 1185 Park Place, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday. Operated by the Stuyvesant Community Center, it will care for sixty children from 3 to 5 years old. A staff of fourteen will be on hand five days a week from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 17 (AP)-- Any notion that Jordan might conclude a separate peace with Israel was ruled out today by Premier Samir Pasha Rifai. California, which has supplied so many fine players to the major leagues, next spring will receive a long-awaited opportunity to watch Joe DiMaggio, its outstanding diamond hero, in action with the world champion New York Yankees.

Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Gounod's "Faust" will be given as a benefit performance for the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday evening, Jan. 14.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)--Will Rogers, state Senator of Oklahoma, died here in Hines Veterans Administration Hospital today. He had undergone two operations for removal of a brain tumor. Increased cost of fabrics and labor will force the price of popular and low-end dresses to increase $1.00 a garment at the wholesale level, it was learned yesterday.
One of the 6,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus and received at the New York Post Office has brought a response from a group of workers in Syracuse, N.Y.

Accelerated by the General Motors Corporation order halting delivery of 1951 automobiles, a used car sales boom in this city went to new high level in price and volume yesterday, according to Charles Kreisler, president of the New York Used Car Dealers Association.

Railroads, air and bus lines began preparing yesterday for holiday traffic that is expected to equal the heavy flow of last year.

The stock market staged yesterday another roaring performance, with gains sufficient to push the list within a point of the year's top level. While price increases and volume failed to match those of the vigorous session of Monday, the fact that the motors advanced was considered important.
The Third Avenue Transit Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated profit of $237,909 for October, contrasted with a loss of $124,126 a year before.

Joseph Szigeti celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his American debut with the Philadelphia Orchestra, which occurred on Dec. 19, 1925, by another concert with orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

White blossoms formed a floral setting yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church for the marriage of Miss Helen Wilmot Moffett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Moffett 2d of Old Brookville, L.I., to James Russell Lowell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell of 812 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Despite further diminution in business, the stock markets here developed a better tone today. A British Government securities closed at or slightly above yesterday's prices. Foreign bonds were quiet, with Japanese loans little changed.
PULTNEYVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 19 (AP)--An atheist went ahead today with plans to protest against holding Christmas pageants in public schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Air Force today ordered five additional Air National Guard groups to Federal duty, presumably for assignment to defense of the continental United States.
The Western Pacific Railroad yesterday sold an issue of $22,000,000 refunding and improvement bonds due on Jan. 1, 1981, at an interest, cost of about 3,145 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- November retail sales fell 3 per cent below the October level, after allowance for seasonal factors, the Department of Commerce reported today. However, last month's sales, totaling $11,650,000,000, ran 7 per cent above November, 1949.
Deportation of Russian-born Alexander Bittelman, former national committeeman of the Communist party, was recommended yesterday under the Internal Security Act.

A realization that the dangers facing each American today are not new, but merely applied to a new situation keynoted the annual Christmas message of Dean Millicent C. McIntosh of Barnard College at a college assembly held yesterday.
One entry by Miss Melanie Nancy Marra of Manhasset, L.I., in the International Fabric Design Competition 1950-51 received the first prize of $400 and another an honorable mention award of $50.
Trading in hide futures featured the activity in commodities yesterday in generally lower markets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The House of Representatives passed the civil defense bill today by a vote of 247 to 1. The only opponent was Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan.

Into sleepy harbors of eastern Long Island a steady stream of small coastal vessels flying the British flag is flowing these days from ports in Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia, their holds bulging with sacks of seed potatoes soon to go into the fields of Long Island, one of the country's main potato-raising districts.

Fiscal autonomy was recommended yesterday for the Board of Higher Education to give it greater flexibility in determining faculty promotions, salaries and tenure in the four municipally owned colleges.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, national chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, announced yesterday that its recent nation-wide campaign had brought in 15,507,877 signatures for the Freedom Scrool and $1,288,044 in contributions for Radio Free Europe.

Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, denied yesterday that he had ever offered to sell the C.B.S. color television system "lock, stock and barrel" to the Admiral Corporation for $3,000,000.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein sustained the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx yesterday in its refusal to rent a ballroom to the American Labor party for a meeting to honor Paul Robeson.

Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson replied last night to the Americans, including former President Herbert Hoover, who are advising withdrawal of our forces to our own shores. Mr. Patterson declared "it is the counsel of discouragement, despair and defeat."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) The nine-year-old coaching regime of Jeff Cravath sank at the University of Southern California today, torpedoed by powerful "win or else" alumni sharpshooters.
LONDON, Dec. 20 Officials of Britain's Labor Government expect a substantial increase in defense spending as a result of the Brussels conference.

With trading reduced to a minimum owing to the holiday season, textile and apparel manufacturers and distributors will not be able to make an immediate evaluation of the voluntary price freeze order. Most of the mills are withdrawn from the market and the sales which were made reflected no change in policy pricing, according to a survey of the market.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 20 (AP) The beltwide cotton producers committee wants a Federal guarantee that planters won't suffer losses by doubling their crop next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Senate, by an almost unanimous voice vote, passed a 77 per cent excess-profits tax today with an estimated yield of $2,600,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The twenty-one-nation Council of the Organization of American States voted unanimously today to summon a meeting of foreign ministers here to rally the forces of the hemisphere against the threat of international communism.

With the North American F-86 jet fighter now in action in Korea, the skies of Asia have become a laboratory and proving ground for the new tactics and techniques of the jet age.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20 (AP) Warning that World War III seemed near, Premier Ali Razmara announced today that he had alerted all Iranian Army garrisons, including those facing Russian frontier forces.

PARIS, Dec. 20 Government circles here found particular satisfaction today in the fact that the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France had agreed at Brussels on the notes they would sent to Moscow in the next few days, leaving the door open for a possible four-power conference.

PARIS, Dec. 20--The French Government has mapped plans for an extensive civilian defense system to protect the populace against internal sabotage and enemy action in event of war, Interior Minister Henri Queuille disclosed today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec, 20 As one of the first consequences of the decisions made by the North Atlantic Council, the five Brussels treaty powers Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg met here today to effect the immedate merging of the Western Union defense organization with fine twelve nations' forces to be gathered under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's command.

Negotiations are under way for a contract between Margaret Truman and the National Broadcasting Company, it was announced yesterday by Charles C. Barry, vice president in the programming department of N.B.C.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the world's largest, announced yesterday that Charles G. Taylor Jr. would become president on the first of the year. He will succeed Leroy A. Lincoln, who is to be chairman of the board of directors.

Pleas for the prompt construction of the proposed new $18,500,000 hospital in Harlem to reduce the incidence of tuberculosis in that area marked yesterday the last calendar meeting of the City Planning Commission under the chairmanship of Jerry Finkelstein.

Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury was asked yesterday to study the living standards of members of the Police Department with the view of "prodding the conscience of the community" into raising their "substandard income level.

Fifth and sixth graders can be competent critics of radio and television programs and broadcasters interested in improving their productions might do well to avail themselves of such service, the report of a five-year-project along these lines indicates. Findings of the study, which was conducted primarily at Horace Mann School, were released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) President Truman will make his traditional Christmas Eve speech to the nation from his home in Independence, Mo., the White House said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The National Rent Control Law was extended until next March 31 when President Truman signed a joint Congressional resolution today providing for the extension.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Astor, the attraction is "Harvey," Universal-International's adaptation of the Mary Chase play starring James Stewart. Henry Koster directed and John Beck produced the comedy-fantasy from a script by Mrs. Chase and Oscar Brodney. Josephine Hull Peggy Dow, Charles Drake, Cecil Kellaway, Victoria Horne, Jessie White, Wallace Ford and William Lynn are among the supporting players.

ANY man who is willing to sit on a small ammunition box, his feet buried in salt slush, and with a strong wind blasting a 23degree temperature through an ineffectual screen of reeds can qualify as an ardent wildfowler. Having so qualified yesterday, we are now ready for warmer shooting.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 15 showed a decrease of 136,331 shares over that of a month earlier, according to figures released yesterday and complied from reports of members and member firms. On the settlement date, earlier this month, the total stood at 2,139,837 compared with the Nov. 15 figure of 2,276,168 shares.

NEWARK, Dec. 20 One of the substantial banking fortunes in the East that of the late Julius S. Rippel of this city is to be used for charity. His will was filed for probate today in the office of the Essex County Surrogate.

Another tie was recorded by the New York Rangers last night. Opposing the Boston Bruins in the battle of the National Hockey League cellar, the Blue Shirts skated to a 4-4 deadlock against the Hub sextet.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20--Marshal Tito issued an order of the day to the Yugoslav Army tonight urging the greatest vigilance because, he said, the forces of aggression were again on the march and threatening a new world war and because Soviet military and political pressures were continuing against Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Mrs. Frank Slingluff gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Sulgrave Club to introduce to society here her niece, Miss Katherine FloydJones Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Sherman of Caracas, Venezuela.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology will establish a new School of Industrial Management with a $5,250,000 gift from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation. This was announced yesterday by Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the institute's corporation, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the foundation, at a joint interview in Mr. Sloan's offices in 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Dec. 20 In St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Ruth Emelie Patrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Hurlburt Patrick of Mount Vernon, was married to Webb Hilbert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilbert of Katonah.

For a newspaper to welcome restrictions on the news may seem unnatural, but we consider the imposition of such restrictions on news of Korean military operations to be salutary. No reliable newspaper has any desire to publish news that might cost the lives of troops or hamper military operations.

LONDON, Dec. 20 Consideration was being given here today to the prompt setting up in London of the Defense Production Board for the twelve North Atlantic Treaty countries. The decision to create the board was made in Brussels over the week-end by the defense ministers of the treaty nations.

"Sunset Boulevard," the Paramount drama concerned with a former silent-screen star, which was produced by Charles Brackett and directed by Billy Wilder, has been designated the best American film of the year in the twenty-fifth annual poll conducted by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday.

The Seaboard Finance Company achieved new high records in earnings, volume of business and receivables outstanding in its fiscal year ended with last September, the annual report of W.A. Thompson, chairman, and Paul A. Appleby, president, revealed today.
After fifty-two years as a division of the Community Service Society, the New York School of Social Work is to become an independent institution.

Undefeated Long Island University and once-beaten City College will meet formidable intersectional foes in a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Blackbirds will tackle U.C.L.A., Pacific Coast Conference champion, in the opener at 7:45 P.M., while the Beavers will

H. Harold Whitman has been appointed vice president of the National City Bank of New York. Mr. Whitman is one of National City's veterans in South America, having served almost thirty years in that territory. He is now in the head office.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20 The word "discrimination" slipped today through platitudes devoted to the Brussels conference to express the West German Government's principal objection to the North Atlantic powers' attitude toward a German defense contribution.
TOKYO, Dec. 20 Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters yesterday imposed military censorship on dispatches from Korea and on accounts of the United Nations operations written in Tokyo.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 20 (AP)--Nearly 1,000 big-eyed little Korean street orphans were air-lifted to an island sanctuary off South Korea today.

Herbert Hoover urged the United States last night to concentrate on preservation of the western hemisphere by holding the Atlantic and Pacific oceans with the island outposts of Britain, Japan, Formosa and the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) The Department of Agriculture today forecast the 1951 winter wheat crop at 899,096,000 bushels.

Four-year-old Abraham (Jerry) Frolich went to see Santa Claus and the wonderful toys in a big department store a week ago today. The dark-eyed little boy was shy, but he was happy and excited. The same day his father started a new job as a carpenter.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 20 The distribution of Christmas bonuses to 500 employes of the Elizabethtown Consolidated Gas Company and 120 at the Elizabethtown Water Company Consolidated was announced here today.

THE new art book lies on the table in stiff splendor. The people who come into the room turn its bright pages briskly as if they were looking for something in a pile of paintings that had suddenly fallen from an unseen wall.

Plans for integrating the military forces of Great Britain, France and the Benelux countries, known as the Western Union, have been in progress for more than a year under the direction of Field Marshal Montgomery.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was very active yesterday and prices closed irregular, 42 points lower to 46 points higher, with far months the strongest.
A Seton Hall quintet, which took advantage of its every opportunity, raced to a 66-49 triumph over Fordham University last night before a crowd of 2,800 at the Rams' gymnasium.

Debussy remarked that there is one music, which may be found in a waltz or a symphony. This was proved again last night when the Metropolitan Opera Association presented a new Americanized version of the operetta by Johann Strauss, "Fledermaus," staging the piece and performing it with a sufficiency of technical brilliancy and high spirits to delight a hilarious audience.
Close attention is being paid to the effects of military leave on employe benefit plans in most of the 180 companies surveyed on this point by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PARIS, Dec. 20 The Brussels conference of the North Atlantic Council fixes a punctuation mark in history. It accomplished neither more nor less than had been expected. As a result, the moods of the departing delegates varied.
A jury of seven women and five men was selected yesterday as the perjury trial of William W. Remington, former Government economist, opened before Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Senate and House cleared for floor action today differing bills on broader defense authority for the President, thereby laying the grounds for a Congressional battle impairing prospects of pre-Christmas adjournment.

The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to Nov. 30 amounted to $17,845,064, a gain of $2,921,208 over the $14,923,856 shown for the preceding twelve months. Share earnings for the respective periods amounted to $2.88 and $2.54.

Ground was broken yesterday at East Lincoln Avenue and Esplanade North in Mount Vernon, N.Y., for the construction of Vernon Manor, the first cooperative apartment development in the metropolitan area under Section 213 of the National Housing Act of 1950. Initial occupancy in the 720-family development is scheduled for next July.
CAIRO, Dec. 20 (Reuters) Egypt has decided to remove a restriction that denied repair facilities at Egyptian ports to blacklisted ships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) It was 117 degrees hot. The ground was so rugged footwear lasted only ten days. Nineteen rattlesnakes were killed. One false step meant a fall of hundreds of feet to death on sharp rocks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 It was both inevitable and desirable that the moment the plan to build an integrated army, including strong United States forces, for the defense of the North Atlantic Treaty area, and the designation of General Eisenhower as its Supreme Commander, became an official compact, the project would be laid before the American people by national leaders as a major issue of foreign policy.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20--Pravda called again today for "increased vigilance" against American war plans and said that what it termed the struggle for a united independent democratic Germany was "of tremendous importance for strengthening peace in Europe and throughout the world."

HONG KONG, Dec. 20 Although Hong Kong is now seriously affected by United States and Chinese Communist foreign trade restrictions, merchants of various nationalities here will be able to look back on the first eleven months of 1950 as an unusually prosperous period.

Dr. George Gray Ward, a surgeon in this city for fifty-five years, who was Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Cornell University Medical College from 1916 to 1934, died yesterday at his home, 1175 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)--The five directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today faced the possibility of seeing their jobs abolished during the next session of Congress.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 Helen Hayes has tentatively agreed to return to the screen in"My Son John," a photoplay which John Lee Mahin has written at Paramount from a story idea by Leo McCarey, the studio disclosed today.
Mr. and Mrs. John S. Renwick of New York and Wayne, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Scott, to Capt. Samuel Rhea Gammon 3d,

THE three local baseball clubs, the Giants, the Dodgers and the Yankees, offered a preview yesterday of Lew Fonseca's official films of the world series. It is the painful duty of this reviewer to report that Fonseca is beginning to slip badly. The 1950 classic had none of the thrills or drama of his 1949 presentation. In fact, it's two years since he put on a really spectacular show.

Scoring with only 31 seconds left to play, the Princeton Freshmen defeated the St. Paul's School in the teams' annual holiday season hockey clash at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Dick Price of the Tigers got off a right alley shot that flew into the cords to give his team the victory by 2 to 1 before 3,217 fans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Organized labor, minus John L. Lewis, today abandoned the strong opposition to wage controls that it has maintained since the Korean war started and advised President Truman that it would accept wage stabilization on certain terms.

Organized labor in America has established a United Labor Policy Committee composed of representatives of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Railway Labor Executives Association and the International Association of Machinists.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the Federal Communications Act does not prohibit radio stations from censoring political speeches of supporters of candidates, but only the speeches of the candidates themselves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, re-elected in November to his fifth term in Congress, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on seven counts of accepting a total of $1,380 in campaign contributions from two women clerks in his office.

CORAL GABLES, FLA., Dec. 20 (AP) Lindahl Stable's Little Captain, reserved off the pace to the far turn, exploded a spectacular stretch rally that carried him to a half-length victory in the feature at Tropical Park today. He paid $10.40 for $2.

Intercity buses entering and leaving New York by way of the George Washington Bridge and the Holland Tunnel will not be permitted to make stops between 168th and Twenty-third Streets beginning Jan. 2.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) This year's motor vehicle production is estimated by the Automobile Manufacturers' Association at 8,015,750 units.

Enrollment of 10,000 taxicab drivers and 6,807 taxis in the Emergency Taxi Corps of the city's civil defense organization was announced yesterday by Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense Director. He said the corps' goal was 35,000 drivers and 11,800 cabs.

LONDON, Dec. 20 The stock markets here improved today in keeping with Wall Street, despite a further pre-Christmas contraction of business. The exception was British Government securities, which failed to hold early gains and closed scarcely changed.
A miscellany of recipes given today will create the warm, spicy odors that, spreading from the kitchen to the rest of the house, are quite as much Christmas as fir trees and caroling.

Amendment of the immigration clauses of the Internal Security Act to permit the entry into this country of men and women who have repudiated totalitarianism, regardless of affiliations they might have held in the past, was urged in a resolution adopted last night at the annual conference of the Italian-American Labor Council at 218 West Fortieth Street.

WITH U.S. FORCES, in Korea, Dec. 20--In new defensive positions south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel United Nations forces under the command of Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker awaited apprehensively a full-scale onslaught by several hundred thousand Chinese Communist troops.

Several young women made their formal debuts at various parties held here yesterday. Miss Antoinette Sickles, daughter of Mrs. Jorge R. Andre Jr, of 120 East Seventy-eighth Street and of Daniel E. Sickles of Paris, was introduced to society at a large supper dance held last night in the Biltmore Roof.
A group of city employes peacefully picketed in City Hall Park between 1 and 1:30 P.M. yesterday in a demand for a flat annual wage increase of $500.

Martin T. Lacey, secretarytreasurer of Local 816 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., and president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of committing acts of "monstrous and irresponsible dictatorship" against one of the city's largest trucking concerns.

Considerable resistance to the advance was encountered yesterday by the stock market. Three days of gains invited sufficient profit-taking to hold prices in check, although business remained heavy. It was a highly confused market despite the fact that final quotations were on the better side.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 20 The United Nations Truce Committee has sent a new message to Peiping aimed at assuring the Chinese Communists that negotiations on a Korean cease-fire would be followed by talks on other Far Eastern controversies.

The United States District Court reserved decision yesterday on the contention of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., that reinstitution of the exclusive patronage contract rate system proposed by two North Atlantic Conferences would be discriminatory and in violation of the Shipping Act of 1916.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The Wheeling (W.Va.) Electric Company has received authority from the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow $3,500,000 from three New York banks. The funds would be borrowed from time to time over a period ending Dec. 31, 1955, with an initial borrowing of $2,500,000 to be made on Dec. 29, next, and the proceeds applied to the repayment of Wheeling Electric's outstanding notes of that amount.

The Economic Stabilization Agency has now acted to generalize the action it took last week in the case of the automobile industry. It has undertaken to freeze indirectly the prices of manufactured products, materials and services (other than those specifically exempted by the law) by freezing profits at approximately the levels of Dec. 1. Theoretically this price freeze

There is a hopeful note in the terms of the leave of absence granted General Eisenhower by the trustees of Columbia University. It is understood, says the announcement, that General Eisenhower "will resume his duties as president of the university immediately upon his military release."
Cole Porter's new musical, "Out of This World," bows at the Century Theatre this evening. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

Al (Sonny Boy) West, Washington, D.C., lightweight, was taken to St. Clare's Hospital in critical condition last night after being knocked out by Percy Bassett of Philadelphia in the seventh round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20--The Kefauver Senate Crime Committee today heard testimony by the brother of a former bookmaker in Kenosha. Wis., that two Kenosha City Councilmen had demanded $15,000 of the bookmaker, had settled for $7,500, and had arranged for the bookie to reopen a lucrative crap game in order to make enough money to pay the $7,500.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) Raymond (Buddy) Parker, who started his National Football League career as a player with the Lions in 1935, was named today as head coach of the Detroit team.

A further sharp drop took place last week in fuel oil supplies, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks dropped 4,051,000 barrels to 76,913,000 at the week-end. They were 82,450,000 barrels a year ago. Supplies of heavy fuel oil were down 1,709,000 barrels to 41,598,000. A year ago they were 62,786,000 barrels.

For those who would trim their holiday board as well as their Christmas tree, new furnishings for the table now are in the stores. Cloths, napkins, ashtrays, glasses, all trimmed with Christmas motifs, are made of durable materials so that they may be packed away with the tree ornaments and used for years to come.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) Columbia stormed from behind in the final two minutes tonight to defeat Tulane's basketball team, 62 56. It was the undefeated Lions' second straight victory over the Green Wave in as many nights and their sixth consecutive triumph of the season.

Quick action by Federal authorities to relieve the present serious congestion of imports in the port of New York was urged in a resolution passed yesterday by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade. The group met at the Town Hall Club.
BUSINESS NOTES

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The Government went ahead today with plans for clamping controls upon the civilian economy, disregarding a cross-fire of criticism of the Economic Stabilization Agency's proposal for voluntary price ceilings. The criticism came from industry and organized labor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 The International Harvester Company rescinded today price increases put into effect after Dec. 1. Its action followed the Government's request to all business yesterday to freeze prices voluntarily at not more than the Dec. 1 level.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) The Government took another step today to keep Russia and other countries in the Soviet bloc from getting war-useful goods.

Faculty members and students at universities and colleges and employes and employers in many occupations were among the 580 donors who sent gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from all parts of the country.

Complete accord with the Government's efforts to prevent increases in prices was expressed yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which represents more than 7,000 department, chain and specialty stores throughout the country.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 21 Hard-fighting United States infantrymen, backed by the big guns of the United Nations armada off shore and air strikes of carrierbased marine and naval fighters, held the enemy attack to a standstill yesterday along the shrunken perimeter around Hungnam on the northeast coast of Korea.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 20 The United States, British and French replies to the Soviet suggestion for a four-power conference on Germany will be discussed with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer before they are transmitted to the Soviet Union probably Saturday.
Santa Claus and his myriad helpers filled a wonderful variety of early engagements yesterday, as the city and its neighbors advanced into the holiday season.

PARIS, Dec. 20 Marquis Melchior de Polignac, noted sportsman and member of the International Olympic Committee, died here today at the age of 70. He was a member of an important champagne producing firm and president of the Champagne Producers Association.

Massachusetts municipal housing authorities borrowed $11,140,000 yesterday on issues of short-term notes guaranteed by the Commonwealth. A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank here bought $8,440,000 of notes at 1.07 per cent and 1.08 per cent interest, with small premiums, as follows: Lowell Authority, $2,820,000; Cambridge Authority, $2,850,000; Salem Authority, $1,400,000; Fall River Authority,$1,370,000. The notes will be due on Oct. 31
SAFEGUARDS FOR DRUGS
SINGAPORE, Dec. 19--Malaya is reveling in the embrace of boom-time prosperity. Business is so good that Communist terrorism and Moslem rioting appear in comparison almost like minor afflictions.
Coordinated naval air and gunfire attacks yesterday continued to prevent enemy troops from massing for an attack on the Hungnam defense perimeter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 13, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Government's anti-trust suit against seventeen investment banking concerns "may be of extraordinary moment to the future of the country," Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declared yesterday.
Ships from the national defense reserve fleet will be withdrawn to carry coal and grain to Europe under the Foreign Assistance Act.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that a section of Birmingham's zoning law violated the Federal Constitution by barring Negroes from "allwhite" residential sections.

The New York Central System has sold the "fee" to its property at 300 Park Avenue to Webb Knapp, Inc., a real estate concern which, in addition to other holdings, controls properties on Park Avenue that have a combined assessed valuation of $35,000,000.

A twenty-one-minute motion picture in color depicting what a person can do to protect himself in the event of an atomic bomb attack was exhibited here yesterday by the Cornell Film Company, 1501 Broadway.
Ships from the national defense reserve fleet will be withdrawn to carry coal and grain to Europe under the Foreign Assistance Act.
The Department of Health warned New Yorkers yesterday to keep their Christmas merry by observing safety rules in the home.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 20 Two Navy field goals in the last forty seconds of play gave the middies a 53-49 victory over Rutgers today in a basketball thriller that was deadlocked nine times during the second half.

Frank B. Lasette, president of Frank B. Lasette, Inc., 41-32 Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, Queens, plumbing contractors, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in the Surrey Hotel, 22 East Seventy-sixth Street. His age was 82.

SARASOTA, Fla., Thursday, Dec 21 (AP) Mrs. Ida Ringling North, only sister of the seven Ringling brothers of circus fame, died shortly after midnight today at Sarasota Hospital. She would have been 77 years old on Feb. 2.

Television receiver production will probably be reduced 50 per cent by the middle of next year, James D. Secrest, general mangaer of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday. The group's membership comprises the most important television producers and parts and components suppliers in the coun try, with the notable exception of the Admiral Corporation.

Terminating an ownership of one year, Hugh K. McGovern, operator, has sold the five-story fifty-fourfamily apartment house at 1524-30 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Jacob C. Schulman, attorney. Irving Lester Levitt was attorney for the seller. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of 172d Street, is assessed at $130,000. It was sold for cash above mortgages of $109,400.

High point of the State Racing Commission's annual report, released for publication today, is that thoroughbred horse racing in New York experienced a mid-season boom in attendance and wagering this year.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 The Republican State Committee has sent out 2,000 copies of a Christmas card that says "faltering international leadership" is lessening the country's chance for peace and that praises "the stanch values of the Republican party."

The Columbia Broadcasting System has asked its 2,500 regular employes including radio and television performers, to sign the same type of loyalty statement required of applicants for civil service jobs in the Federal Government.
As elder statesman and humanitarian, Herbert Hoover speaks with unusual authority, and his words will carry special weight in Congress, to which he appeals for support.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20--The San Francisco and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges, respectively the nation's second and fourth ranking regional securities markets, are formally exploring the possibility of consolidating, it was disclosed today.
Several fielding records in the National League were shattered in 1950 and others of long standing were tied, with two Dodgers and two Giants getting into the books with new marks.

What if handsome Bobby Thomson's 1950 batting average was an anemic .252? After he and President Horace Stoneham had agreed to 1951 terms yesterday, Thomson, who has height, speed and youth, plus the determination to succeed, on his side, still remained Staten ...

With the opening of the new skating rink in Central Park yesterday, young gay blades may take advantage of the holiday for some fancy daytime capers at the 9 A.M. to noon free children's session or from 2:30 to 5 P.M. for 9 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP)--Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, indicated today that the Senate Elections Committee, of which he is chairman, would not challenge the right of any Senator-elect to take his seat next month.

Directors of City Stores Company yesterday called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 26 to consider the revision of its capital structure, Albert M. Greenfield, board chairman, announced. This would be the initial step in a corporate financing program recommended by the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Senate quickly passed a $20,147,062,938 emergency funds bill today with its Committee on Appropriations demanding, that the Department of Defense rush the money into contracts before the value of the dollars shrink further.

Only two individuals stand out in the mass of so-called "miscellaneous records" just released by the National League Eddie Stanky, Giants' pepperpot second baseman, and Stan Musial, rated by many as the league's possibly the game's greatest all-around player.

Unless and until the United Nations Truce Committee can make public the exact texts of its communications to Peiping there will necessarily be some doubt and some confusion as to what has actually been proposed. It is known that a second communication has gone forward.

TOMORROW afternoon, at exactly one hour before sunset, the local wildfowlers and the waferfowl will declare a truce for the year, so if you are planning to get in one last fling at the sport in these waters no time should be wasted.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 The General Motors Corporation late today dropped its opposition to an order of the Economic Stabilization Agency rolling back 1951-model passenger car prices to the Dec. 1 level. It immediately lifted its embargo on the sale of 1951-model Chevrolet, Pontiac and Cadillac passenger cars, which it had imposed Monday.

William Brown Bell, president since 1922 of the American Cyanamid Company, one of the world's largest chemical manufacturing concerns, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Marrakesh, French Morocco.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 Konrad Cardinal von Preysing, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Berlin, died this afternoon of a heart attack at his home in the United States sector. He was 70 years old.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 22--Fighting slowed down along the Korean fronts yesterday, but Chinese and North Korean units received reinforcements both in the east and west for new blows against the United Nations lines.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 (AP) A $185,000 face-lifting job will have the State Capitol's historic Assembly chamber prepared for two major events during the next two weeks.

Viewed from the employment standpoint, the stage actor's lot isn't a gainful one. Allowing statistics galore to speak for themselves, that is the implication conveyed in an exhaustive survey conducted by Alan Hewitt, of the Actors Equity governing board, and printed in the January issue of the union's magazine.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP) Yuri Zhdanov, writing in the Soviet magazine Culture and Life, today attacked dogmatism in science, calling it the enemy of progress.

A tradition established by an anonymous donor to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was reaffirmed yesterday when the giver appeared at THE TIMES office and passed a single $1,000 bill across a counter as her annual donation to the fund.
Al (Sonny Boy) West, 21-yearold Negro lightweight from Washington, D.C., died at 7:59 o'clock last night at St. Clare's Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The line above, the opening of Matthew Arnold's sonnet on Shakespeare, probably applies to only one man in American public life at the present time, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. Though his shoulders are broad, and they carried ...

Dr. William Buschke of 138-52 Jewel Avenue, Flushing, Queens, director of the Ayer Foundation Ophthalmic Research Laboratory at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, and associate surgeon, died yesterday in the laboratory, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 43.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) A Congressional investigating committee charged the Interior Department today with a "miserable record" of "wasteful and extravagant" procurement, citing as examples the purchase of Esquire magazine and paper drinking cups.
LONDON, Dec. 21 British and European thoughts were somewhat confused today by former President Herbert Hoover's speech. Just when European nations were asked to put forth greater efforts ...

BONN, Germany, Dec. 21 The first steps on the road leading to the end of Western Allied occupation and the rearmament of Western Germany were taken by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the council of the Allied High Commission in a historic five-hour meeting at the Petersberg in Koenigswinter today.

THE Cleveland Browns and the Los Angeles Rams will meet for the professional foot ball championship on Sunday amid the igloos scattered along the polar wastes on Cleveland's lake front. Will some tremendous trifle again decide the issue? Lady Luck usually is in her most prankish mood whenever there is a big title match in Cleveland.
The Welfare Council of New York City announced yesterday the organization of a city-wide Committee on the Use of Narcotics Among Teen-Age Youth.

Turkeys for the holidays are both abundant and moderately priced with the small birds at 63 cents a pound, or a couple of cents below a year ago. Larger turkeys (of more than eighteen pounds) may be had for 55 a pound.
Associated Press Wirephoto
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Air Force announced today tentative plans to reopen thirteen more bases as part of the program to expand the Air Force to a sixty-eight-wing size.

Claudia Jones, national secretary of the women's commission of the Communist party, was ordered deported yesterday by Joseph J. Mack, hearing officer, at the close of deportation hearings at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 90 Columbus Avenue.

Individual companies as well as trade groups for the cotton textile industry will support the voluntary system of price controls requested by the Economic Stabilization Agency, it was learned yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 Three major film-story purchases were announced today, two by Hal Wallis, autonomous producer at Paramount, and a third by Twentieth Century-Fox.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Charles E. Wilson officially took charge of the mobilization program today and said that industry was in shape to do a great defense production job.

The "Great Stalin-Genius," the "Greatest Scientist of Our Time," and the "Leader of the World Peace Camp" reached his seventy-first birthday yesterday. There is less ingenuity in the paeans of praise this year in Moscow, as if the worshipers were running out of adjectives. It is a good thing communism is atheistic, for nothing else ...

Metropolitan skiers, who have a penchant for rushing the season, will find the best sport available near by this week-end. The recent snowstorm that struck this part of the country provided the Poconos of Pennsylvania, the Catskills and Hudson Highlands and some of the Adirondack Mountain points with the heaviest blankets for trails and slopes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21 The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted by a vote of 32 to 6 this afternoon a 1951 county budget of $28,102,941. It included $2,000,000 salary adjustments for 2,600 employes and a new cost of living bonus as had been proposed.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 21--Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that the future of the United Nations would not depend on the outcome in Korea. He declared the organization would live through the Korean crisis, but conceded that some of the principles it stood for might emerge damaged.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 21 The United Nations Truce Committee, which has been striving in vain for a cease-fire in Korea, today urged Communist China to respond to the committee's earlier overtures and intimated that if it received no encouragement from Peiping its would start winding up its work next week.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 21--The United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea announced today that the South Korean Government had accepted its recommendation for the mitigation of death sentences and other punishments of convicted collaborators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) The Senate by overwheiming voice vote confirmed Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg as Assistant Secretary of Defense today after investigators had cleared her completely of charges she had attended Communist-front meetings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2l (UP) Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, tonight made public what he said purported to be a 1942 memorandum by former Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles to Earl Browder, former Communist leader, belittling the menace of communism in China.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 Evening-up operations for the approaching holidays, combined with a forecast for a winter wheat crop of 150,000,000 bushels more next year than was harvested this summer, resulted in lower prices on the Board of Trade here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The 22-month railroad wage dispute was settled today by Dr. John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, on terms that will ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ratified the appointment of Maj. Gen. William H. Draper Jr. as trustee of the Long Island Rail Road Company.

An appropriation of $140,705 to carry the gambling investigation being made by Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald through the first half of 1951 was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The authorization brings to $306,985 the total approved so far for the gambling inquiry.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 21 An extensive program of Federal, state and local measures to improve the economic and social conditions of migrant farm workers was proposed today to Gov. Earl Warren by a special commission he established last spring to study migrant problems.

TRENTON, Dec. 21 Prompt development of new water supplies for metropolitan north Jersey to produce 100,000,000 gallons more a day was proposed today by the State Water Policy and Supply Council in a report to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, in its third week under the guest leadership of George Szell, played a Beethoven program at Carnegie Hall last night. There could be no surprises in the Sixth Symphony or the Violin Concerto.

Financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed tomorrow and on Monday in observance of Christmas. Some of the commodity exchanges in New York will close at noon today. Most British and Canadian exchanges will be closed tomorrow through Tuesday, Dec. 26.
New York got a Christmas present of its own yesterday when Mayor Impellitteri dedicated the new $750,000 Wollman Memorial outdoor skating rink in Central Park.

The plan of the State Thruway Authority to construct a 15,000 foot-long bridge and causeway across the widest part of the Hudson River between South Nyack and Tarrytown was defended vigorously yesterday by Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the agency.

Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, denied here last night that he had withheld or threatened to withhold Federal welfare funds. Mr. Ewing has been in Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center for a physical check-up and is scheduled to leave today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The Department of Agriculture predicted today that farmers will produce more hogs next year but not enough to increase civilian meat supplies materially.
The success of America's industrial mobilization program is menaced by shortages of engineers, with the situation held "desperate" in some plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Defense and civil air authorities tightened flying regulations today to guard against a "sneak" aerial attack on vital industrial areas and key atomic installations.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP) The Soviet Union marked the seventyfirst birthday of Premier Joseph Stalin today without an announcement of Stalin Peace Prizes, which had been expected to be awarded for the first time.

NEWARK, Dec. 21 Judge Walter J. Freund reserved decision in Superior Court today on an application to approve a judgment of $3,054,347 against a syndicate that in October, 1948, sold two Delaware River toll bridges to Burlington County for $12,000,000.

The New York State Civil Defense Commission and the city's Office of Civil Defense said yesterday that the twenty-four hour alert they had observed since President Truman declared a state of national emergency would be maintained over the Christmas weekend.

NEWARK, Dec. 21 Twelve persons were injured at 2:20 P.M. today when nine cars of a Philadelphia-to-New York express were derailed as it approached the Newark railroad station at twenty-five miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Arbitrary revaluation of the ruble by the Soviet Union has materially increased living costs for the handful of foreigners still permitted to reside in Moscow on governmental or private business, returning diplomats reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--Opponents of a bill giving union-shop rights to railway labor, taking advantage of slack attendance attributable to the approaching holiday season, declined to be counted for a quorum today until House leaders agreed to limit business to non-controversial measures.

Light snow and freezing temperatures in the Middle West delayed trains from Chicago, Cleveland, Cincinnati and St. Louis from twenty-five minutes to five hours yesterday at the beginning of the holiday travel period.

The forty-one-family apartment house at 3033 Brighton Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Louis Ingerman to Harry Molberger and Samuel Smith. The property, on a plot 110 by 100 feet, is assessed at $123,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $134,000. Hussey Hoeh were the brokers. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Strength in the public utilities and a few rails helped yesterday to keep the stock market on a fairly even keel. Generally, the price structure proved highly spotty with changes generally limited to fractions. The advance in the utilities was considered significant since this section had not participated fully in the recent recovery.

The conversion of "mothballed" capital ships at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn to present naval requirements calls for the employment of large numbers of skilled civilian workers, Rear Admiral Paul B. Nibecker, commander of the yard, said yesterday.

Dr. Henry B. Smith Jr., formerly Professor of Chemical Engineering at Bucknell University, Lewisburg, Pa., and manager of the Pilot Engineering Company, Lewisburg consulting concern, has been appointed director of General Foods' engineering research, laboratory at Hoboken, N.J., effective on Jan. 1.

A twenty-six-hour strike of 750 gas production workers in plants servicing the sprawling North Jersey industrial area appeared at 1 A.M. today to be ending "in the interest of the national situation." State officials quoted union spokesmen as saying that 250 workmen at the West End plant in Jersey City had ratified a new agreement, and had begun returning to their jobs at 1 A.M.

In its first change of ownership in more than 50 years, the building on lot 20 by 100 feet at 245 East Fifty-eighth Street, near Second Avenue, was sold by the Arthur P. McNulty family to a buyer for occupancy. The M. MorgenthauSeixas Company were the brokers in the sale for cash over a mortgage of $6,000. The tax valuation is $22,500.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., won today the right to a union shop clause in future contracts with the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division. A count of the ballots in Tuesday's National Labor Board election on the issue showed 10,599 in favor of a union shop to 1,043 against it.

In the air, on the ground and even underground the spirit of Christmas was in evidence yesterday. As the holiday approached, the heart of this big city opened wider to share and to spread gladness among the young, and among the less fortunate of all ages.

A special committee consisting of Mayor Impellitteri, Controller Lazarus Joseph and Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson began yesterday an intensive study of the question of pay rises for the city's 200,000 employes.

JOHN PHILLIPS MARQUAND, a "fiction winter since 1921" according to his "Who's Who" biography, is the author of some 125 magazine stories and of nineteen books. Since the publication of "The Late George Apley" in 1937 his place in the front rank of living American novelists has been secure. His satirical novels about the more economically fortunate citizens

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Truman will fly at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow to his home town of Independence, Mo., to spend Christmas with his family. As usual, he will also maintain a tem porary White House in the penthouse suite of the Hotel Muehlebach in Kansas City to carry on his official duties.
Edward J. Hanley, executive vice president of the AlleghenyLudlum Steel Corporation, was elected president yesterday to succeed E.B. Cleborne, who is resigning, effective Dec. 31.
Directors of the Carrier Corporation yesterday declared a 10 per cent dividend payable in common stock on March 1 to common stockholders of record of Feb. 1.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (UP) The Queen Mother of Iraq died today in Baghdad at the age of 38, the Iraqi legation announced.

Plans for the erection of eleven ranch homes were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Ralph Silvestri, builder, of the last remaining landmark in the old Bailey estate in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Saul M. Dash was the broker in the sale of the parcel...

Industrial equipment manufacturers have started compiling information on 1951 materials requirements for the National Production Authority, executives revealed here yesterday after returning from conferences in Washington. Sessions of individual equipment industry groups are being held ...

Loans to business by New York banks found renewed strength last week, advancing $149,000,000 in a spurt which brought the total outstanding to a new high level of $6,329,000,000. The rise, twentyeighth to be registered in twentynine weeks, is the second largest increase this year, comparing with a gain of $165,000,000 in the week ended on Sept. 13.
Soon after Jan. 1 New York International Airpor at Idlewild, Queens, will have the nation's first airport general order warehouse for handling bonded air cargo.

LONDON, Dec. 21 Proposals have been made to the British Government that Egypt might join a Middle Eastern defense pact, or become associated with the North Atlantic Alliance, as an alternative to having British troops continue to occupy the Suez Canal zone.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) Six assistants to Jeff Cravath, former Trojan coach, received their walking papers today at the University of Southern California.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Schuette Jr. of 1150 Fifth Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Parker, to B. Bradshaw Minturn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Minturn of Florence, Kan., formerly of Chicago. The announcement marked the anniversary of the engagement of the prospective bride's parents twenty-six years ago.

People who have been successful in various activities will be interviewed by Betty Furness in a new television series on WJZ-TV, beginning Jan. 2. Entitled "Success Story," the series will be presented on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 2:15 to 2:30 P.M. under the sponsorship of Rogers Brothers.

So long as the present provisions of law relating to farm prices remain on the statute books it is difficult to see how price control can be either really effective or really fair. For food prices are obviously a major factor in the cost of living; and under existing legislation the control of farm prices, on which food prices directly depend, can only be utterly inadequate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 An effort will be made in the Eightysecond Congress, which assembles on Jan. 3, to give private citizens the right to sue the Government for damages for slanderous attacks made on them behind Congressional immunity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Truman said today that the appointment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as Supreme Commander of the Western European Allied forces had inspired the free nations with a renewed determination to maintain their collective strength.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 Governor Dewey appointed Col. Lawrence A. Wilkinson, Director of the State Civil Defense Commission, as acting chairman of that commission to succeed Gen. Lucius D. Clay today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Senate Banking Committee today voted to ask the Senate to adopt a House-approved bill reactivating the War Damage Corporation before Congress adjourns.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 Seeking relief in the face of steadily dimin ishing receipts, this city's neighborhood motion picture houses have asked the Motion Picture Operators and Stage Hands Union (A.F.L.) to take an immediate 25 per cent reduction in pay.

Kling Factories will introduce a line of modern bedroom furniture at the Chicago home furnishings market next month, George Dudley, general sales manager, revealed yesterday. The company, a top supplier of traditional bedroom furniture, has not produced the modern line for almost ten years.

The novelty on the altogether interesting program that the New York University Washington Square College Chorus and Orchestra gave last night in Town Hall was the first New York performance of Benjamin Britten's "Ballad for Heroes."

ALBANY, Dec. 21 Governor Dewey charged today unauthorized interference by Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing in New York's locally-administered welfare programs. He accused Mr. Ewing of jeopardizing the state's right to millions of dollars in Federal aid for needy and disabled persons.

Although the comprehensive collection of contemporary furniture just received at the John Stuart Showrooms. Thirty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, borrows almost every trick of modern design, the total result is conservative rather than shocking.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 21 Police Chief Henry Witte of Lodi, which is described as the center of the gambling activities of Joe Adonis and Willie Moretti, said this morning he had not ordered a gambling arrest in the last thirty years because he had not been aware of any gambling going on.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Truman created today a new over-all committee to coordinate the Government's military relationships with the rest of the free world.

The greatest aggregation of Yugoslav-flag shipping ever seen on this side of the Atlantic, ten freighters measuring approximately 55,000 gross tons with a cargo lift of more than 80,000 tons, is due to arrive or sail from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore during January.
Buyers with bargaining ability were bringing home yesterday Christmas trees that cost no more than what they paid last year.
Deadly United States Navy rocket ships went into action in defense of the Hungnam perimeter for the first time yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway of Arkansas, the first woman ever elected as a United States Senator, died today in the White Hall Sanitarium in near-by Falls Church, Va. She would have been 73 years old on Feb. 1.

Except possibly by some "fluke," no flour is being sold or has been sold for a long time at prices even as high as price standards announced by the Economic Stabilization Administration. Directors of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company announced yesterday a Christmas bonus for all personnel. Employes will receive up to 15 per cent of their annual salary, according to length of service. Last year the maximum was 10 per cent.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) William G. Helis Jr.'s Mr. Ace, entered in a claimer for the first time, had too much class for nine rivals as he made every pole a winning one in the seventh and best race of the program at Tropical Park today.

Although it is difficult to make sex a tiresome subject, "Out of This World" has very nearly succeeded. This is the new Cole Porter show, which opened at the Century last evening. Following the current trend, it looks a lot better than it turns out to be.

On Christmas Day in 1944 Mrs. Julia Pribojowa set five places at a the table in her home in Velka Luka, Czechoslovakia. The settings were for her daughter, herself and three American fliers she was hiding in her house.

The town of Lansford, Pa., which heretofore had been barred from television reception because it lies in a valley, is now receiving video programs regularly after erecting what is believed to be the country's first "community aerial."

The bespectacled, 23-year-old son of Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, notorious draft dodger of World War I, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan to a maximum five-year prison term for evading military service.
A unique foundation garment s strapless spiraled bra that molds the body to the waist and is attached to brief pants is the latest offering by designer Frances Sider.
A Federal judge heard six hours of argument and then took under advisement yesterday a petition to disbar two of the defense lawyers at last year's Communist trial.

The price of milk will go up half a cent next Thursday in a move that was described by James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, as a "shocking disregard" of the Government's efforts to hold the price line.

Oklahoma's possession-minded quintet repeated its triumph of a year ago over City College's national champions, beating off a late challenge by the Beavers to win, 48 43, before 15,232 roaring spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

Coffee futures edged higher yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trade hedge-lifting and some producer demand for the distant positions furnished the main support. Final prices in the S contract were 20 to 45 points above previous levels in a turnover of 77,250 bags. Closing at 52.80 cents a pound, the March, 1951, contract was up 20 points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Edward G. Robinson, motion picture actor, appeared before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today at his own request to deny Communist affiliations.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP)--Wilfred L. Denno, a veteran of twentyfour years of service in the State prison system, was appointed warden of New York's famed Sing Sing prison today.

The Home liner Atlantic, fastest passenger carrier now in the New York-Mediterranean run, has entered the Ansaldo shipyards in Genoa for power plant alterations designed to add at least one knot to her speed, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 14--Christmas in Paris is more and more like the fairyland of an American Christmas.

Kid Gavilan eked out a victory over Joe Miceli in their ten-round bout last night at Madison Square Garden, but the Cuban caught a tartar and his stock as foremost challenger for the world welterweight title underwent a slight change.

Early celebration of Christmas Eve will also take place here tomorrow, when many Protestant churches will have annual Christmas Eve services in late afternoon by candlelight. Others will be held through the evening. Roman Catholics will attend late afternoon vespers and their usual midnight masses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22-- Jane Wyman will play the chief role in. "The Blue Veil," a film to be produced by Jerry Wald and Norman Krasna at R.K.O. from a French photoplay by Francois Canteaux. The story concerns a woman who, having lost her own child, devotes her life to the care of other children as a nurse-gov erness.

Robert McManamy Jr., president of the investment securities firm of McManamy Co., 120 Broadway died on Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital shortly after suffering a heart attack. Mr. McManamy, who was 55 years old, lived at the Grosvenor Hotel, 35 Fifth Avenue.

Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity since July 9, 1948, resigned yesterday at the request of Mayor Impellitteri. The request took the form of a telephone call from Frank J. Sampson, Assistant to the Mayor, notifying him that the Mayor wanted him to quit the $15,000 post.

In the chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon Miss Pamela Cushing, daughter of Mrs. Brokaw Cushing of Los Angeles and Leonand Jarvis Cushing of 880 Fifth Avenue, was married to Joseph William Donner, son of Mrs. James M. Manufactufers in several industries pledged their support of voluntary price controls yesterday. Prices which had been increased since Dec. 1 were rolled back by two producers and another said that the Dec. 1 level would be frozen.
The stock market yesterday ploughed through to new highs since early in 1931 as buying in the motors gave the list a generous lift.

A rambling colonial residence on two-acre plot on Bradford Avenue, north, of the Boston Post Road, in Rye, Westchester County, has been purchased by George Mavroleon, president of the East Harbor Trading Corporation of New York City, from the Venona Corporation, which completed the building recently. Wynn Meredith, a partner of Sanderson Porter, engineers and constructors, who was in charge of its San Francisco office since 1908, died Thursday in his home at Oakland, Calif., according to word received here yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (UP)--The Chrsyler Corporation today received the biggest tank-building contract since V-J Day.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22--The Most Rev. Hugh C. Boyle, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh since 1921, and one of the leading parochial school educators in the nation, died tonight in Mercy Hospital, where he had been confined for more than a year. He was 77 years old.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 22-- The marriage of Miss Joanne Elizabeth Bigham, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Reginald R. Bigham, to Ensign William Ellis Pinner Jr, Civil Engineering Corps, U.S.N., son of Captain Pinner, Medical Corps, U.S.N., and Mrs. Pinner of Portsmouth, N.H., took place here this evening in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Harold F. Hohly. A reception was held at the Siwanoy Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Twelve Congress members complained today that Attorney General J. Howard McGrath was too severe in barring immigrants under the Subversive Activities Control Act. Mr. McGrath replied that it was not his job to rewrite the law.
Local manufacturers of tin housewares have abandoned plans to introduce new lines at the January housewares market in Chicago, a canvass of representative producers showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Retail prices of goods and services bought by moderate-income city families reached a new high on Nov. 15.

Miss Joan McAlpin Shiland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Shiland of 39 East Seventy-ninth Street, was married to Richard Austin Tilghman, son of Mrs. George Tilghman of 157 East Seventy-second Street, and the late Commander Tilghman, U.S.N., late yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. John E. Large performed the ceremony.

PARIS, Dec. 22--There are mounting reports that although it is the official policy of neither the United States nor Britain an influential bloc is growing in each country that favors the eventual establishment of a tripartite alliance between the two English-speaking nations and Western Germany.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 22-- Communist China today denounced the United Nations Korean truce team as illegal, announced that it would not negotiate with the committee, and once again named its price for peace in Korea.

Representatives of all seafaring unions have been asked to attend a conference in Washington on Jan. 4 to discuss manpower problems, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, Maritime Administrator, announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22--In a practical exhibition of good will, Jordan and Israel have agreed on arrangements that will allow more pilgrims and other Christians transit arrangements to attend Christmas services in Bethlehem than any time since the two countries were at war in 1948.

WARREN, Ohio., Dec. 22 -- Charles M. Lincoln, internationally known newspaper executive and retired foreign editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died here today in his home at the age of 84. A former managing editor of The World and New York Herald he retired seven Years ago.

Six Russian-designed MIG-15 jets were shot down in flames and a seventh damaged before the enemy fighters fled back to their protected bases in Chinese territory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Senate passed and sent back to the House today its own version of the civilian defense bill. The bill now goes to conference and legislative action on it cannot be completed before Jan. 2.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday and closed 13 points higher to 30 points lower.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., Dec. 22 (UP) --Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Vice Chief of Staff, said today that Air Force strength would be increased to 917,000 men "as soon as possible."
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 23--Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker, commander of the United States Eighth Army in Korea, was killed today when his jeep crashed into a truck north of Seoul.

Mayor Impellitteri urged milk and bread companies yesterday to cancel recently announced price increases "in the name of decency and patriotism." The price of a loaf of bread has been advanced one cent and that of a quart of milk half a cent, effective next Thursday.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that he had subpoenaed the records of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. Less than a month ago Mr. Hogan called for the business and finanial data of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, subsequently announcing that he was starting an "allembracing" grand jury investigation of the Fire Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec.22--Before leaving for Kansas City today, President Truman shook hands with about 300 White House employes at the yearly Christmas reception for the staff. Every employe was given a Christmas card bearing the signatures of the President and Mrs. Truman.

ROME, Dec. 22--The Pope has decided to hold a consistory for the creation of a number of Cardinals, both Italian and non-Italian, next February or at the beginning of March, well-informed Vatican circles said today. Boston and St. Louis were mentioned among the dioceses that may be headed by a Cardinal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Government froze all wage agreements and salary plans in the new passenger automobile industry today until March 1.
Merchants in the city are determined to "fight to the finish" any attempt by the city to increase the present 2 per cent sales tax.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP)--Joe Culmone, the nation's leading jockey, celebrated his return to the saddle at Tropical Park today by booting home his 371st winner this year.

Romulo to return to Manila from the United Nations headquarters, presumably for consultations on the position of the Philippines on world developments, a Government source said today. More than $25,000 was contributed yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. It was the best day's response so far in the thirty-ninth annual appeal for relief of unfortunate New Yorkers.

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 22--Although some sentiment in favor of the route selected by the State Thruway Authority for the path of its super-highway in Rockland County was evidenced today, generally there was mounting criticism here of the agency's latest announcement aimed at placating residents of the Nyacks.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 22--In an atmosphere of growing optimism that its diplomatic and military aspirations will be realized, the West German Government confirmed today the appointment of two former leading generals of Hitler's armies to take part in military negotiations with the Western Allies.

American Furniture Associates, a buying office, has advised its 200 member home furnishings outlets throughout the country to keep television orders to a minimum despite anticipated shortages, Sidney Rosenberg, vice president, said yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Coach Joe Stydahar--still insisting he has "only an outside chance" of winning-sent his Los Angeles Rams through their first workout today in snow-covered Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22,--HouseSenate conferees unanimously agreed today on the final draft of a bill increasing corporation taxes $3,300,000,000 a year, and the Senate promptly approved it. Final House action was delayed until Jan. 1.
Arthur S. Leland, senior partner in the private banking firm of Arthur S. Leland Co., 50 Broad Street, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home, 593 Riverside Drive. Mr. Leland was 93 years old.

Miss Grace Keefe has been named assistant to the director of the women's division of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., effective Jan. 2. Miss Keefe is a former president of the New York League of Business and Professional Women, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce reported today that a heavy outflow of private United States capital to other countries took place in the first three months after outbreak of the Korean war.

Foreign buyers are outbidding domestic purchasers of lead refined here. Export prices above the domestic market and active demand yesterday emphasized the trend toward expanding foreign sales.

United States Attorney Irving H. Saypol's office admitted yesterday that thus far it had obtained insufficient evidence to indict four Puerto Ricans charged with conspiracy to assassinate President Truman. Even so, Assistant United States Attorney Frederick Block asked United States Commissioner Edward A. McDonald to continue to hold the accused on the conspiracy complaint.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 22-- Rhode Island Textile machinery manufacturers, now producing at capacity levels, are seeking to convince Washington that their production is vital to a war effort and that their supply of materials should be assured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The United States today offered to talk with the Soviet Union on all the major issues inflaming the world, but it made it clear at the same time that Washington had little hope for successful negotiation.

MINEOLA, L. I, Dec. 22--A legislative program that includes fifteen bills designed to make the Long Island Rail Road safer and more efficient was agreed upon here today by thirteen Republican Assemblymen and State Senators from Nassau, Suffolk and Queens Counties.

Prices of coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange advanced sharply yesterday, with one delivery rising the daily 2-cent-a-pound maximum, and other positions gaining 1 to 1 cents a pound.
