LONDON, Dec. 22--Early in 1951, a new step will be taken in the developing relationship between the three principal Western powers and their former enemy, Germany. According to present intentions, a contract will be negotiated with the Bonn Republic for a German contribution to the defense forces of the North Atlantic alliance.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 23-- Enemy forces, apparently Chinese, launched strong exploratory attacks yesterday along the Thirty -- eighth Parallel in Korea, driving forward almost two miles before the onslaught was halted by timely reinforcements.

There was a round of debutante parties yesterday, one of the largest being the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Andrew Munroe for his granddaughter, Miss Rhea Munroe Elliman, in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria in a Christmas setting of silver and white.

Kentucky, rated the nation's No. 1 quintet, will pay its annual visit to Madison Square Garden tonight. Col. Adolph Rupp's vaunted Wildcats will oppose St. John's in the nightcap of a double-header that will open at 7:45 P.M. with a contest between New York University and Vanderbilt, the Southeastern Conference's second-ranking team.

Stockholders of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company at their annual meeting in St. Louis on Jan. 16 will vote on a proposal to call the outstanding 7 per cent cumulative preferred and issue a new convertible preferred.

ALBANY, Dec. 22--The Public Service Commission instituted a Federal Court action today to annul an Interstate Commerce Commission order granting the New Haven Railroad permission to increase its commuter fares within this state by an average of 8 per cent by Feb. 1.
Glazed roads in three boroughs gave the city a somewhat slippery start last night for the Christmas week-end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The application of the New York State Power Authority to develop a power project on the St. Lawrence River was denied today by the Federal Power Commission. Northwest Airlines has put into operation a huge triple-deck, structural steel repair plant, reported to compare in working arrangement to a naval drydock, for use in overhauling its $20,000,000 fleet of Boeing Stratocruisers. The plant is at the company's main overhaul base in St. Paul.

Department store sales in the city for the Christmas season were fully up to merchants' expectations, it was reported in the trade yesterday. Nevertheless, the retailers were not altogether pleased on several counts, it was said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP)-- The Government suspended its sales of backlog butter today and warned housewives to expect a price rise soon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22--A rush of general buying following an easy start carried grain prices up rapidly on the Board of Trade today, with May corn and March and May soy beans selling at new high levels for the season to date and final trades about at the top.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Average primary market prices advanced 0.6 per cent in the week ended Dec. 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A former convict, described as an associate of a Harlem narcotics syndicate that supplies 2,000 drug peddlers preying on school children "for the purpose of making addicts of them," was held in $50,000 bail in General Sessions yesterday.
PARIS, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP)--E.F. Prichard Jr. relaxed today in seclusion with his family and declined to discuss the Presidential commutation of his two-year prison sentence.

Fears of a music-less New Year's Eve in New York's leading night class and hotels were dissipated yesterday with the announcement of a settlement between employers and Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L.
One of the top jazz ensembles of a decade ago was reassembled to give a concert in Carnegie Hall last night.
A long-standing foe of public power moved swiftly yesterday to avert what he called efforts of the Federal Government to "seize" a generating station of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company.
Don Bradford Fitch, an editor on the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES since March 4, 1927, died at 10:25 o'clock last night in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 56.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 22--America is in excellent shape to meet the present situation, which has been "accumulating" since 1946, President Truman said tonight.

Chrysler Corporation plans to build a new engine plant in Trenton, Mich., at a cost of almost $20,000,000, it was announced yesterday. Construction is scheduled to start within ten days.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 22 --Three judges of the California Court of Appeal listened today to final arguments on whether eighteen professors of the University of California were entitled to continue teaching despite their refusal to sign a special loyalty declaration ordered by the Board of Regents.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP)-- On the surface, things didn't look any different than at similar affairs in other years.
Columbia defeated Harvard by 2 -1 at the Marshall C.C. yesterday in a successful defense of the Belden-Stephens Trophy, emblematic of supremacy in the C.H.Y.P. College Chess League.

At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the auditorium of the High School of Music and Art was so quiet you could hear a note drop. Christmas cheer and laughter rang loud and clear from morning until dusk yesterday throughout the town. There were parties and food for the needy and gifts by the thousands for the small fry, and there was the promise of scores of parties still to come during Christmas Week.

Walter Damrosch, dean of American conductors, died of a heart attack at 8:15 o'clock last night in his home at 168 East Seventy-first Street. The veteran composer and pianist, who for forty-one years conducted the New York Symphony Orchestra--later merged with the Philharmonic Society of New York--would have been 89 years old on Jan. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin in a statement today opposed the relaxing or waiving of employment standards, including those providing for overtime pay and the basic straight-time week of forty hours. He said that lowering the standards would hinder, not help, the defense effort.

The decline in gold holdings of the United Sates in 1950 has been the largest for any year in the nation's history. Up to Dec. 20, the loss of gold had amounted to $1,631,000,000, exceeding the previous record year's loss of $1,319,000,000 in 1944. This will be the first year since 1945 that the country's holdings of the metal have declined.

Billy Miles' Loughlin trackmen, the perennial scholastic rulers in the city, walked off with four events in the meet, in which no point score was kept. The Bishops won two firsts in the open program and two in the novice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, changed places with four Washington reporters today and questioned them about alleged sensationalism and "unfair" attacks on public officials by some newspapers.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 Steel output last week was rounding out a banner year of production, with little likelihood of a letdown this week except that some mills were to be shut down for Christmas.

The Light of the World brightened the faces of small children yesterday evening at the annual Feast of Light service at the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street.

Wassail, called punch at other times of the year, will probably be a topic of much interest in many homes from now until Twelfth Night. New bowls to hold the various beverages preferred by each family are available.

Peculiarly symbolic of this Christmas time is the curtain of twinkling lights suspended like a starry sky over the crowds that gather in Rockefeller Plaza to admire the gleaming tree and listen to the lilt of old carols.
With the traditional Christian day of worship falling this year on Christmas Eve, thousands of New York church goers paid special homage last night to the birth of the Christ-child.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president-emeritus of the Union Theological Seminary, returned to the scene of his first labors in the ministry yesterday to give the golden anniversary sermon at the Bedford Park Presbyterian Church, 200th Street and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 24 The cities and towns of Malaya are swarming with Christmas buyers in a display of ready cash that has Government economists here worried.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 25 The United States Tenth Corps announced today that the sea evacuation of United Nations forces from the Hungnam beachhead had been completed.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 Comment in Moscow has expressed the conviction that the question of whether there will be a third world war depends upon the outcome of the struggle between East and West over the remilitarization of Western Germany.
Maids and other household workers were urged yesterday to lose no time in obtaining Social Security account numbers.

LONDON, Dec. 24 On Christmas Eve in the ruins of a church wrecked by the bombs of one war, prayers were said tonight for deliverance from the terrors of another.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 24 With the full endorsement of the Bonn Government, a vigorous campaign for "restoration of the honor of the German soldier" is about to begin throughout Western Germany. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer regards this as a primary psychological requirement for German participation in western Europe's defense.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 A new attack on California's problem of smog, a form of air pollution about which residents of the Los Angeles area have been complaining for several years, was foreshadowed recently as a legislative committee prepares its findings after two years of study.

City officials will press for a quick wage agreement on the major private bus lines before giving formal approval to the recommendation of Mayor Impellitteri's fact-finding committee for a general 10-cent fare.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 24 Miss Patricia Bell Blake, daughter of Mrs. Frances Bell Blake of Montclair and Comdr. Theodore D. Blake, U.S.N.R., of Los Altos, Calif., has chosen the afternoon of Jan. 13 for her marriage to Percival S. Hill 3d, son of Mrs. Hill 2d of Nutley and the late Mr. Hill.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 The fellowship system at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion here was hailed today as contributing "significantly" to interfaith understanding in America.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) With the steel industry completing a record shattering production year, the Magazine Steel predicted today that 1951 will be even bigger.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 24 Prices on the Amsterdam stock market rose as much as seven points this week. Shipping and Indonesian issues were best and improvement was noted in home industrials.

Three debuts will take place at the Metropolitan Opera during its ninth week which begins Jan. 1. EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 24 Twenty weeks a year the beaches from Montauk to Southampton are dotted with men engaged in a type of fishing known as "drawing seine." Many of them are descendants of the whalers of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.
Shakespeare's tragedy, "King Lear," with Louis Calhern starring in the title role, will open this evening at the National Theatre. The curtain for the premiere will rise at 7:45 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Dr. Helen Corbin Monchow, land economist and former professor at Northwestern University, died here yesterday at the age of 52.
West Side properties were involved in most of the Manhattan housing deals reported by brokers yesterday.

HANOI, Indo-China, Dec. 24 (AP) Joining the army and air force drive against Vietminh units which infiltrated the defense zone in north Indo-China, a French cruiser yesterday shelled the coastal village of Tamlang. The village, twelve miles from the China border, was a reported hideout for rebels.
Long Island University places its unbeaten record on the line tonight when it tangles with rugged Idaho in the feature clash of the collegiate double-header at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 24 An official announcement that the United States and Spain will exchange Ambassadors for the first time since 1945 is expected to be made soon. Final diplomatic amenities must be satisfied before the announcement can be made.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 24 Artillery rumbled across snow-sheeted mountains and crackled through frosted valleys tonight to provide an eerie background for carols and hymns as Seoul awaited the expected all-out assault by Chinese Communist armies massed north of the city.

William H. Buell, chemical engineer and vice president and general manager of the Polychem Corporation, 501 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 73 years old.

Announcement has been made here by Dr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Kerr of the American University in Beirut, Lebanon, of the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Anne, to Philip Caryl Jessup Jr., son of the United States Ambassador at Large and Mrs. Jessup of Washington and Norwalk, Conn.

Confidence in the survival of Christian civilization was voiced in sermons here yesterday as clergymen affirmed in a time of crisis their belief in the ultimate victory of Christ.

Nick Mickoski took care of the Chicago Black Hawks practically by himself at Madison Square Garden last night. The lanky New York Ranger forward scored four goals as his team subdued the skidding Hawks by the count of 6 to 1.

With Christmas distractions, you may have postponed the matter of a dress for a New Year's Eve date, a holiday party or a Southern vacation. The patterns today offer a group of quick-to-make fashions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 President Truman, delivering his Christmas message to the nation today, declared that, in the fight against the tyranny of Godless communism, democracy's most powerful weapon was "faith in the brotherhood and dignity of man under God."

CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 Although the Korean war apparently has not been a factor, there are 9.4 per cent fewer full-time and 7.1 per cent fewer grand-total students in American universities and four-year colleges this fall than last, Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, reported here tonight.

WHITE HAVEN, Pa., Dec. 24 A major skiland that compares favorably with those in the more northern areas of New York State, New England and the Canadian Laurentians is to be found here in the southlands of the Pennsylvania Poconos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) A well-known Roman Catholic educator said today that President Truman would be morally justified in striking first with the atomic bomb if this country were on the verge of being attacked.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 The Rev. Dr. John Carroll Perkins, minister emeritus of King's Chapel, died yesterday in his home at the age of 88.

TOKYO, Dec. 24 A wide split in the higher councils of international communism, with Chinese and Russians vying for control of Korea, preceded the massive Chinese intervention in the Korean war last month, according to authenticated information available today.

The Rev. Patrick Peyton, whose "Family Hour" consistently has been one of the more rewarding uses of radio for the presentation of religious themes, has made a notable contribution to television in his new film, "The Joyful Hour," which is being presented on all local video stations over the Christmas holidays.

PARIS, Dec. 24 France is now covering with exports 80 per cent of her imports from Latin America, according to official foreign trade sources. Prior to the war, France bought from these countries double the amount she sold them.

BABYLON, L.I. Dec. 24 Nearly $6,000,000 in contracts for work on the Captree parkway and causeway across Great South Bay are in the bidding stage and may be awarded next month. Included is the paving from the Southern State Parkway, north of West Islip, to Montauk Highway.

TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 24 Mrs. Ruth A. Peffall decorated the Christmas tree tonight in the corner of her living room, and placed gifts underneath for her two sons. Last Christmas Day her children were not here to receive the gifts. Tonight she still held fast to the hope that they might appear tomorrow.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam is at sea bound for Rotterdam with a new master in command as commodore of the company's fleet. A veteran of forty years in the Netherlands merchant marine, he has taken his company's vessels safely through every ocean and major sea in the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that the excessprofits tax bill being considered by Congress was a "travesty on justice" and called for a "fair and equitable" law to raise $6,000,000,000 to $7,000,000,000 in additional revenue.
A new lightweight, collapsible shipper for frozen foods has been perfected that will permit a sharp reduction in the cost of delivering such foods from warehouse to retail store.

The Department of Licenses, which on Saturday banned the showing of the Italian picture, "The Miracle," at the Paris Theatre on the ground that it was "blasphemous," has threatened to seek suspension or revocation of the license of any other New York theatre that attempts to screen the film.

The three-member truce committee of the United Nations General Assembly met yesterday to re-examine Communist China' refusal to have anything to do with its efforts for a cease-fire in Korea. No decision was taken on what the committee's next move might be.
Christmas was in the wings last night, waiting to work its annual magic of joy and hope today on a world beset with fears.

POWELL, Wyo., Dec. 24 New life is being pumped into the thirty-year-old Elk Basin oil field, near this community by what the Department of the Interior describes as a notable experiment in natural-resource conservation and the first operation of its kind in the world.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 24 The transition from peace to war production is expected to disturb the Rhode Island textile industry, the state's largest, more than it will some of the lesser industries.
A record high in generosity was reached in 1950 in the support of newspaper drives for the needy, aged, children, disabled veterans and the sick.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 24 A strange mass graveyard 200 feet underground has been found in a large limestone cavern in Calaveras County.

ROME, Dec. 24 The twentyfifth Holy Year in the history of the Roman Catholic Church ended at noon today when Pope Pius symbolically closed the Holy Door of St. Peter's during a majestic ceremony performed under the portico of the basilica.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 Mickey Rooney will report to Columbia in April, after he finishes Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Strip," to star in "Center Ring," which Nat Perrin will produce. Franklyn Coen is writing the photoplay, a circus story, in which Rooney will be seen as a clown.

The recent Federal Court decision against multi-million-dollar suits by longshoremen for back overtime on overtime is reported as having had a heartening effect on the stevedoring industry, which, for the first time in five years, no longer is faced with possible bankruptcy.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (UP) Lou (The Toe) Groza, Cleveland's kicker de luxe, kissed his shoe today in mute thanks for a tightsqueeze championship victory.

Thomas K. Scherman led an ensemble from his Little Orchestra Society late yesterday afternoon at the New Friends of Music concert in Town Hall. It was an unusual program of Bach's "Musical Offering" and his "Coffee" Cantata.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 24 The Israeli Government is becoming increasingly concerned over the fate of this tiny new state, which depends for sustenance on the outside world, in the event of a major armed conflict between East and West. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 Recent social surveys demonstrate that such a newly established Communist state as Yugoslavia has already encountered many of the social problems and evils that have existed for a long time in capitalist societies.

Children who suffer a form of stage-fright at the prospect of their first big holiday parties inspired two newly released booklets on teen-age manners. The intricacies and fine points of etiquette at home dinners, the theatre and formal parties are balanced with advice on getting along smoothly at school, on buses and on the job.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Two Government agencies have disagreed again over who should build a hydro-lectric dam at Roanoke Rapids, N.C.

Jack Koshak, alleged forger who escaped from the Barkley Avenue police station in the Bronx on Dec. 12, was captured early yesterday in the same Bronx apartment house where he was first arrested.

In the nature of things not all the news gathered on a given day--not even on Christmas Day--can be good. Tragedy strikes families and nations. Hundreds are killed, most of them needlessly, in holiday accidents.

The shapes and textures of straw objects these days make them decorative as well as practical. In use since the era of primitive man, according to the Encyclopaedia Britannica, this material makes inexpensive, lightweight articles that may be cleaned easily with a damp cloth.

Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, said in his year-end statement, released yesterday, that television had grown so rapidly this year that it might be very helpful in accelerating mobilization for defense.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINES IN KOREA, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP)--Maj. Gen. Oliver P. Smith, commander of the First Marine Division, said today that Chinese intelligence "must be of a low order--and I don't mean their military intelligence."

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 25--The violent Communist guerrilla, reaction against a new British program of resettling rural and suburban "squatter" inhabitants of Malaya has convinced the authorities here that the resettlement will make a basic contribution to the campaign against Communist insurgents in this area.

LONDON, Dec. 25--The Stone of Scone, the coronation stone of Britain, was stolen from its place in Westminster Abbey early on Christmas morning. In removing the 336-pound stone, the vandals also damaged the coronation chair upon which twentyseven British kings have been crowned.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25--The United States would have a vast potential of proteins if it managed its lakes as it did its pastures, Arthur D. Hasler, aquatic biologist and Professor of Zoology at the University of Wisconsin, said recently in outlining a new program for the fertilization of small lakes.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 25--The establishment of a Cornell University Council to aid in the longrange development of the university was announced here today.

Before 1950 is entirely over a review of the headliners is in order --the restaurants, imports, shops and domestic preparations that furnished us with food news during the year. Space being limited, we confine ourselves to those places, products and potables that seem, in flipping back through the file, to have been the most outstanding.
Ridgely Torrence, poet, playwright and editor, who won the Shelley Memorial prize in 1941, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after an illness of three months. He was 75 years old.

IN the later stages of the last baseball season there were some snickers at the predicament of the Boston Braves, whose pennant gamble had failed dismally. The Braves had ignored the future and made a one-year stab at the 1950 flag. They had stocked up with a lot of oven-aged--and over-paid--gaffers and missed tne target by a wide margin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25--How well is spelling taught in the United States ? What are the words most Commonly misspelled? Is it true, as many business men complain, that high school graduates today do not spell as well as those of fifty years ago?
The birth of the Prince of Peace was celebrated yesterday in the city's churches as thousands of devout New Yorkers, beset by the anxieties of war and toil, sought surcease in prayer.

After an ownership of nearly seventy-five years, the Constable Estate has disposed of a group of properties in the heart of the district which was once a center for Manhattan's retail and wholesale trading. The deal was reported to involve nearly $2,000,000.

"Hansel and Gretel," long identified with the holiday season because it is an opera about and for children, was presented in a special television version yesterday over the N. B. C. video outlet. Produced under the guidance of Samuel Chotzinoff, the work turned out to be well suited to projection on a small screen at home. It made a pleasant hour of viewing and listening.

One does not usually celebrate a military withdrawal, even in the face of an overwhelmingly large enemy force. There are exceptions, of course, such as Dunkerque, but the celebration stems from admiration of an indomitable spirit rather than from the appraisal of the movement itself.

The wholesale markets here were inactive last week, while retail trade was very busy, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Some last-minute calls were received by the offices for the holiday fill-in items.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP)--The Boston Bruins generated their highest scoring power of the National Hockey League's current season while subjecting the Chicago Black Hawks to their fourth straight setback at the Boston Garden tonight. The score was 7-4.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP)-- New York farms produced crops worth about $370,388,000 this year, according to the year-end Federalstate crop summary issued today by the State Agriculture Department. The department said the estimate compared with a crop value of $352,476,000 last year.
The public assistance case load in this city declined in November for the fifth consecutive month and disbursements were $158,864 less than in October.

Indicative of the shoe styles that will accompany spring fashions is footwear being shown for use at southern resorts. Many of the present designs have taken their lead from the latest fashion trends in both silhouette and color.

HONG KONG, Dec. 25--Communist Gen. Yeh Chien-ying, governor of Kwangtung and vice chairman of the Central-South Military Zone, was reported today to have left Canton on an inspection trip to Kwangsi and Hunan Provinces.

Large larcenies on New York's waterfront are becoming fewer each year as the direct result of the campaign against theft and pilferage being carried on by the Security Bureau, Inc., Benn Barber, president of this maritime industry organization, asserted yesterday.
Borough offices of the American Red Cross were busy yesterday handling emergency appeals for aid on the holiday.

Full compliance with the Economic Stabilization Agency's Dec. 1 price freeze, so far as raw material prices make it possible, is pledged for the shoe industry in a statement released today by the National Shoe Institute. The institute is the joint committee of the...
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP)--Nearly 2,000,000 Scots last year signed the Scottish Covenant, a petition for a greater measure of home rule along the lines of that enjoyed by Northern Ireland.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25--An increase in industrial building of war production facilities was predicted today by R.D. Wood, president of the American Institute of Steel Construction, national association of the fabricated steel industry.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP)-- At least six elderly men perished tonight in a three-alarm fire in Sam's Hotel, east of the downtown district. None was identified immediately.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) --Rear Admiral George W. Bauer, retired, was found dead in his apartment today. The police said his body was hanging in a noose fashioned from Christmas neckties.

Furniture manufacturing activity as a whole is continuing at peak levels, despite some signs of slackening, according to a report issued for publication today by Seidman Seidman certified public accountants.

A gulf developed yesterday between the wage expectations of Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., and the pay increases that operators of major private bus lines were prepared to give their 8,000 drivers and mechanics.

Not in our time has "King Lear" had so worthy a hearing in New York. It opened at the National last evening with Louis Calhern as the monarch of anguish and woe. This is Shakespeare's most savage tragedy and the most difficult to stage.

ROME, Dec. 25--Pope Pius signed today a papal Bull extending the Holy Year's spiritual benefits to the entire world in 1951, received a special Italian Government mission that gave him a Christmas gift and then spent the rest of the day quietly with members of his immediate family. The Bull will be published tomorrow.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)--Jockey Willie Shoemaker closed ground on Joe Culmone today and trailed by only two winners in their race for riding honors of the year.

NEWPORT, R. I., Dec. 25--G. J. Guthrie Nicholson, retired rancher and industrialist, died last night at his estate. The Glen, in near-by Portsmouth, after a long illness. He was in his eightieth year.

A new approach to the harassing question of the Arab refugees is indicated with United Nations approval of a $50,000,000 fund for the next fiscal year that carries implications far beyond either the existing work relief or dole.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP)-- Senator Zales M. Ecton, Republican of Montana, predicted today there will be a serious effort in the new Congress to increase the nation's copper reserves by aiding domestic producers and cutting the present import tax.
DENVER, Dec. 25 (AP)--Protesting against the proposed rearming of Western Germany, three Denver housewives picketed today the home where Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was spending Christmas.

TOKYO, Dec. 25 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway arrived tonight on his way to take over command of the United States Eighth Army in Korea. He succeeds Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker, killed two days ago in a jeep accident near the front.

"No one is interested in building a military shipping empire," and the private American merchant marine is not in jeopardy on this score, according to John T. Koehler, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

Long Island University's undefeated basketball team maintained its unblemished record by rallying to turn back Idaho, 59-- 57, before 8,126 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Clair Bee's Blackbirds achieved their sixth straight victory when, with only forty-two seconds remaining, Leroy Smith counted with a shortrange one-hander.

LONDON, Dec. 25--In his annual message to the people of the British Commonwealth, King George VI referred today to the blight that falls upon this Christmas throughout the world. With the "grim shadow of war" overhanging the world, he said, it was difficult to "feel the happiness and merriment which naturally belong to Christmas."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25--The audible hiss of the lighted fuse which is carrying its spark toward world destruction on a timing schedule known only to the Kremlin has made this an apprehensive Christmas in the West.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP)--Santa Claus deserted the New York Rangers tonight as they dropped a 4-1 decision to the Detroit Red Wings in a bruising National Hockey League battle. It was the first time since 1928 that the Rangers had lost on Christmas night.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25--The three Todd boys, aged 10 to 13, who wanted to join the Army or Navy because they felt Uncle Sam needed "lots of help," were turned down with thanks by the Army today. But they took their rejection philosophically.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25--The City Council has enacted a new code that sets up a Chicago Traffic Commission and revises virtually the entire system of ordinances governing traffic.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 25 (AP)-- Oklahoma, the nation's top football team, will arrive here tomorrow for its pre-Sugar Bowl drills, but there will be no sneak preview of Sooner, might for Mississippians.
Two men have been flying a small plane over the Adirondacks in recent days.

HONG KONG, Dec. 25--A full official membership list of the new coalition Government established by the Chinese Communists for the Tibetan Autonomous Region in Western Sikang Province on Nov. 24 has just become available here.

BILLINGS, Mont., Dec. 25-- Montana Indians, who have a high death rate from tuberculosis, will receive care in the state tuberculosis sanitarium at Galen, Mont., under a contract signed here by Paul L. Fickinger, area director of the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 25--The Egyptian Government and Army command are waiting today to see whether reported mobilization of Israeli troops near Egyptian-held Gaza strip constituted a threat.
Now that everything has been satisfactorily adjusted, "The Green Bay Tree" will begin its second Broadway career on Feb. 1 after a lapse of sixteen years. Residence will be established at the Golden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25--It appeared tonight that the five-member Subversive Activities Control Board, appointed by President Truman in October to administer the Communist registration phases of the new Internal Security Act, would not be approved during the present Congress and would run into difficulties with the incoming one.
LENOX, Mass., Dec. 25--George Alfred Mole, Lenox lawyer, banker and civic leader, died today in Pittsfield General Hospital, at the age of 74.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP)--A fighting South team came from behind and smashed over a touchdown in the last forty-five seconds tonight to beat the North, 14 to 9, in the Shrine's third annual charity football game here before 39,132 spectators in the Orange Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP)-- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today that the Administration apparently "muffed the ball" and contributed to inflation by failing to intervene when the steel industry recently increased wages and prices.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 --Col. Gen. Ivan Goshnyak, Deputy Minister of Defense and a member of the Yugoslav Politburo made it clear today in a speech to the Communist party organization in Zagreb that Yugoslav leaders did not share Western Europe's deep pessimism regarding the Chinese Communist victories in Korea nor any fatalistic acceptance of a Soviet victory in the event of a third world war.
FORT DIX, N. J., Dec. 25 (AP)-- A teen-age Wac was killed and seven other Army personnel were injured in a Christmas morning auto collision after attending midnight mass.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 25--Sugar Ray Robinson, the world welterweight titleholder, concluded his five-bout European tour here tonight with a neat fiveround knockout of Hans Stretz, a willing but outclassed former German champion.

Next Tuesday forty cadet-midshipmen of the class of 1951 at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I, will leave their classrooms for a month's assignment with various steamship companies. The group will be followed by a second contingent a month later.

The new Wollman Memorial outdoor skating rink in Central Park was crowded yesterday afternoon with bright jacketed skaters, young and old, many with shiny Christmas-present skates. But the Christmas Day hush stilled the streets in most of midtown Manhattan.

As General Eisenhower prepares to return to Europe to build up an integrated Atlantic defense force which must include German contingents to make it effective, it begins to appear as though the success of his efforts would largely depend on the outcome of two series of negotiations initiated by the Western Powers.

To begin with, let's list the nicer things about the Capitol's current bundle of Technicolor celluloid from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, "Pagan Love Song." Not having ever laid eyes upon Tahiti, we can have no quarrel with the tropical scenery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP)-- The American Legion asked the nation's children today to play Santa Claus for underprivileged children here and abroad by joining its annual "Tide of Toys" drive.

KALIMPONG, India, Dec. 25-- With a new threat to Lhasa developing in the Communist Chinese drive from Western Tibet, the Dalai Lama is at last leaving his sequestered Himalayan state for sanctuary in India, it was reported from Phari Dzong today.

HELENA, Mont., Dec. 25--Plans for changing the method of electing Montana judges have been recommended by the Committee on Selection and Tenure of the Judiciary of the Montana Bar Association, and will be presented to the 1951 Legislature, convening in January, if approved by the state association.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (AP) --Following are the texts of a special communiqu issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur, a report to General MacArthur from Maj. Gen. Edward M. Almond, United States Tenth Corps commander, and an announcement by the Navy:
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25--Mrs. Thomas Jones Hilliard, wife of a former vice president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, died in Shadyside Hospital last night after a brief illness.

The busy program of four college double-headers arranged for Madison Square Garden this week keeps in full swing as St. John's meets Temple and New York University plays host to Stanford in the second twin bill in as many nights. In keeping with the new...
The country faces a serious teacher shortage, particularly on the elementary level. A survey conducted by this newspaper discloses some rather disturbing facts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25--The Federal Reserve Board estimated today that four out of ten American families are worth at least $5,000, and that one family in ten has assets of $25,000 or more.
TOKYO, Dec. 25 (UP)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur charged today that recent "vicious" Communist propaganda broadcasts were "openly inciting" guerrillas to the atrocity-murder of United States prisoners.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 26--The withdrawal of the United States Tenth Corps from the Hungnam beachhead in northeastern Korea completed the readjustment of the United Nations positions forced by the Chinese intervention in the war, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said in a special communique this morning.

PENTICTON, B.C., Dec. 25 (AP)--The blanket-shrouded bodies of two commercial fliers were brought down snowy Mount Okanogan by stretcher-bearers late last night, completing a three-day plane crash rescue operation.
Rolf Obermaier, the 5-year-old German boy grounded in Long Island Saturday, 3,000 miles from his new home in the United States, enjoyed an American-style Christmas yesterday with his temporary hosts.

Eighth Army area: United Nations forces along the Eighth Army front maintained and improved their positions throughout Sunday. Enemy forces continued the pressure against our lines northeast of Chunchon. Counterattacking United Nations troops have regained ground taken by the enemy on Saturday.

"The Yellow Storm," a new novel by Lau Shaw, will be issued by Harcourt, Brace on Feb. 9. Set in Peiping during the Japanese occupation, it is a story about the simple people who live in seven compounds on a street called the Little Sheep Fold.

BENGHAZI, Cyrenaica, Dec. 10 --With Libya due to emerge as a fully independent state by the end of the coming year, 45,000 Italians in the western territory--Tripolitania--are wondering anxiously what is to become of them.
ONE of the novels crowded out of this space in October's torrent of new books was a pretty good one, "Jubel's Children," by Lenard Kaufman.

An uneasy world celebrated Christmas yesterday with fervent prayers for peace. Supplications to the Prince of Peace rose from great cathedrals and from humble chapels, from the lips of men and women everywhere, and from the lips of their national leaders.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25--The latest chapter in the touching story of Patsy Li, a 15-year-old Chinese waif of World War II, ended on a happy note here.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS, in Korea, Dec. 25--Amid flurries of snow and the din of gunfire, men of the Fifty-second Field Artillery waited in line for their Christmas dinner here to day. Only about 100 feet away

Walt Disney can take over television any time he likes. Yesterday afternoon, in a special holiday show at 4 o'clock over N.B.C., he momentarily relaxed his ban against television appearances by Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, Pluto and the Seven Dwarfs.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 19--Inferior in numbers, tanks and guns the Allied forces in West Germany are striving to make sure that in one important aspect, that of morale, they are the equal of the Soviet forces in Eastern Germany.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 25-- Ground has been broken for a $5,242,000 cancer research hospital, the first of four units planned here by the University of Texas in this city's Texas Medical Center. The unit will have 150 beds and will be called the M. D. Anderson Hospital for Cancer Research.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25-- Fidelity Pictures, the Howard Welsch-Pam Blumenthal independent company, has acquired an option on "My Fine Feathered Friend," a musical comedy laid in the Twenties which Dorothy Parker is writing from a story by Alan Campbell and Hunt Stromberg Jr.
On Christmas Day The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached $226,008,86 as donors from a score of states sent gifts to bring a measure of holiday joy to the needy.
Frankie Neve, veteran of 200 ring fights, took his worst licking Christmas Eve from a 4-month-old infant who wore him down to a walk in a night-long engagement.

Supplemental appropriations are urgently needed to relieve congestion of imports through United States customs entry points, Congressional and Government agency officials were warned over the holiday week-end by the National Council of American Importers.

Weather permitting, all airline arrivals and departures are from La Guardla Airport unless otherwise noted. The cities listed below in capital letters are terminal points. With rare exceptions, all inbound and outbound planes carry mail.

The marriage of Miss Meta Weintrob, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Weintrob of Brooklyn, to Alan Edward Willis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Willis of Rego Park, Queens, took place yesterday afternoon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun in West Eighty-eighth Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 25-- Contrary to so many "expert" predictions, the Israeli Government will maintain its policy of unrestricted immigration although it is the primary cause of the country's critical economic condition.

BOSTON, Dec. 25--Massachusetts and Boston civil defense officials watched the Christmas holiday week-end pass without incident today and privately expressed thanks that security measures were not put to a test by a "major catastrophe."

President Truman's Christmas Eve plea for nation-wide prayers for peace was hailed yesterday by the head of the new National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. as a major "reinforcement" for religion's "prayer crusade."

Two new films will arrive in first-run houses this morning. At the Victoria, the attraction is "Born Yesterday," with Judy Holliday, Broderick Crawford and William Holden heading the cast of the comedy presented by Columbia and adapted by Albert Mannheimer from Garson Kanin's long-run ...
LONDON, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--Attached to the stone of Scone in olden times, on a piece of metal, was a prophecy that Sir Walter Scott translated as:
Two men who are said to have admitted holding up thirty hotels in the last two weeks, nine of them on Christmas morning, were held without bail on robbery charges yesterday in Felony Court.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (UP)-- A fine-scarred 8,000-ton tanker which was in collision with a loaded oil barge on the Mississippi River here last night was beached today.
When Dante reached the circle of the Fixed Stars and swung around on the constellation of Gemini, "the eternal Twins," he looked back over the road he had traversed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP)-- Senators Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, and John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, believe that the fate of the United Nations hinges on a swift military build-up by the free nations.
Two families were routed from their homes on Christmas Day by a fire in a four-story brick building at 4019 Third Avenue, Brooklyn.
HOUSTON, Dec. 25 (AP)--There was little open grumbling heard as Government officials asked the oil industry to hold its price line.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 25-- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors today ruled that the late Walter Huston was justified in canceling a performance of his play, "The Apple of His Eye," in Worcester, Mass., on Dec. 16, 1946.
HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 25--A laboratory for research on how to simplify work and production procedures in industry is being set up at the Thayer School of Engineering at Dartmouth College.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 25--In a Christmas broadcast from Bonn, Federal Chancellor Konrad Adenauer this morning reasserted the West German Government's determination to defend the nation "together with other peace-loving nations."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP)-- The State Department accused Russia today of having engaged in an increasingly "bitter and vicious" propaganda attack on the United States, which was "now bordering upon open psychological warfare."
OFF HUNGNAM, Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (AP)--In war, the warmakers sometimes destroy something essentially simple and nonmilitary, like a fence or house, simply because it stands in the way of the war.

ALTHOUGH the upland game season is now over in the North, except for the preserve shooting, those planning a Southern trip will find excellent quail shooting in a half-dozen states and can even make a try for a gobbler in three of these.

Though he was rebuffed in his bid to regain the world heavyweight title he surrendered volun, tarily, and has failed since to show any of the ability which once made him feared as the ring's Brown Bomber, Joe Louis is named as the No. 1 challenger for Ezzard Charles' championship in tha ratings of Nat Fleischer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP)-- Workmen will start a race against the clock tomorrow to get the Capitol in shape for the incoming Congress.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 25--President Truman, after a long telephone conversation with Secretary of State Dean Acheson, has decided to cut short his Christmas vacation by twenty hours. He will take off on the four-hour flight to Washington tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock, Central Standard Time.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP)--The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today that direct price controls on agricultural commodities should be avoided "as long as possible."

The Communist party, now at the low point of its influence in America, will open it fifteenth biennial national convention here this week. The convention will start with public rallies in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn tomorrow night and three days of "closed door" sessions for the Communist high command immediately afterward.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (AP) The Moscow radio announced today the appointment of a twelveman committee that will award the first International Stalin Peace Prizes.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20--Despite the introduction of two new tanks, one American and one British, the reorganization of United States infantry regiments to increase their fire and striking power and improvements in some other weapons, the equipment with which the United States, British and French Armies would meet a Soviet attack in Europe remains very much what it was in 1945.
LONDON, Dec. 26--James Stephens, author of "A Crock of Gold" and many other books and poems touched with a glow of Irish fantasy, died at his home here tonight. He was 68 years old.
Support for the campaign by merchants here to oppose an increase in the city sales tax was voiced yesterday by a trade group representing 350 independent retailers.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec., 26-- Police Judge James N. Brems of Haverstraw was released until Jan. 9 in the custody of his lawyer by Rockland County Judge Robert Doscher today when he pleaded not guilty to a fourteen-count indictment charging him with failure to make proper returns of fines.

BENGAZI, Cyrenaica, Dec. 10-- When Libya accedes to independence a year or so from now, it will be the eighth Arab country to achieve full statehood and its soverign-designate, Emir Sayyid Mohammed Idriss el Mahdi el Senussi, will become the fifth king in the Arab world.

Rubber, hides and the non-ferrous metals were traded narrowly and in comparatively small volume on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Crude rubber, a strategic import commodity, traded only 100 long tons during the session. Both the London and Singapore rubber markets were closed for the holiday season.

Who won or lost in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night became merely incidental to nearly all of the 8,238 fans on hand. As it developed, St. John's swarmed all over Temple by 90--68 and N. Y. U. routed hitherto unbeaten Stanford, 84--70, but it was a three-cornered struggle for the season's individual high at the Eighth Avenue arena that held the interest of the spectators.

Three million stockholders in the power and light business, and an unknown number of bondholders in that third largest industry, should find cause to cheer in estimates of what 1950 meant to their investments. If the official calculators are correct--and they usually are-- revenues from the sale of electricity during 1950 will have risen 9 per cent over 1949 record gross revenues to $4,482,000,000.

Tax selling tools a fairly heavy toll on the stock market yesterday and with the lack of any followthrough to the pre-Christmas rally, prices suffered the worst reversal since Dec. 14. After an early effort to further last week's rise, the list encountered sufficent liquidation to produce losses of fractions to 2 points. The composite rate slipped 1.58 points.
TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)--Release 763 issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters at 4:05 P.M. Tuesday (2:05 A.M. Tuesday, Eastern Standard Time):
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP)--The West won again today--as it has in thirteen previous meeting of the annual Men's Intercollegiate Swimming Forum, 37 to 18.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--All deliveries of corn and soybeans and the deferred months in wheat and rye went to new high levels for the year on the Board of Trade here today, commission house buying and short-covering finding offerings light in the early trading, but when the demand was satisfied the markets eased under profit taking,...

CAIRO, Dec, 26--The Egyptian Parliament and press have sharply criticized during the last two days intervention in political matters and agitation among officers by a group known as "Free Officers." The Wafdist review, Al Sawadi, called the group "fingers of Communists or Zionists."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec, 26 (AP) --The Peiping Communist radio reported that 173 United States Marines and infantrymen, captured in the Changjin. Reservoir area, had been "removed to the rear" from Northeast Korea.

Food sales for the Christmas holiday week-end in this area showed a good-size gain over last year, and a possible record in bulk and dollar volume, it was reported yesterday by retail food trade sources.

A repeat performance of what happened at the Yankee Stadium two years ago is in prospect for the 1951 baseball season if forecasts on the outcome of the pennant race in the junior circuit run true to form.

After a long, arduous holiday weekend, some of the town's most outspoken and enthusiastic youngsters repaired to the BarbizonPlaza Theatre yesterday afternoon for a performance of "The Three Bears," and the indications were that they enjoyed it. A simple variation of the Goldilocks story, written by Charlotte B. Chorpenning, the play was presented by the Children's World Theatre. Other performances are scheduled for today through Saturday.

Operating by remote control, Maurice Evans, artistic supervisor of the New York City Theatre Company, who is detained in Hollywood, has been marshaling the City Center's winter program, which opens at 8:15 tonight with George Bernard Shaw's "Captain Brassbound's Conversion."

CORAL GABLES. Fla., Dec. 26 (AP)--Jockeys Joe Culmone and Willie Shoemaker continued neck and neck today in their race for riding honors of 1950 as each booted home two winners. Culmone now has 375 for the year and Shoemaker 373.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 26--Progress made by a new Social Science Research Center and the establishment of similar agencies in four other fields of research were notable gains during 1950 at Cornell, the university reports in a yearend review.
With a strike on the city's principal private bus lines threatened for midnight Sunday, new complications entered the bus wage situation yesterday.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Dec.26-- Nassau County police are looking for a young bandit who used an ingenious method of proving to a store owner here today that he was equipped for robbery but then missed the store's week-end receipts by less than a minute.

One of the highest awards in aviation--the Robert J. Collier Trophy-- goes this year to a man who has shown much forward thinking in the application of electronics to the air. He is William P. Lear. The trophy is awarded for his automatic pilot, weighing only thirty-six pounds, which has contributed so much to making practical, under battle conditions, the use of ultra-swift modern jet fighters.

WASHINGTON, Dec.26--Death by starvation may face thousands of Yellowstone's famed elk herd if this winter is severe. Not only the elk, but the scenic values of Yellowstone Park and and its unusual vegetation will be destroyed if the Elk population is not reduced, animal specialists of the National Park Service and other federal and state agencies believe.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 26 (Reuters)--Wool prices have risen so high that Australian ranchers just are not butchering their sheep for meat.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP)--Fastmoving Tottenham Hotspur won its third game in four days and moved within 1 point of the lead in the English Football League today.

Quill, for instance, enjoyed professing...

LONDON, Dec,26--The freshlycarved initials "J.F.S." on Britain's coronation chair were the only clue today to the theft of the Stone of Scone, the British coronation stone, from Westminster Abbey early Christmas Day. Scotland Yard issued an appeal for information and police continued their nation-wide search.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 (AP) --The Eventual transfer of governmental powers in turbulent Nepal from the Prime Minister to the people is provided under proposals voted by the Parliament in Katmandu on Christmas Eve, a Nepalese spokesman said here today.
The Federal Reserve System's bid for the longest-term bonds of the United States Government was dropped a slight fraction yesterday, marking the first market change of this kind in nearly a month.
The Long Island Rail Road is embarking at once on a $6,000,000 program to install automatic speed control and cab signal devices on 52.6 miles of road, its most heavily traveled
The first measurable snow of the winter whitened New York yesterday, on the third anniversary of its biggest blizzard.

A 20-year-old pseudo-cowboy bandit from Florida, who said two partners in crime had left him stranded in a midtown hotel, surrendered yesterday to the police and warned that his partners were armed with a small arsenal and "ready to kill."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The Army tonight issued a call for 7,500 volunteers from among the captains and lieutenants on the rolls of the Organized Reserve Corps and the National Guard. Principally sought are officers trained in combat specialties.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 27-- United Nations troops were unified in Korea yesterday under a new field commander, Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, as Chinese Communist troops were officially identified south of the Thirtyeighth Parallel for the first time when patrols were reported twenty-eight miles north of the South Korean capital of Seoul.

Mrs. Ralph Noel Dagg, former advertising director of the General Foods Corporation, who was known to the public during her business career as Ella (Bobbie) Myers, died yesterday in her home at Yale Farms near Armonk, Westchester County, after a long illness.
A former Follies girl, who was once the wife of Gordon Godowsky, son of Leopold Godowsky, noted pianist and composer, was found strangled yesterday, morning in an East Side hotel.

Debutantes of this season, young women introduced last season, and young men at home from schools and colleges for the holidays attended the annual Yuletide Assembly held last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre under the direction of Miss Bonnie May Murray.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 26 --West German officials and political leaders in northern Germany are distressed by what they describe as a "Danish cultural offensive" in the northern part of Schleswig-Holstein, just south of the Danish border,

After several wet runs, fake rains, glowering of clouds and disappointing flurries that quickly melted, the child was naturally taking no chances. Peering out of her window,...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Two Defense Department Korean casualty lists issued today carried 533 names. Of the total, 105 are dead, 248 wounded, 139 missing end 41 injured in war zone accidents. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

HONG KONG, Dec. 26--A new call for technicians to help develop Northwest China has been issued by the Communist Military and Administrative Commission for that area. The Nothwest zone includes the five provinces of Sinkiang, Tshinghai, Kansu, Ningsia and Shansi.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP)-- United States Attorney John McKay filed a motion in Federal District Court today asking either for a partial summary judgment or a temporary injunction against The Times-Picayune Publishing Company for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

JUST as the wind blasted some powdery snow through a crack in the window, a wire was dropped on our desk from Ernie Lyons of Stuart, Fla., reporting the largest run of sailfish since 1940, as well as exceptional catches of channel bass, bluefish and snook.

With the appointment yesterday of Deputy Commissioner Dominick F. Paduano as Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, Mayor Impellitteri gave representation in his Cabinet to a potent wing of labor that supported him for election.

In the First Baptist Church at Flushing, Queens, last night Miss Ada Sue Groome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Marvin Groome of Flushing, was married to Harold Robert Henry, son of Mrs. Walter Henry of Atlanta and the late Mr. Henry.

Three hundred persons--musicians, music lovers and members of the family--attended a funeral service yesterday at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, for Dr. Walter Damrosch, composer and conductor, who died Friday at his home, 168 East Seventy-first Street, of a heart attack at the age of 88.

Evacuation, even when described as "redeployment," is seldom regarded as good news--not, at least, in the United States. The British were able to celebrate Dunkerque as a victory, but Americans are inclined to think of the most heroic retreats as misfortunes other nations are forced to suffer. The tradition of invincibility is strong in us.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Representative Victor Wickersham, Democrat of Oklahoma, called today for immediate passage of legislation to encourage construction of merchant ships which would be of military value.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26--The discovery of an unusual star in an unusual place in the universe was reported today before the astronomical section of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opened its annual meeting here.

Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler announced yesterday that television rights to the World Series and annual all-star games have been sold for the next six years for $6,000,000 to the Gillette Safety Razor Company.
Prominent members of the National Music Council, meeting here yesterday, agreed that musicians faced bleak days but they were divided on whether Government subsidies were necessary or even desirable.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP)-- A foul by Nick Stallworth in the last 26 seconds of play gave Idaho a 64-63 victory over St. Joseph's tonight. Idaho waived two other fouls in the last eight seconds to insure its triumph.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26--A strike of American Federation of Labor carpenters stopped repair and "de-mothballing" work on five Navy ships today at the Todd Shipyard in Alameda, on the east side of San Francisco Bay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP)-- The Army announced today that it had started production of a new anti-tank weapon capable of knocking out any known tank--the 105mm. Jeep-mounted recoilless rifle.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 26 (Reuters)--With eight wickets still to go in the second innings after close of play today, England needed 151 runs to beat Australia in the second cricket test match here.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 26 (UP)-- Glenalee McCarthy, 17-year-old daughter of Glenn McCarthy, millionaire, eloped early this month with George Pontikes, 19-year-old son of an immigrant shoe repairman.

Three new "public interest" campaigns in 3,300 house organs will be begun next week by the Advertising Council. The first copy, designed to aid defense production, was prepared for the free use of company publications by McCann-Erickson, Inc.
The United Nations can develop into a world government only if its Assembly is elected directly by the people, Dr. Albert Einstein declared in a statement released last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Richmond, Calif., led all cities with 25,000 or more population in the 1950 census in rate of growth since 1940. The Census Bureau reported today that Richmond had 23,642 persons listed in 1940 and gained 319.7 per cent by showing 99,218 in 1950.

The possibility of either a new opera house or the complete rehabilitation of the present Metropolitan Opera House has been pushed further into the future by the international situation, George A. Sloan, board chairman, reported yesterday.

IN the seventeenth century a wind from the west blew over England, says Shirley Barker in her historical romance, "Rivers Parting." From the Sussex downs to the Yorkshire dales men heard its call and left their farms and their shops and sailed westward to the new lands across the sea. Some of them went to Virginia

A drive for the Associated Services Fund in behalf of the Associated Services for the Armed Forces, to begin in January, will provide New Yorkers with an opportunity to contribute to an expanded A. S. A. F. program designed to meet the spiritual, welfare and recreational needs of the military forces. Success in the drive will assure support for "home front" hospitality programs here in New York.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 26--As front-line reports reveal increasing pressure against the United Nations lines by the massing Chinese Communist forces, Seoul is rapidly being drained of its civilian population and taking on the appearance of an already abandoned city.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26--Political analysts of the Yugoslav Communist party put forward today the theory that the Chinese Communists had sent their armies into Korea to challenge the Soviet Government's pretension to be the dominant power in Asia.

A first-hand insight into life behind the Iron Curtain was provided last night in a special documentary radio program over C.B.S. at 10:30 o'clock. Awkwardly produced in spots, the program, entitled "Through the Curtain," constituted a most effective indictment of communism because it was neither hysterical nor given to value generalities.

A subway-bound crowd of several hundred persons near Astor Place and Fourth Avenue witnessed a spectacular pistol battle at 5:30 P. M. yesterday. They saw an off-duty policeman, flat on his face in the slush, kill a hold-up man in a duel in which each man fired six shots.

PARIS, Dec. 26--Overriding Premier Rene Pleven, the National Assembly today voted 302 to 289, to postpone until tomorrow the opening discussion on the rearmament financing bill. The bill would provide an increase in French taxes for defense by 8.5 per cent of the national income.

To the relieved officials and nurses concerned, yesterday's shift of the New York Orthopaedic Dispensary and Hospital to its new quarters at Columbia-Presbyterian-Medical Center was smooth and undramatic. But to some of the thirty-two patients it was almost as good as a picnic.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., ended its fiscal year Sept. 30 with working capital and earned surplus at new peaks, unfilled orders rising and "accelerating monthly earnings running at the annual rate of better than $2 a common share," according to the annual report issued today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--President Truman was reported authoritatively today to have disclaimed any intention to intervene in the selection of a Democratic Senate leader for the incoming Eightysecond Congress.

DES MOINES, Dec. 26(AP)--The Farmers Grain Dealers Association of Iowa tonight urged Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan to restrict sales by the Commodity Credit Corporation of corn and feed grains.
Now is a good time to settle down to write thank-you notes for Christmas gifts, before the excitement of receiving the presents has worn off. Papers suitable for such messages are in various stores.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 17-- Mayors for fourteen Israeli towns will be chosen soon by the new municipal councils that were returned in popular country-wide elections on Nov. 14. Twenty-nine local councils in rural areas will also elect chairmen.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 26--The Netherlands proposed to Indonesia today that authority over Western New Guinea be vested in the Netherlands-Indonesian Union. This would have the effect of creating a condominium over disputed territory.
[Later reports of the United Nations on fighting in Korea, P. 2.] Release 761 issued at 11:35 A. M. Tuesday (9:35 P. M., Monday, Eastern standard time):

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--The first test of the public's willingness to pay for premium entertainment in the home will be started New Year's Day when the Zenith Radio Corporation begins its Government-authorized limited test of Phonevision, its "box-office" television system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP)-- United States corporations approach 1951 in record financial condition as a result of a twelveyear program of corporate working capital expansion, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Responding to the efforts of manufacturers to hold the price line, specialty shop owners are placing substantial orders for early spring delivery. At the opening of the Metropolitan Juvenile Mart yesterday, more than 400 smaller retailers in the metropolitan area visited the New Yorker Hotel to view children's apparel lines.

The retirement on June 1, 1951, of Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary as president of the New York State Maritime College was announced yesterday by Arthur M. Tode, chairman of the college board of visitors. Admiral Leary will reach his sixty-sixth birthday on May 31.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26-- Jean Simmons, British film star, is regarded as the likeliest prospect for the role of Rowena in M-G-M's projected production of "Ivanhoe," in which Stewart Granger, Miss Simmons' husband, will play the title role.

Richmond Weed, well-known attorney, who was president of St. John's Guild, collapsed and died yesterday as he was emerging from the Broad and Wall Street subway station to go to his law office at 15 William Street. He was 75 years old.

The circus came to town with the snowfall yesterday, bringing its sun-tanned performers from Florida and other Southern spots for three weeks at the armory at West Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue.
LONDON. Dec. 26--Lady ForbesRobertson, widow of the Edwardian actor, Sir Johnston-ForbesRobertson, died at her home in Kent on Christmas Eve. She was 76 years old.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26--The world has enough potential mineral and biological resources to meet all present needs of the world's population if the resources are properly developed, two Harvard University scientists declared here today at the opening general symposium of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Christmas leaves even the appetite of a food columnist somewhat apathetic, though not so much so that we cannot with pleasure consider a little restaurant known as Le Gourmet, at 49 West Fifty-fifth Street. Many establishments in this city go by the tag of "French restaurant;" this is one of the few to which the term may be aptly applied.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were little changed yesterday after the threeday holiday and the close was 6 points higher to 26 points lower than on last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP)-- The Korean war has put the brakes on the Government's public housing and slum clearance program, and officials are rapidly completing a new program emphasizing housing for defense workers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- The National Boxing Association today gave to Joe Louis, former heavyweight champion, his lowest boxing rating in thirteen years of campaigning.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 26--The Embassy of Nepal officially confirmed today that rebels under the banner of the Nepali Congress had occupied the important industrial town of Biratnagar and also Bhojpur and Chainpur in East Nepal and Kailali and Kanchanpur in West Nepal.

Mrs. Ann Remington, divorced wife of William W. Remington, testified in Federal Court at his perjury trial yesterday that he had told her in the spring of 1938 that he was a member of the Communist party.

Sam Minskoff, founder and head of Sam Minskoff Sons, one of the city's leading building firms, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in the Hotel Navarro, 112 Central Park South. He had observed his sixty-sixth birthday a week ago.

Arthur W. Wallander, the city's civil defense director, urged women yesterday to enroll in defense agencies. He said they could play an important part in the program, particularly when men were at work.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Leaders of the Lutheran and Methodist churches issued a call here today for solemn observances of the New Year week-end.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--It is doubtful there will be a request for new taxes in January, the White House said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The National Production Authority today established a facilities and construction bureau, with Frank R. Creedon as chief, to expedite industrial expansion and related defense construction.

NEWARK, Dec, 26--Officials of New Jersey and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company this afternoon held the opening wage negotiation conference with union representatives of 500 gas production workers. The session was adjourned after two hours to next Tuesday. Unofficial reports indicated progress.

HONG KONG, Dec. 26--General Chu Teh, Commander in Chief of the Chinese Communist Army, told a mass rally in Peiping on Sunday that Communist victories in Korea would bring about a "new upsurge" of revolutionary activity throughout Asia, the New China News Agency reported here today.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., Dec. 26 --A $750,000 lignite laboratory to spearhead research aimed at greater use of the country's enormous lignite reserves is ready for work here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although there is much to be said for Mr. Hoover's economic demands, and for his recommendations with regard to Communist China and the United Nations, his military position is untenable and completely nullifies his avowal of no appeasement; "no more Teherans and Yaltas."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Communist China has become an important supplier of strategic raw materials to the Soviet Union, information available here indicates. Much of this represents minerals formerly exported to the United States but now being diverted to the Soviet Union.
The Department of Commerce yesterday reported the following winter sports conditions at state resorts:

Coasting and skiing facilities in New York parks were listed last night by the Department of Parks. Main slopes and hills will be supervised by department playground directors during the hours of greatest use. The places listed were:

ROME, Dec. 26--The Latin text of the "Apostolic Constitution," by which the Pope extended the Holy Year through 1951 to Catholics throughout the world was published today in the Vatican organ L'Osservatore Romano.

The City of New York has borrowed $60,000,000 on tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 1 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold to twenty-three local banks and trust companies. The obligations were dated Dec. 27, 1950, and will come due as follows: $30,000,000 on April 23, 1951, and $30,000,000 on April 25, 1951.
Formation of a committee to press for an emergency allocation of grain to India was announced yesterday at a meeting attended by Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian Ambassador to this country.

The New York Rangers, who lost their first Christmas night game since 1928 last Monday at Detroit, returned to town last night, determined to make amends at the expense of the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at Madison Square Garden.

A first novel by Cardinal Spellman, "The Foundling," has been scheduled for April publication by Scribners. It is a story about a Protestant, a veteran of World War I, and of his interest in a child he finds abandoned in a cathedral. The child, brought up in the Roman Catholic faith, grows up to fight in World War II. The story now is running in Good Housekeeping.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--In an effort to lighten its work load during the final days of the present Congress, the House of Representatives sent the $3,100,000,000 civil defense bill to conference today for adjustments of differences with the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- The Air Force is gearing its emergency mobilization program to a strength four times as powerful as that on hand before the Korean war began.

Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. B. Pardee of New York and Lauderdale, Lawrence, L. I., gave a reception yesterday afternoon in their home here at 770 Park Avenue for Miss Nancy Van Wicklen Proseus and their son, Hobart Porter Pardee, whose engagement has been announced.

John Morrell Co., pork and beef packer, increased its net profit in the fiscal year ended Oct. 28 to $860,899 from $84,065 earned in the previous fiscal year. The earnings are equal to $l.08 and 10 cents a share on 800,000 capital shares, for the respective years.

It is now a virtual certainty that before the Lame Duck session of the Eighty-first Congress expires on Jan. 2 it will have carried out the "mandate" voted in the dying hours of the regular session and placed an excess profits tax on the statute books. Congress will thus have enacted two emergency revenue bills within approximately six months of the outbreak of the fighting in Korea.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that it had granted $1,509,990 in March of Dimes funds for research and professional education in universities and research centers in sixteen states and Canada. The grants numbered thirty-two.

The possibility that the ban imposed on showings of the Italian film, "The Miracle," by License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey may be lifted or modified today was held likely yesterday in city administration circles.

The blockfront business property on the southerly side of East Fordham Road between Third and Washington Avenues in the Bronx has been purchased by Charles D. Loventhal, operator, from the Ordham Realty Corporation, of which Vera Bloom is president. The property, a holding of the late Congressman Sol Bloom, had been...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--A Senate investigating committee has until Jan. 31 to finish an inquiry into recent food price increases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will limit marketings of sugar in the United States to 8,000,000 tons in 1951.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Election of a successor to Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago is expected to be a complicated process, likely to take many months if someone outside the university is selected. The university's unusual educational setup, especially at the undergraduate level, erects a special hurdle.

Even in a colorless performance it is easy to see that "A House in Berlin" is a perceptive play. Translated from the German of Max Frisch, it was put on at Mr. Piscator's Dramatic Workshop last evening, under Brett Warren's direction. It probes ruthlessly into the subject of German war guilt and is said to have aroused the populace when it was first acted in Berlin last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Between the hangover of Korea and the hangover of Christmas, this town was in a distinctly funereal mood today, but despite all the gloom the state of our international affairs is in some ways much better than it was three weeks ago.

The outlook dimmed yesterday for general action by metal, equipment and other heavy industries to follow General Motors Corporation's pattern in rolling back prices to Dec. 1 levels and in rebating the difference between Dec. 1 and advanced price levels. Purchasing executives in big companies sought counsel on their right to ask for such rebates and were told they had no basis for making such requests.

Drug store string, tassels, burlap and metal screening are some of the materials employed by Mariska Karasz in her "pictures," which are now on view at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition will continue through Jan. 13 and will be open weekdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 26--The House committee investigating lobbying activities advised Congress today to be "wary" of any figures which the Conference of American Small Business Organizations offers as a measure of small-business opinion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission today denied a rehearing on a commission order authorizing construction of natural gas facilities for New England and other areas. The rehearing was asked by coal and railroad interests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP)--A Greek farmer who knew the Italians weren't planting potatoes saved a Marshall Plan project from going up in powder last week.

With the biggest fields in the eight-year history of the tournament, competition in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's junior and boys' indoor championships began yesterday at the Third Lngineer Group Armory. More than fifty matches were played in a session that lasted from mid-morning to late at night.

Chess players representing City College and competing in defense of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy made a good start yesterday in the annual tournament for the team championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League by defeating the University of Miami, 3--1.
A new mechanical device for producing seventeen-inch color television pictures, larger than have been shown previously, was demonstrated here yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 26 (Reuters)--The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, liberal newspaper, has criticized Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, newly appointed Supreme Commander of the Atlantic forces, as "anti-German."

The slump in television receiver sales which began late last month is definitely past and sales again are mounting to satisfactory levels, retailers and distributors declared yesterday. They said last week's boom at retail was the beginning of a new sales spurt at all trade levels.
NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 26--The Rev. Dr. Vincent Ravi Booth, one of the founders of Bennington College in Vermont, died here today at the age of 71.
