ALBANY, Dec. 26--Governor Dewey, in his annual message to the Legislature on Jan. 3, will express hope of balancing the 1951-52 state budget without increasing taxes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26----Thirtytwo prominent Americans announced today the formation of a National Committee to repeal the McCarran (anti-subversives) Act. They included two Nobel Prize winners, six bishops and numerous leading educators and scientists.

The year-old taxpayer at the northeast corner of 147th Street and Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, containing nine stores, has been sold by Max Low, operator, to an investing client of Emanuel Wolfe, attorney. Brener Lewis, Inc., was the broker and Irving Lester Levitt was attorney for the seller.
Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were received yesterday from 288 persons, including a retired vice admiral of the Navy, a resident in Mexico and one in Switzerland.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kurt Beckers of 1115 Fifth Avenue gave a tea dance yesterday afternoon in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 130 East Eightieth Street, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Annabel Beckers.

Unit sales of electrical appliances will total 53,700,000 this year, H.L. Andrews, vice president in charge of the appliance and merchandising division of the General Electric Company, predicted yesterday. This is 12,000,000 more than production schedules called for at the beginning of the year, he said.

Arturo Toscanini will return to his post as conductor of the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra on Jan. 27. For this concert and the next five broadcasts the orchestra will be shifted from its present Monday evening time to late Saturday afternoon, and the concerts will come from Carnegie Hall.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26-- Far-reaching changes to streamline the top levels of the Indian Government were announced by President Rajendra Prasad today.

Following the successful amphibious movement of 105,000 men and their equipment from Hungnam to a juncture with the main army, all the United Nations forces are now redeployed for battle in the "new war" which Chinese Communist aggression has forced upon them. This is the significant fact that emerges from the Korean news.

Ancient civilizations and primitive lands of today provide inspiration for fabric designers. For some drapery fabrics, designers have drawn from the Peruvian and Mayan ruins, the American Indians and the South Sea Islands. The geometric motifs appear in keeping with the straight, clean design prevalent in present decorating.

The Korean battle is not over. The transfer of the troops evacuated from Hungnam to a concentration area in the south and the unification of all the fighting forces under one field Commander is the best evidence that there is no intention of abandoning the struggle. Trygve Lie repeated in Oslo a day or two ago what the Prime Minister
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Korean Government officials estimated today more than half of this capital's civilian population had been evacuated southward.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Civil Defense Administration, in a handbook issued today, estimated that it would take more than 17,000 first-aid workers, organized into 180 stations, to care for the casualties resulting from an atomic bombing attack on an average city.

BERLIN, Dec. 27--Almost six months after they vanished on the Autobahn between West Berlin and Helmstedt, Heinz Tochtermann and Siegfried Rogge, German photographers employed by Pathe News, were sentenced last Thursday to three and four years of

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Breaking a tight game wide open in the second half, Michigan's basketball team defeated Pennsylvania, 58--51, tonight before 3,500 in the Palestra. After the score had been tied nine times the Wolverines pulled out to a 32-26 half-time lead.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Hopalong Cassidy was unable to find a boat to ride the waves of the Atlantic this Christmas, and his trip to German youth centers had to be put off until Easter.

CAIRO, Dec. 27--A new threat to the West's military position in the Near East appeared today when Gen. Nuri as-Said, Iraqi Premier, brought the demand for a change in the treaty with Britain into the Iraqi Parliament.

Saks-34th Street catered to the junior-size miss at a showing of spring and cruise wear yesterday afternoon at the store. The selections included casual sportswear as well as formal attire in the latest spring colors and fabrics.

A year-end rally, unmatched in extent in more than four years, was staged yesterday by the stock market. In a complete reversal of Tuesday's performance, quotations were bid up 1 to 5 points, although the volume failed to increase materially. Cash sales to establish tax gains or losses within the calendar year were numerous.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 27--Dr. Earle G. Brown, Nassau County Health Commissioner, declaring that the county had the lowest average infant mortality rate in New York State, said here today that an intensified program on care of premature babies has been designed to effect a further reduction.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP)--Henry A. Wallace said today that the United States needed a friendly China desperately because "Russia and China in complete accord can eventually dominate the World."

ALBANY, Dec. 27--Governor Dewey will ask the 1951 Legislature to pass an emergency act conferring broad administrative and legislative powers on a new State Defense Council patterned after the State War Council that went out of existence in 1946.

LONDON, Dec. 27--The search for the Stone of Scone, stolen from Westminster Abbey on Christmas morning by persons believed to be Scottish nationalists, broadened today into one of the nation's biggest hunts but failed to produce a tangible clue to the coronation stone's whereabouts.

While City Hall was silent yesterday in the controversy over the ban on public showings of "The Miracle," the New York Film Critics protested and the picture's distributor announced that legal action would be taken against the city.

Retaining walls are being poured for the new Nassau store of Abraham Straus in Hempstead, L.I. Foundations are half finished on the two-story and basement building which will contain 225,000 square feet of floor space, to be ready for business in the spring of 1952. The cost is about $2,500,000,

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27-- Union leaders agreed late today to ask workers to return to their jobs at the Todd shipyards at Alameda, on the east side of San Francisco Bay, to enable the resumption of repairs on Navy ships.

Lumber production this year probably will total 36,300,000,000 board feet, Richard Colgan, executive vice president of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, predicted yesterday. He emphasized that the figure was unofficial and added it represented a drop of 1,700,000,000 board feet from industry production expectations at the beginning of 1950.

Price analysts serving industrial corporations warned management executives here yesterday that, continuing price rises are providing clear evidence that the Government's price freeze program will not work.

Going into the lead only 35 seconds after the start of play, the Deerfield Academy hockey team of Deerfield, Mass., blanked the St. Mark's School sextet of Southborough, Mass., at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 8 to 0. A small but enthusiastic gathering saw the battle, which was the second annual clash locally between the sextets.
The announcement by the Department of Agriculture late Tuesday of the 1951 sugar marketing quota of 8,000,000 tons brought only a mild reaction in the sugar futures market on the New YorK

There remains little prospect for action by the "lame duck" Congress to relieve unusual congestion in customs clearance of the heavy volume of imports now entering this country, foreign trade officials reported yesterday.

Wiretaps made by plainclothes men attached to Brooklyn divisions were used by members of the Police Department as a "club to blackmail and shake down bookmakers," it was charged yesterday in Kings County Court.

Rehabilitation of the North Korean Forces: During the past six weeks many reports have stated that the North Korean Army is undergoing an extensive training and expansion program in North Korea and in Manchuria.

Down in the snow-blanketed slopes of New York's parks sped the small fry on their shiny red sleds (new and old) from morning until dusk yesterday. Faces were redhued from the cold, but the laughter and cheers were long and loud.
A former refugee from nazism sent his second gift this year to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, this time to honor a German educator killed as a result of the anti-Hitler plot in 1944.
The practice of starting weekday afternoon ball games at 1:30 o'clock, so far as it concerns the Polo Grounds, is here to stay.
The three-story taxpayer at 288 Jackson Avenue in Jersey City, N.J., tenanted by a unit of the Singer Sewing Machine Company. has been sold by William and Anna

Recreational skiers in the metropolitan area will find plenty of opportunities to do their "swinging" and "turning" during the holidays, with most of the sport available close to home. The recent snowstorm once again left a blanket in the Pennsylvania Poconos, metropolitan New Jersey and New York, the Hudson Highlands, the Catskills and Adirondacks of upper New York State.

Walter E. Borden has been appointed senior vice president and general manager of the National Shawmut Bank, it was announced yesterday. He will serve as chief executive officer of the bank under Walter S. Bucklin, president.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP)--Col. Bolick Saholsky, Cleveland Ordnance District chief, announced today that about $78,000,000 worth of defense contracts had been awarded to Ohio manufacturers. Biggest order was for $63,000,000 worth of jeeps from Willys-Overland motors at Toledo. Other orders announced:

Prices of United States Government securities firmed up somewhat in the dealers market yesterday, with all of the longer-term issues showing fractional rises except the bank-eligible 2 s of 19721967 and the partially tax-exempt

The new luxury liner Independ ence, one of the largest United States merchant ships afloat and expected to be the nation's fastest, will be delivered to her owners, the American Export Lines, on Jan. 17. The transfer will take place at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard at Quincy, Mass., where she was built.

Distillers are determined to hold the price line on whisky with no fear of immediate shortages and with confidence they can supply both Government and civilian demand, up to the time of, all-out mobilization.

A manufacturer of curtains and draperies has purchased for part occupancy the twelvestory building on plot 108 by 113 by 101 feet at 137 Fifth Avenue from the 137 Fifth Avenue Company in a deal negotiated by Williams Co.,

The "Dean," Judge George L. Donnellan of the Court of General Sessions, stepped down yesterday from the bench after twenty-three years. With him, also retiring because, of the constitutional age limit of 70 years, went his lifelong friend and colleague for seventeen years in the same court, Judge Owen W. Bohan.
At the start of a new year the President of the United States reveals to the people, in his "State of the Union" message, what direction his thoughts and purposes are taking.

With the third round of play in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's eighth anual junior indoor championship at the Third Engineer Group Armory one match short of completion, all but one of the ten seeded entrants remained in contention yesterday.

A peanut seller, who six years ago moved into the more lucrative business of putting up bail in prostitution cases--a pursuit that enabled him to turn a $15,000 to $20,000 yearly profit--was sought yesterday in a thirteen-state police alarm.

Columbia's players, defeating Temple by 31 - in the third round last night, took the lead with 8 points in the annual tournament for the team championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League. The matches are being played in John Jay Hall, on the Columbia University campus.

It is important that no time be lost in rounding out, the general policy that began with the Defense Revenue Act of 1950 and was expanded in the bill for a corporate excess-profits tax now pending. A wartime tax program

The application of the Bulova Watch Company, Inc., to build a $3,000,000 watch assembly plant in a twenty-four-acre site in Jackson Heights, Queens, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. Jackson Heights is largely zoned for residence use.

The international crisis which has imposed on the Western nations a rearmament race that is inflating their defense budgets and beginning to strain their economies has also confronted them with another problem that must be solved to make their present efforts a success.
Two thousand persons attended Communist party rallies last night in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. The gatherings were preludes to a secret party convention scheduled to open here today.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Mutterings of dissatisfaction over last week's agreement in the rail dispute arose today from union strongholds.
The advertising and merchandising budget of the Hickok Manufacturing Company, Rochester, was set yesterday at $1,000,000 for what was described as its

BETHPAGE, L. I., Dec. 27-- Four young campers from Brooklyn willingly cut short their planned four-day stay here today, but their retreat was not without honor. For boys so young they had absorbed a rugged amount of bitter weather.

Although Jimmy Flood knocked out Artie Diamond, whirlwind slugger from the East Side, in the eighth of their scheduled ten-round fight at St. Nicholas Arena last night, the Yorkville middleweight never again is likely to draw so near defeat and escape.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, en route to Washington and Europe to take command of Western European defense forces, reiterated today that "the United States is capable of doing any chore necessary."
LONDON, Dec. 27--The stock markets here drifted downward today while the holiday atmosphere still prevailed. The tone was set by British Government securities,
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--President Truman will make known his views on a much broader and expanded tax program "at the appropriate time," Joseph Short, Presidential press secretary, said today.
A possible downward adjustment of gas rates for 160,000 consumers in Westchester County was indicated yesterday at hearings before the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--President Truman announced today his appointment of Stanton Griffis as Ambassador to Spain, thus ending a lapse of five years in which this country has not had ambassadorial representation in Madrid.

Long Island University will risk its six-game winning streak tonight against Western Kentucky after City College tangles with the University of Arizona at 7:45 o'clock in the collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

The United States Marine Hospital on Ellis Island, which has been in operation since 1892, will be closed on March 1 by the United States Public Health Service, and no new patients will be admitted after New Year's Day.

ALBANY, Dec. 27--Manpower demands of the expanding armed forces will make urgent an extension of New York's new system of two-year community colleges in 1951, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University, said today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 27--The Dutch-Indonesian conference on the future of Western New Guinea broke up today without agreement after twentythree days of negotiation. But the door was left open for possible United Nations intercession.

SAUGERTIES, N.Y., Dec. 27 (Ap)--Chief of Police A.W. Richter said today state police were checking a report that the description of a missing Saugerties woman fitted that of a dismembered body found in two suitcases Dec. 4 in Brooklyn. State police, however, declined to talk, and Brooklyn police would say only that they had a promising lead.

THE Stanford basketball team appeared in Madison Square Garden the other night for the first time in thirteen years. To most folks the visit of the Indians from Palo Alto was merely another game in the gala holiday series of double-headers. Perhaps it was.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sigmund Stralem of 941 Park Avenue gave a supper dance last night in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria to introduce their daughter, Miss Sandra Jean Stralem. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a bouffant gown of white nylon tulle made with a matching stole and overskirt. She carried a bouquet of pale pink camellias with pink velvet streamers.
Max Beckmann, internationallyknown artist, died yesterday of a heart attack near his home, 38 West Sixty-ninth Street. His age was 66.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Dec. 27--Fast-climbing, high-altitude, radar-loaded Lockheed F-94 jet interceptor planes capable of flying day or night in all kinds of weather are now guarding New York City and the industrial East on a twenty-four hour stand-by alert, the Continental Air Command disclosed here today.

Clusters of silver Christmas bells and southern smilax provided a holiday decor for the second Junior Assembly for this season held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. It was the first time that the Junior Assemblies, which have had their setting for many years at the Ritz-Carlton, had been held at the Plaza, their future home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The 1950 buying habits of 17,000 families in ninety-one cities will be put under the microscope by the Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics in the next fortnight to decide to what extent the consumers' price index should be brought up to date.

Dr. Henri Emile Enthoven, lecturer, pianist, composer and former Professor of History at universities in the Netherlands, died here of a heart attack Tuesday night at his home, 320 East Fiftyseventh Street. He was 47 years old.

Arthur Miller's adaptation of "An Enemy of the People," by Henrik Ibsen, opens this evening at the Broadhurst Theatre. Fredric March and Florence Eldridge are co-starred in the roles of Dr. Stockmann and Mrs. Stockmann. The curtain is announced to rise at 8 P.M.

Although Bernard Shaw has now left us for a more agreeable neighborhood, his spirit is still mischievous and witty. The spirit is currently visible in "Captain Brassbound's Conversion," which opened the City Center's winter series auspiciously last evening. This is the amusing comedy that Shaw wrote for Ellen Terry out of affection, admiration and wonder in 1899.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser to Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, will defend the correctness of this country's foreign policy in a major speech Friday night in New York.
All of the New York Film Critics awards for outstanding cinematic achievement during 1950 went yesterday to Twentieth Century-Fox Films, Inc. In a series of coincidences unparalleled in the

In a bruising battle that bore a semblance to hockey of a sturdier era, the Rangers conquered the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Carrying the play to their league-leading foes all the way, the Blue Shirts outscored Joe Primeau's sextet by the score of 3--1.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27--Pravda characterized today the decisions of the North Atlantic conference at Brussels as a "serious menace to the cause of peace" and Izvestia declared that in the present critical times the efforts against warmongers "must be doubled and tripled."

The marriage of Miss Joan Weidberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Weidberg of West Atlantic City, N.J., and Miami Beach, Fla., to Eli Timoner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Timoner of Woodmere, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the sale of the Don Lee broadcasting properties in California for $12,320,000.
HONG KONG, Dec. 27--The official New China News Agency announced today in a dispatch from Peiping that Red China's Central Government Council had adopted a new national budget for 1951.

Price controls, quotas and allocations in foreign trade are inevitable, it is agreed by executives contributing to the annual symposium on the outlook for the new year conducted by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. Details of the symposium were made public yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has not yet entered the current debate on the Truman Doctrine and the Hoover Doctrine, but the new supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces has stated, in the past, various opinions that bear directly on the military issues now under public discussion.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 27--A special meeting of the Asian and Arab delegations to the United Nations has been called for 5 P.M. tomorrow to consider possible lines of action in view of the Chinese Communist rejection of the General Assembly's plan for a cease-fire in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce announced tonight that it had permanently banned a New York exporter, Carl Lohman Janik, from getting export licenses.
The nation's first complete rehabilitation program for crippled youngsters is to be established at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

The sixty-fifth annual convention of the Modern Language Association of America opened yesterday at the Statler Hotel, with 4,000 college and university teachers attending. The conference, which is devoted largely to the presentation and discussion of research papers, will close on Friday.
The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and its two major domestic affiliates announced yesterday a plan to protect itself, its employes and their families against sabotage.

The shy young heroine of one of the strangest happy-ending stories of World War II arrived here yesterday for her first visit. Six days after taking off from Singapore, Patsy Li, who is 15 years old now, landed at La Guardia Airport on her way to school in Virginia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Senate investigators said today they were looking into charges of political intrigue in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The following from one of those principally responsible for the atom bomb, proximity fuse and other United States weapons which created a favorable balance against the Germans and Japanese in the Second World War summarizes an opinion which probably is held very widely in this country:

G.P. Putnam's Sons, publisher, have leased the third floor and about half of the second floor and 210 Madison Avenue. The lease was negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, with the Cross Brown Company repre senting the lessee.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27--At a time when President Truman's choice of an Ambassador to Argentina is expected at any moment, La Nacion, in its leading editorial today, says diplomats who are only

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--In St. Margaret's Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Jean Elizabeth Benton, daughter of Mrs. John E. Benton of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mr. Benton, was married to Willard Mills
Shortages of essential materials threaten to delay announcement of the 1951 Plymouth line, R.C. Somerville, general sales manager of the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 --Albert W. Pross, senior partner in the law firm of Pross, Smith, Halpern Lefevre, 342 Madison Avenue, New York, specialists in estate, real estate and tax law, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Pross, who was 71 years old, resided at 20 Claremont Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.
The efforts of freight forwarders to obtain brokerage fees in the movement of Government aid cargoes and similar shipments are futile and should be dropped, Federal shipping officials said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Coast Guard issued today security regulations aimed at weeding out subversives among mairitime workers. The regulations are effective immediately.

MADRID, Dec. 27--Anonymous propaganda here--apparently Communist--has begun circulating letters suggesting that the United States is following an imperialist policy. Though unlikely to have any great effect, these allegations may indicate a new Soviet decision to be more active in Spain.

ROME, Dec. 27--A war against the Government's rearmament program was announced today by Communist Deputy Giuseppe di Vittorio on behalf of the Italian General Confederation of Labor, of which he is secretary general.

TWO excellent novels by the sporadically mysterious Henry Green, an Englishman who lives near Lancaster but favors the rose of York, are published here today. They are "Concluding," a subtle parody of the world of tomorrow, and "Caught," an ironic satire on the world

The Quartermaster Corps is handling its wool textile program in a manner that will offer little interference to civilian trade, it was re-- ported here yesterday. Invitations have been issued in the last two days for a total of 17,200,000 yards, 55 per cent of the "immediate" requirements set down by the Department of the Army two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Senate and House conferees were reported tonight to be nearing agreement on legislation to prevent communities or promoters from "boondoggling" in the $3,100,000,000 civil defense program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The State Department announced today the signing of an agreement with the Government of India for the extension of technical assistance under the Point Four program outlined by President Truman two years ago. Several United States technicians are already at work in India.

The divorced wife of William W. Remington, continuing her testimony yesterday at his perjury trial in Federal Court, forged another link in the chain the Government contends ties him to membership in the Communist party.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 27 (AP)--Art Bragg of Morgan State, Amateur Athletic Union sprint champion of the United States, and Mal Whitfield, former Ohio State runner who won the 800-meter Olympic crown in 1948, were defeated today in the opening races of the Canterbury Centennial Games at Christchurch.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27--A new world of living matter, revealed for the first time by the electron microscope, was shown here tonight in an illustrated lecture before the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Ralph W.G. Wyckoff of the National Institute of Health of the United States Public Health Service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The National Production Authority today banned the use of cadmium for products classified as nonessential, an action that may ultimately result in lower-quality hardware, washing machines, gardening tools and the like.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Department of Defense today established new procedures for the call of doctors and dentists into the armed services.

In case you have nothing to do these holiday times you might like to try bird counting. A lot of people are going to, and that does not mean counting the weird birds that show up at holiday cocktail parties.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 28--The Chinese and North Korean Communists have built up a force of nearly 450,000 men in Korea, with a total of 1,350,000 either on the peninsula, aligned along the Manchurian border at the Yalu River, or en route, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters said yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP)--Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Poland, all under Kremlin pressure to increase industrial output, said today that they had done so in 1950.
Theodoe W. Kheel, impatial chairman of the private transit industry, intervened yesterday in an effort to head off a New Year's Eve strike on the city's principal private bus lines.
The first issue of The Protestant World, a new periodical that will be published temporarily as a monthly and later come out as a weekly, is in the mails under a January, 1951, date line.

With bookings now running 47 per cent ahead of last year, some form of allocation of home furnishing fabrics to retail outlets early in 1951 appears inevitable. This was stated yesterday by Jack G. Graham, sales manager of the Waverly Fabrics division of F. Schumacher Co. "Waverly is selling some classifications now at a higher rate than receipt of gray goods," Mr. Graham said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Politically tinged shake-ups of the Detroit, Denver and Boston offices of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and a retiring R.F.C. official's blast at the "stench of cheap politics" today spiced a simmering Senate investigation of the lending agency.
The American Legion is appealing to the fortunate children in America to send toys to others less fortunate-- the children of Western Europe and Puerto Rico, the children here at home

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had ordered "immediate construction" of its long-considered East Coast steel mill on a site near Morrisville, Pa., because of the "increasing seriousness of the international situation."
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 21--A disconsolate major stood helplessly in the C.O.'s office. He had traveled many miles that morning with a carload of witnesses to preside over a court-martial.
Virtually the entire eastern half of the United States, including the sunny South, was in deep-freeze yesterday.

Because of the flimsy evidence produced by the United States Attorney's office, the charge against one of the four Puerto Rican Nationalists of conspiracy to assassinate President Truman was dismissed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Proposed excess-profits taxation would create a barrier to the establishment of new businesses and to the expansion of established businesses through outside financing, leading economists were warned here today.
Two six-story buildings on Midwood Street in Brooklyn, to contain a total of 288 apartments, were among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following princpial changes for the week ended Dec. 20:

Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, and Mrs. Evelyn Wagner Steinreich of 365 Park Avenue, were sworn in yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., as chairman and co-chairman, respectively, of volunteer civil defense activity in Manhattan.
J. Zachary Stein has been elected vice president and Miss Harriet M. Bensley has been elected secrtary and a director of J. Clarence Davies, Inc. Both have been with the company for many years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Harvey L. Carey, United States Attorney for the Western District of Louisiana Since August, was suspended by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today, pending an investigation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP)--Joe Culmone, who began the day with a lead of two victories over Willie Shoemaker for the 1950 national jockey title, booted home three winners among his seven mounts today at Tropical Park.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 27--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared today that Western Allied negotiations with the Bonn Government on possible West German remilitarization were being treated as a matter of "urgency," without regard to prospective Big Four talks that might deal with German demilitarization among other subjects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Thirty-two defense plant expansion projects, including the United States Steel Corporation's new mill at Morrisville, Pa., today received certificates of necessity, carrying tax benefits, from the National Security Resources Board. The total value of the tax amortization clearances exceed $544,000,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--The grain markets opened fairly active and higher today, with all deliveries of corn and rye and the deferred deliveries of wheat and soybeans at new high prices for the year. Liberal profit-taking developed, however, and a reaction followed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Economic Stabilization Agency reiterated in unmistakable terms today its intention to issue mandatory price control orders, if necessary, in cases where voluntary standards set on Dec. 19 are not observed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 Lionel Barrymore's next picture at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will be "The Man With a Cloak," a murder mystery scheduled to go before the cameras in February, with Stephen Ames as the producer. The actor's last film, "Right Cross," was made nearly a year ago.
The following city officials, whose appointments had been previously announced, were sworn in yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at ceremonies in the City Council chamber at City Hall:

PARIS, Dec. 27--Jules Moch, Minister of Defense, told the National Assembly today in a debate on the French rearmament program that the surest way to make the proposed four-power talks a success was to vote for that program and show that France was determined to rearm.

A two-story factory building and adjacent gasoline and service station at 164-66 Bruckner Boulevard, southeast corner of East 133d Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Magnetic Realty Corporation to the Flaherty Holding Corporation. J.P. McCann was the broker in the sale of the property, which is 137 by 125 feet.

PARIS, Dec. 27--The United States Army announced here today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would establish his temporary headquarters in the Astoria Hotel in Paris when he arrived here shortly after the first of the year to assume command of the North Atlantic pact forces.

THOSE hardy souls which never get enough fishing and have been watching the thermometer drop with high glee can unearth the tip-ups and begin chopping holes in the ice on such waters as may be reasonably barren of trout.

Loyalty questionnaires prepared by the Columbia Broadcasting System for its employes were condemned yesterday by the council of the Authors League. In a fivepoint statement signed by its president, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the C.B.S. form was termed both "improper" and impractical.

The group of twelve Asian and Arab states that is trying to find a basis for negotiation with the Chinese Communists and that may urge some such basis upon the United States is moving on treacherous ground. There can be no doubt that the motives of the men in this group are the highest.
After-Christmas contributions continued yesterday to swell the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's thirty-ninth annual appeal, which reached $248,912.48 as 403 gifts added $9,791.31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) An application by the Lone Star Steel Company for an $83,000,000 loan to expand its Daingerfield, Texas, plant is under consideration by two Government agencies. Officials told a reporter today final action is unlikely this week, but they indicated a decision may come soon.

ALBANY, Dec. 28--The new Legislature will get a request from Governor Dewey to extend the provisions of the Emergency Housing Act for the benefit of war veterans, and to insure that rent control will be continued in the state after March 1, when present ceilings expire.

Problems concerned with the defense of New York City in the event of war were among the most pressing matters that confronted the city's two newest commissioners yesterday as they spent their first full day in office.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 29 The Chinese Communists are massing six army corps with a total of nineteen divisions that, it is believed, will be in position to launch a coordinated attack against the United States Eighth Army in Korea by Jan. 1, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.

PARIS, Dec. 28 The belief here that the United States favors control of raw-material supplies by a committee representing the United States, Britain and France has left obscure the position of the European Marshall Plan Council, which aspired to be the medium for such control.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 22 For more than a year the rearmament of Western Germany has been debated with such fervor that it has come to represent a sort of philosopher's stone solving all problems of European defense and readjusting the terrible imbalance of Soviet and Western forces.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 Synthesis of a hormone of the adrenal gland, Compound F, the only known substance with activity comparable to cortisone and ACTH, was announced here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by four research chemists of Merck Co., Rahway, N.J.

Kenneth Carter of Plainfield, N.J., accounted for the most impressive performance yesterday as the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's eight annual junior indoor championship moved into the quarter-final round at the Third Engineer Group Armory.
LONDON, Dec. 28 A murmurous undertone of resentment against United States leadership in world affairs could still be heard in Britain today.
ALBANY, Dec. 28--Governor Dewey plans to tell the 1951 Legislature that the salaries of New York's 74,000 public school teachers must be raised to meet increased living costs.

MANILA, Dec. 28 The second major shake-up and reorganization of the Philippine armed forces within a year was announced today by President Elpidio Quirino with the removal of Brig. Gen. Alberto Ramos as head of the Philippine Constabulary and relegation of that branch of the military service to a minor position, largely shorn of personnel and responsibility.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) Joe Culmone, sensational Sicilian rider, stayed in front of Willie Shoemaker today in their race for 1950 national honors.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 28 The Communists' sabotage in Singapore, where they are showing increasing strength, includes setting fire to motor vehicles. Public transport is a special target and hardly a day passes in this teeming southeast Asian crossroads without the burning of a taxi or a bus.

The city government is encountering more and more difficulty in finding educated men "who have guts" to assume the responsibility of enlisting public support for what are often "drastic" solutions to municipal problems, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28--"The Racket," Bartlett Cormack's 1927 crime melodrama, in which Willard Robertson, Hugh O'Connell and John Cromwell appeared on Broadway, will be filmed next month by Edmund Granger for R. K. O. release, the producer announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 Warren Wright, sportsman and head of the Calumet Baking Powder Company of Chicago, died tonight in his home here. He was 75 years old.

Moore-McCormack Lines announced yesterday a 50 per cent curtailment of its services to Rio de Janeiro to help alleviate severe cargo congestion in the Brazilian port and also to afford proper service to the more southern ports of Santos, Montevideo and Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The American Chemical Society recommended today that this country, if forced into an all-out war effort, adopt total mobilization of its scientific and technical manpower between the ages of 18 and 65.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 No sign visible to this department suggests that any attempt will be made on Jan. 3, 1951, to organize the Eighty-second Congress on other than the usual party lines. An idea of trying to form a bipartisan coalition which would choose the officers and chairmen in each...

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 28 (AP) Colgate roared back from an early 15-2 deficit to upset Duke, 84 69, tonight in the final game of the opening round in the second annual Dixie basketball classic before 10,000 fans.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Dec. 28 Mrs. Isabelle Dwight SpragueSmith, founder and executive director of the Bach Festival at Winter Park, and formerly principal of a girls' school in New York, died here yesterday, after a brief illness, at the age of 89.
The programs that American radio stations generally send into the nation's living rooms were attacked and defended yesterday at the Mid-Century Conference of the Speech Association of America.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 28 Confronted with possible collapse of their peace-making efforts in the Far East, the twelve members of the Asian-Arab group in the United Nations met today to consider their next move.
With subzero temperatures prevailing for two nights in the Hudson River Valley, the Coast Guard reported yesterday several calls to assist icebound craft.

Greece takes vigorous exception to the Hoover arguments for writing off Europe as a defense area against Soviet aggression. In reply to the statement that fewer than twenty combat divisions are now available in the western half of the Continent and that the will of the non-Communist peoples...

The signing of an agreement between the United States and India for American technical assistance under President Truman's Point Four program again calls attention to the fact that the free nations are opposing Communist tyranny not only on the military and propaganda fronts but also on a...
Birger Nordkvist, apple picker for a Western New York State cider firm, was held without bail in Felony Court here yesterday for hearing Jan. 15 on a homicide charge.

Loans to business by New York banks dipped slightly last week, registering the second decline in thirty weeks. The reduction of $24,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday was the first to be recorded since Oct. 18.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the resignation of Deputy City Treasurer Arthur A. Lynch, effective at midnight Sunday. Letters made public by the Mayor disclosed that Mr. Lynch had submitted his resignation on Dec. 5 and that it was accepted yesterday after the Mayor had failed to persuade him to "stay in office for at least a short time longer."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The Federal Government took over the importation and distribution of natural rubber today in one of three important and far-reaching moves related to the defense program and control of inflation.

Thirteen young women are holding open house in the model apartment they furnished in the New York Housing Authority's Lexington Houses as a part of their course in the Department of Home Economics at Hunter College.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to the city yesterday with a plea for unity among Americans, confident that such unity would insure the successful defense of Western Europe.

Although L.I.U. sagged toward the finish, the early lead built up by Clair Bee's Blackbirds proved sufficient to keep them among the nation's undefeated quintets as they staggered to a 77-70 victory over Western Kentucky last night at Madison Square Garden. The biggest midweek turnout of the campaign, 18,026, saw Long Island register its seventh straight.

A slight rise in temperatures eased the cold spell in New York yesterday and Weather Bureau charts indicated that the warmer weather would continue through today. A light snow was falling early this morning, but it was due to turn to rain, ending tonight. Afternoon temperatures are expected to be in the mid thirties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Army Medical Corps spokesmen expressed today complete confidence in the efficacy of a post-war substitute for morphine, the chief battlefield painkiller for the wounded. They told of Army acceptance of the synthetic drug following field tests on the Hamhung-Hungnam beachhead in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 President Truman announced today that he will deliver his State of the Union message in person to the incoming Eighty-second Congress on Jan. 8 if he can get it ready by then.
City officials succeeded early today in hammering out a bus wage agreement that was expected to head off a threatened New Year's Eve strike on lines that normally carry 3,000,000 riders a day.

MARSHALL, Tex., Dec. 28--Myron G. Blalock, one-time Democratic National Committeeman from Texas, who was credited with helping to rally Texas support behind Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, died at his home here early this morning of a heart attack. His age was 59.

A debut 'cello recital was played last night in Town Hall by Richard Kay, whose serious approach was reflected in his program, which consisted of a Frescobaldi Toccata, Bach's unaccompanied Suite No. 3, Boccherini's Concerto in B flat, Schubert's "Arpeggione" Sonata, the Debussy Sonata and shorter pieces by Faure, Hure and Popper.
SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Dec. 28 Living under conditions admittedly far superior to any they had known before, more than 120,000 North Korean prisoners are occupying five tented compounds.

The stock market put on a highpowered rally yesterday in the final hour after encountering cross currents the greater part of the session. The late spurt sent the list to the highest levels in twenty years, to the accompaniment of heavy dealings. Cash sales to establish tax gains or losses for 1950 were overbalanced by a renewal of year-end reinvestment demand.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 Prof. Henry De Wolf Smyth, scientistmember of the Atomic Energy Commission, proposed here today a program for stockpiling and rationing scientific manpower in the best interest of the country, "just as we would any other essential resource."

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 The American Catholic Sociological Society was warned today that "there is a current suspicion that Protestant-Catholic relationships in the United States are again shifting in the direction of conflict."

The Giants yesterday brought another important member of their cast into the fold for their 1951 pennant bid with the announcement that Alvin Dark had just forwarded his signed contract from his home in Lake Charles, La.
Guerrilla and bandit activity in Communist China and defections from the Communist "Peoples Liberation Army" have increased noticeably if not yet significantly in the last six months.
William W. Remington and his divorced wife, Ann, were "not orthodox Communists" who followed all the rules, Mrs. Remington testified yesterday at his perjury trial in Federal Court.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 28 Civilians are now abandoning the city at the rate of 80,000 a day, the United Nations Civil Assistance Command estimated today. It estimated also that 600,000 from here and 100,000 from farther north are now fleeing south toward safety on foot over snow-covered mountains.

HONG KONG, Dec. 28 The Peiping regime issued a decree today ordering the seizure of all United States property and freezing all United States public and private bank deposits in Red China as an act of retaliation against the "economic sanctions" applied by Washington.
The first positive results of Governmental control rules on nonferrous metal materials essential to defense productoin appeared here yesterday.

Winter, they say, is a time for sitting by the fire in quiet contemplation, a time of enforced and welcome idleness. Anyone who goes around saying such nonsense has never lived in a house where a child or children have...

The Federal Reserve Board's action caused little surprise in financial circles here in view of the rapid expansion in bank loans during recent months. Reports that such action was under consideration, it was pointed out, have been current since the beginning of November.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 General chairmen of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers adjourned a day-long session here today without reaching a decision on whether to accept a proposed contract for settlement of their wage dispute with the railroads.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 28 Machines have accomplished feats of mathematical calculation that man could never hope to complete. The orbits of the five outer planets of the solar system, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto, have been calculated to fourteen places for more than a hundred years in the future, to the year 2060.

GENEVA, Dec. 28 A critical demagraphic problem is developing in Western Europe, according to authorities, and means must be found to facilitate the emigration of between ten and twelve million people if serious social, economic and potential political consequences are to be avoided.

In the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Iola Wise Stetson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene William Stetson of 117 East Seventy-second Street and Beachmound, Greens Farms, Conn., was married to John Mitchell Haverstick of New York, son of Mrs. ...

Sixteen young women were introduced to society at the second annual Christmas Cotillion held last night in the Forest Hills Gardens (Queens) Community House for the benefit of the Brooklyn Home for Children. Mrs. Albert W. Morse headed the committee in charge.

A Christmas tale of travel, tears and laughter ended happily last night in the best Dickens tradition for Rolf Obermaier, the 5-year-old boy who lost his passport on his flight here from Frankfort, Germany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP)--President Truman denied today that he is planning to reshuffle the top management of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to head off criticism from Senate investigators.

Plans for the construction of bomb shelters in existing and proposed subways, for the conversion of present subway facilities for this purpose, and for guarding against flooding of the lines if underwater tunnels were damaged were outlined yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 The Public Service Commission today directed a halt to the practice of submetering electricity, which has provoked thousands of complaints from New York City apartment dwellers over a period of a quarter of a century that some submeterers had gouged them by excessive rates.

IF the sailfish continue to throng the Gulf Stream dur ing the next two weeks as they have since Christmas, the International Light Tackle Sailfish Tournament which opens at Palm Beach on Jan. 9 should be one of the most exciting in the history of that contest.

Miss Edith Lawrence Woodruff, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Woodruff of 1065 Lexington Avenue and Bedford, N.Y., was the guest of honor at a supper dance given jointly last night at the River Club by her parents and her grandmother, Mrs. Edith Lawrence Sullivan of Beverly, Mass.

New York Public Library trustees, other officials, division heads and branch libraries staged a farewell party yesterday for Harry J. Grumpelt and his wife, Adele, who are retiring today after an aggregate of seventysix years of service.
DUBLIN, Dec. 28 (AP) The Irish Government today banned fifteen United States periodicals, including Esquire magazine, on the ground that they had usually or frequently been indecent or obscene.

TOKYO, Dec. 28--The Hungnam beachhead in northeast Korea from which the United Nations troops withdrew Sunday in an epic operation, could have been held indefinitely under a curtain of naval gunfire and bombs from Marine and Navy carrier-based planes, the admirals who commanded the operation said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The United States Government served notice today that it might, if necessary, go ahead with other nations, and without the Soviet Union, to make a peace treaty with Japan.

Public officials and safety leaders throughout the country warned motorists yesterday against reckless driving over the New Year's week-end. They predicted 330 persons would be killed in traffic accidents.
Appointments of five vice presidents for operations and a secretary and general attorney were announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 Dr. Otto Dibelius, Protestant Bishop of Berlin, offered today his home in the Western sector as neutral ground for a conference either of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Premier Otto Grotewohl, or of representatives named by them from the Western and Eastern German states, to discuss unification of the country.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 A designer's idea of the "car of tomorrow" was shown here today as the General Motors Corporation unveiled its so-called "laboratory on wheels"
Two Army recruits ended up yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of felonious assault after a series of barroom brawls.

Members of society who have long taken an active interest in the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service attended the Fete des Artistes, given last night at Bill Rose's Diamond Horseshoe in behalf of the organization. Mrs. William C. Breed and Mrs. Lytle Hull were co-chairmen of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Senate and House conferees reached complete agreement today on legislation to provide a $3,100,000,000 civil defense program headed by an administrator with sweeping powers to carry it out.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The United States and Britain are now reviewing their military strategy in Asia and Europe in the light of recent developments in Korea. Though there is some agitation within the Pentagon to get United States troops out of Korea as soon as possible, the policy for the moment remains the same: namely to stand and fight until the security of the United Nations Command can no loner be assured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) Following is the text of the United States note to Russia barring any Soviet veto over a Japanese peace treaty:
The American Communists boasted yesterday of their close affiliation with the Communist parties in the rest of the world, Russia leading the list.

Papa Ibsen has had a shot in the arm. Taking a literal translation of "An Enemy of the People" as the source material, Arthur Miller has made a new adaptation, which was put on at the Broadhurst last evening. Next to "King Lear," it is the bitterest play in town, and it is also a vast improvement over the lugubrious Archer translation that for years has represented Ibsen to us in English.

Control of Reiss-Premier Corporation and Kaufman Brothers Bondy, Inc., manufacturers and distributors of the "Kaywoodie" and "Yello-Bole" smoking pipes and smokers' articles, has been acquired by Associated Products, Inc.,...

LONDON, Dec. 28 Faced with growing shortages of strategic nonferrous metals, the British Government announced today that, beginning Feb. 1 it would prohibit the use of zinc, copper and copper alloys in manufacture of some 200 nonessential items of civilian goods.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 President Truman asserted today that former President Herbert Hoover was recommending nothing more than isolationism for the United States.
A vast integrated garage construction and parking meter program under the sole direction of the new City Parking Authority has been approved by Mayor Impellitteri.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 28 A decision to transfer the office of the United States High Commissioner, John J. McCloy, from the I.G. Farben Building in this city to a site in Bonn, the West German Federal capital, is expected here in a matter of days.

Rudolf Serkin played the piano solo in Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto with the PhilharmonicSymphony last night in Carnegie Hall. George Szell continued his stint as guest conductor, and introduced to this country Frank Martin's Concerto for Seven Winds, Timpani, Percussion and String Orchestra.

PARIS, Dec. 28 Premier Rene Pleven and the Finance Committee of the National Assembly reached an agreement tonight to insure 140,000,000,000 francs ($400,000,000) of new taxes in 1951 for French rearmament enough to match the sum that the United States is expected to offer France in defense aid.

Despite governmental limitations on copper consumption which start next week, the excessive demand for this metal will continue in 1951, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., predicted here...

OTTO SKORZENY, a 6-foot 3-inch Viennese with a scarred face, is known to the world as the man who rescued Mussolini from imprisonment and as the commando officer whose troops in American uniforms did much to contribute to the confusion behind the American lines during the Battle of the Bulge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The views of labor and management on wage-stabilization policy will be laid before the Wage Stabilization Board on Jan. 10, 11 and 12.

Vegetable prices are at a peak for the year this week-end as a result of the series of frosts in Florida and Texas which have shortened supplies. Besides the actual toll taken by the below-freezing temperatures, the cumulative effect of cold weather has resulted...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 The fight by the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish against removal as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn reached the Supreme Court today.

TODAY at 11:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. the National Youth Theatre's production of "Marco Polo" will be staged at the Master Institute Theatre, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. There will be a matinee tomorrow at 2:30. Tickets range from $1.20 to $2.40.

TAMPA, Dec. 28 Senate Crime Investigating Committee hearings that begin here tomorrow probably will center on how Sicilian mobsters in the last ten years have shoved aside those of Spanish and Cuban ancestry who had dominated the rackets for a generation. The hearings will end Saturday.

The number of new musicals destined for Broadway display in April seems to be growing by leaps and bounds. Just added to that month's collection of hopefuls is "Courtin' Time," which will bring back Lloyd Nolan to the New York stage as a star. It will mark his first local appearance since 1934.

Reporting that the Ground Observers Corps of the state's Aircraft Warning Service was seriously under strength, Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, acting chairman of the State Civil Defense Commission, warned yesterday that a "sneak" attack was a grave possibility.

Southern beaches will yield plenty of news when this year's crop of swim togs appears. In addition to the interesting fabrics, which range from grosgrain and lace to terry cloth and gold-treated materials as well as the familiar cottons, jerseys and elasticized types, designers have conjured up many a trick to add surprise and allure to beach apparel.

Sixteen investors in the Broadway success "Harvey," produced by the late Brock Pemberton, have petitioned Surrogate William T. Collins for an order to compel the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, administrator of the producer's estate, to release $95,735 profits now being held to secure Government tax liens and other estate debts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 During the week ended Dec. 27, member bank reserve balances decreased $242,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., filed demands yesterday for a general wage increase of 15 cents an hour and other benefits for 70,000 workers in the woolen and worsted industry. The program called for additional annual increases of 6 cents an hour, to become effective on Aug. 1, 1951, and Aug. 1, 1952, plus a cost-of-living escalator clause.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 With virtual unanimity, economists and statisticians at annual meetings here today forecast only a slight rise in the physical volume of goods to be turned out in 1951.

TODAY at 11:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. the National Youth Theatre's production of "Marco Polo" will be staged at the Master Institute Theatre, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. There will be a matinee tomorrow at 2:30. Tickets range from $1.20 to $2.40.

TAMPA, Dec. 28 Senate Crime Investigating Committee hearings that begin here tomorrow probably will center on how Sicilian mobsters in the last ten years have shoved aside those of Spanish and Cuban ancestry who had dominated the rackets for a generation. The hearings will end Saturday.
Reservations for public parties on New Year's Eve in New York are generally slow so far, a sampling of representative hotels and night clubs showed yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP) Six colleges in the United States may be subject to suspension by the National Collegiate Athletic Association when it convenes in Dallas, Tex., on Jan. 8.

Dr. Harry Clifton Heaton, chairman of the department of Romance languages at New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home at Tuckahoe, N.Y. His age was 65. He had formerly headed the department at the university's College of Arts and Science.
Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared here yesterday that the shipping industry was in a position now to handle effectively any emergency task assigned to it.
CARMEL, N.Y., Dec. 28 The motorists turned out in force today to enjoy the skiing at Fahnestock Memorial Park. Both tows were kept operating.

The Communist party is now meeting in this city for its annual convention. Its meetings are being held in secrecy. The party has drawn its own little iron curtain around the present proceedings, and this withdrawal from public view is symbolic of the increasing isolation of American communism...

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

The one-story taxpayer containing nine stores at 147-01 Union Turnpike, northeast corner of 147th Street, in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Kessler-Hess, the builder, to Maxwell Low, operator. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $150,000. Citadel Realty was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--A constitutional amendment to end the senate's historic and exclusive right to ratify or reject international treaties was proposed here today by a leading political scientist as a means of improving the nation's conduct of its foreign affairs.

An hour-long flight in an Air Force C-47 transport plane marked a tour of Mitchel Air Force Base on Long Island made yesterday by eighty Reserve Officer Training cadets of New York University and thirty-six Explorer Scouts.

The marriage of Miss Renee Helene Schine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Myer Schine of New York and Gloversville, N.Y., to Lester Crown, son of Col. Henry Crown of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mrs. Rebecca Kranz Crown, took place last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Dr. Charles Schulman performed the ceremony, during which Lauritz Melchior, tenor, sang.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 Marshal Tito disclosed to the Yugoslav Parliament tonight the measures that the Yugoslav Government had taken to counter the growing threat of armed attack in the light of the expansion of the Soviet satellite armies of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria.

Albert J. Haas, Local Rent Administrator for Bronx County of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission, died yesterday in his home, 21 Linden Avenue, Silver Beach Gardens, the Bronx, after an illness of several months. Mr. Haas, who was 54 years old, had an office at 1910 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx.

Verdi's "Il Trovatore," absent from the Metropolitan repertory for a season, returned last night for a very eloquent and exciting performance. No wonder that the presentation was constantly interrupted by applause and that at the end there was an ovation of minutes for the artists before the...
OMAHA, Dec. 28 (AP) The Union Pacific Railroad announced today that ten gas turbine electric locomotives have been ordered from the General Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that he would call to the attention of the Senate Democratic caucus to be held next Tuesday charges that "false and misleading statements" and a "trick photograph" were employed in the campaign of Senator-elect John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland.
Navy planes of Fast Carrier Task Force 77 returned to battle yesterday, attacking in close and deep support of ground forces deployed along the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

SPORTS celebrities are so dexterous and limber that they frequently are able to perform the astonishing anatomical exploit of open ing their mouths and putting their feet into them. Fortunately for them, however, few fans remember what ridiculous things they say. But they do have one implacable pursuer, a fellow who collects quotable gems and then exposes them to public view.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The supply of newsprint paper is moderately tight but not "seriously" so and there are no present plans to limit its use, the National Production Authority said today.

Although some foods may be in short supply and price trends will depend on a number of factors over which grocers have no control, prospects are bright that the American people will continue to receive an adequate supply of food.
Two new films will arrive in town this morning. At the Mayfair is "The Milkman," a UniversalInternational comedy, starring Donald O'Connor and Jimmy Durante.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 29 Two Brooklyn Boy Scouts, members of a group of fourteen Scouts from 11 to 19 years old who were camping here in Bear Mountain Park, were burned about the face and arms early this morning when a gasoline stove exploded in their shelter.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 General chairmen of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers turned down today the proposed threeyear peace pact formulated by top Government officials in Washington last week. The White House had based its hopes for settlement of the long-standing wage-rules dispute between the railroads and four operating unions on this tentative agreement.

The coal-burning ship, once a familiar sight to ocean travelers, is rapidly disappearing from the world's trade routes. That this type of vessel is now almost as antiquated as the full-rigged sailing ship, the bark and the barkentine was emphasized yesterday in a terse announcement by the Panama Railroad Company.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 29--Fabulous prices for Malaya's exports of rubber and tin have made dozens of new millionaires in the last few months here and in the Malayan Federation. One foreign banker said today he knew eleven men who had made millions in the last few weeks in rubber sales or speculations.

R.L. Hockley and Edwin F.A. Morgan, both of Baltimore, have been added to the board of United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation. Mr. Hockley is vice president in charge of marketing of the Davison Chemical Corporation and a director of that company.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 29 Sir Bengal N. Rau of India was reported to have indicated yesterday to the Asian-Arab group of twelve United Nations delegations that he did not consider the door to a peaceful solution in Korea entirely closed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Senate met for nine seconds today the shortest session in its history.

After seventy-three years in the family of Mathias Weiden, the twostory brick dwelling on lot 25 by 100 feet at 311 East Fifty-eighth Street has been purchased by Charles Jones, music composer, for occupancy.

Fifty-three members of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, the majority of whom held posts with leading European symphonic ensembles, arrived yesterday afternoon at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP) Three-fourths of the nation's children suffer from under-nourishment, a nutrition study indicated today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29 Four million cruzeiros (about $200,000,000) is the figure Brazilian business men declare is needed to build up a stockpile of foreign raw materials to feed Brazilian industry for one year.
Nine members of the basketball team of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Newtown Avenue and Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens, enlisted in the Air Force as a group yesterday.
On Feb. 9, 1946, in a now-historic speech, Premier Stalin proudly told his people and the world how Russia had achieved her victory.
John Wildberg announced yesterday somewhat regretfully that he must close down his production of "Black Chiffon" at the Fortyeighth Street Theatre after the Saturday evening performance of Jan. 13.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Average primary market prices advanced 0.7 per cent in the week ended Dec. 26, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, declared today that unless President Truman's budget for the coming fiscal year was "reduced to essentials," this country was faced with "financial chaos and ultimate disaster."

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 Branch bureaus of the Chinese Communist party in East China have been ordered to expedite the process of land redistribution there as a national defense measure against "both domestic and foreign counterrevolutionaries."
BRISTOL, England, Dec. 29 (AP) The death of Bertram Thomas, explorer, soldier and disciple of the famed Lawrence of Arabia, was announced today. His age was 58.

In brief ceremonies at Fire Headquarters in the Municipal Building, Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday promoted forty-three firemen to the rank of lieutenant and appointed thirteen young men as probationary firemen.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 29 Five hundred householders and small shopkeepers in Bergen County were on the payrolls of gambling syndicate operators for periods of a month to a year in the last year and a half, Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler charged today. Mr. Stamler is in charge of the state's investigation of gambling activities in Bergen.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar of the capital stock, no par value, of Honolulu Oil Corporation.
Increased retirement income benefits for employes of the International Business Machines Corporation was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the board of directors.

The Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States of America reached figures in ten categories of statistics in 1950 that were the highest on record, it was disclosed in the Living Church Annual published this month.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 30 (AP) Release 772, issued by General MacArthur's headquarters at 12:05 P.M. Saturday (10:05 P.M. Friday, Eastern standard time):

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Secretary of Interior Oscar L. Chapman today approved a contract he said will permit an almost immediate start on construction of a 704-mile electric transmission line in South Dakota. The line will cost $9,600,000.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 29 Miss Barbara Croft Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Clark Babcock of Scarborough, was married to William Neal Campbell Jr., son of Mrs. ...

Dr. Robert H. Broh-Hahn has been named medical director of Bristol Laboratories, Inc., Syracuse, N.Y. Before he joined Bristol last spring he was assistant director of the May Institute for Medical Research, Cincinnati.

Allocation to liquor retailers on an equitable proportion of their present purchases was strongly recommended yesterday to the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., by Morris O. Alprin, the association's counsel.
A Bronx mother whose son was killed in combat in World War II sent a contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases fund yesterday in his memory, as she has done on every anniversary of his death.
The market for United States Government securities was little affected yesterday by the order of the Federal Reserve Board advancing bank reserve requirements.

As midnight tomorrow brings in the New Year, virtually all communities in the country will offer prayers for peace. Constituents of the World Council of Churches in forty-five countries are expected to say at tomorrow's services a prayer recently announced by Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church and president of new National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Dec. 29 (AP) Several Vietminh battalions struck the French defense are north of Hanoi on a twenty-fivemile front today and drove to within ten miles of that provincial capital. Then the Communist-led insurgents yielded their gains and fled under a counter-attack by French mobile reserves and planes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a general revision of outstanding securities of the Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad Company, provided holders of 75 per cent of the securities approve.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 Mrs. Laura Champenois Wright Hedden, widow of Charles R. Hedden, builder of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company tower in New York, died here today in her home at 375 Mount Prospect Avenue. Her age was 90.

"Russians with whom I talked regarding the American films 'Mission to Moscow' and 'North Star' said that they were 'funny' because they showed Soviet villages, towns and homes which seemed fantastically luxurious to Russian spectators."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 29--The Bonn Government formally confirmed today that it was seriously considering acceptance of the proposal by the East German Government for bilateral talks on German re-unification. Until today this attitude merely had been indicated by responsible Bonn officials.
PARIS, Dec. 29--Premier Rene Pleven asked the French National Assembly tonight for four votes of confidence, which by the terms of the Constitution will be taken after midnight tomorrow.

WHAT is Stalin's policy? Well, there have been many restless aspects of it since he gave up a youthful career as a bank robber and started hijacking the freedom of mankind sometimes in collaboration with Hitler, sometimes on his very own. All definitions seem to agree, however, that it is consistently apt to leave a trail of violence in its wake.

Wholesalers and distributors of industrial rubber goods expect no immediate change in supply conditions as a result of the rubber control order issued on Thursday by the National Production Authority.

ISTANBUL, Dec. 15 The record of the Turkish contingent fighting in Korea naturally has received the fullest acclaim in the home country. Newspapers carry long descriptions of exploits of the Turkish troops. In towns and villages there are mass demonstrations of pride.

Many debutantes of the season as well as other prominent members of society attended the Debutante Tiara Ball last night in the grand ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
Taking part in the great debate on foreign policy precipitated by the course of events in Korea, John Foster Dulles has rejected the demand of ex-President Hoover for a retreat from ...

The one-story taxpayer containing nine stores on a plot 200 by 100 feet at 79-02 to 79-24 Twentyfirst Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by the Jackson Avenue Holding Corporation, represented by Simon Panush, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by L.V. Hoffman Co., brokers. Green Selzer were attorneys for the seller.
Communism, once a serious threat among the natives of the French Ivory Coast of Africa, is rapidly loosing influence, according to Capt. Hassoldt Davis, who ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today he would ask the new Congress to set up a "watch-dog" committee to keep a close check on the Civil Defense Administration.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 Dr. Selman A. Waksman, Professor of Microbiology at Rutgers University, acknowledged in Superior Court today that a one-time associate, Dr. Albert Schatz, "is entitled to credit legally and scientifically as co-discoverer of streptomycin."

The United States will face a military invasion by the Soviet Union within the next twenty-five years if the forces of isolationism return to power in this country, Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican of Oregon and member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, warned here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 June Haver has refused to appear in Twentieth Century-Fox's musical comedy, "Friendly Island," and has been suspended from salary as a consequence, the studio disclosed today.
Flowers to wear are the demand for New Year's. No hostess will feel that the festivities are complete unless she has flowers for her dress or her hair.

At the end of the year it is our good custom to pause to think about the past so that we can better plan the future. This year end it is particularly important to do that and we should be grateful to all who, out of wisdom, experience and proven idealism, help to clarify the grave issues that confront us.

Retail sales this week showed good gains over the comparable week of last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers. The gain for department stores here was put at 10 per cent. Consumer demand was described as being generally "across the board."
The Christmas holidays probably have left their mark on furnishings in nearly every home cranberry stains on linens, liquor or ink on rugs, chocolate on upholstery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29--Economists closely connected with defense, mobilization planning reported today before their professional societies in joint sessions here on their efforts to grapple with the uncertainties involved in high-level partial mobilization.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) Two seeded players fell by the wayside today in the opening round of the annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament. The players who upset them bowed in turn in the second round.

The advance in the stock market was stalled yesterday by profit-taking. Cross currents prevailed through most of the session and, while there were no major losses, the tone of trading was the opposite of that of the two preceding days. Declines generally were of fractions and the composite average dipped 0.60 point.

COLUMBIA, N.J., Dec. 29 When Jimmy Dewitt comes home from his last mail route tomorrow he will have hung up something of a record that of carrying Uncle Sam's rural mail for fifty-two years. Jimmy thinks it is a national mark.

Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation will expand its production substantially by the middle of next year in an attempt to meet greatly increased military and civilian demand for its fiberglas yarn. This was revealed yesterday following a meeting of the textile products division at 16 East Fifty-sixth Street.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday the last trading day of the year, and closing prices were 14 points lower to 13 points higher than on Thursday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 Year-end evening up dominated the action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, with prices fluctuating in a nervous manner.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 29 One of the most sweeping reforms of this state's government in recent history will begin when Edwin L. Mechem, 38-year-old Las Cruces lawyer, takes office Monday as New Mexico's first Republican Governor in eighteen years and the fourth in its history.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 Dr. B.E. Cohn of the University of Denver told the American Physical Society today at its meeting here that high altitude research conducted with the aid of balloons had proved that a peculiar form of daytime light was generated in the sky between altitudes of 30 and 60 miles. The light adds only faintly to light from the sun.

LONDON, Dec. 29 The stock markets here became slightly dull today. Announcement of the zinc allocation plan led to some selling of zinc-using concerns particularly motor, engineering and paint issues. In contrast, plastic shares strengthened in the belief that plastics would now be in greater demand as substitutes for scarce metals.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 29 The marriage of Miss Cynthia Cresap Comly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Newbold Comly, to Theodore Giles Montague Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Montague, took place here this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Albert J.M. Wilson. There was a reception at the Round Hill Club.
