LONDON, Dec. 29 Britain's economic prospects in 1951 "will be dominated by the impact of rearmament, both here and in other countries," Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the nation today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 The Philadelphia Cotillion Society honored Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Trusteeship Division of the United Nations, at a Christmas cotillion attended by 6,000 persons tonight in Convention Hall.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 Arnold (Mickey) Owen of the Chicago Cubs was shut out today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in his breach of contract suit against Jorge Pasquel, president of the Mexican Baseball League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 President Truman today urged Congress to enact a joint resolution that would permit the posthumous appointment of the late Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker to the grade of full general.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 President Truman signed "with great satisfaction" today a bill designed to tighten the anti-trust laws governing mergers of corporations.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29--The Peiping regime's action in seizing United States property and freezing American bank assets in Communist China did not come as a major surprise today either to United States officials or business men here.

Clarence Budington Kelland, writer and Republican National Committeeman from Arizona, urged President Truman yesterday to reread former President Herbert Hoover's speech and see for himself that it was not a call to isolationism but a "summons to wise international cooperation."
A special prayer for tomorrow has been authorized for the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York by Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan.

After a painstaking nineteenday search involving almost fiction-like running down of clues, detectives at 1 A.M. yesterday arrested Willard Allen Cole, 25 years old, a Canadian, in a bar at Fiftysecond Street and Avenue of the Americas.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 29 C.M. Beasley, Chief of Police of Tampa, told the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today that he believed the Mafia, a Sicilian secret society, was a working crime syndicate in the United States and that professional killers were sent around the country to commit gang assassinations at its order.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) Alfred G. Vanderbilt's fine little filly, Bed o' Roses, won the $15,000 Anita Chiquita purse today as Santa Anita opened its winter meeting.
Winthrop Rockefeller received last evening the annual award of Phi Delta Epsilon, national Medical fraternity, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that ended a three-day convention.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 23--"This is the time to plug holes, not find them," Lord Gort said after Dunkerque.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (U.P.) Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley, out of an elective job for the first time in almost a quarter of a century, sadly packed his personal belongings today, his last in his office in the state Capitol.

While Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute held City College, defending champion, to a 2 -1 score in favor of the Lavender, Columbia annexed 4 points at the expense of Brooklyn College to regain the lead with 16 points in the sixth and semi-final round of the annual team championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, yesterday.

The search for Pasquale Donofrio, wanted for questioning in Brooklyn's dime-locker murder case, centered yesterday in Albany. Customers at two bars there, after looking at rogues' gallery pictures of Donofrio, recognized him as a man who had been drinking in the bar recently.
Even before the winter solstice our afternoons began to grow longer; the earliest sunset occurred on Dec. 8. The opposite end of the day behaves contrarily.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) The Florida Division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association unanimously voted tonight to strike against Tropical Park race track, effective for Tuesday's program.

RECENT communications indicate that a lot of anglers have hoarded their vacations in hopes of making a winter fishing trip to Florida, but some of them seem to evidence fear that this fishing is not for the man with a limited angling budget.

Agreement has been reached on a pension plan for men employed on tugs, self-propelled lighters, oil barges and oil tankers operated in this vicinity, is was announced yesterday. The plan has been under negotiation for the last eleven months.

Discussion at the national convention of the Communist party centered yesterday on the effect of defense mobilization on the people's civil rights and living standards, according to a statement issued at the party headquarters, 35 East Twelfth Street. The convention, at Stuyvesant Casino, 142 Second Avenue, is closed to newspaper reporters.
The conversion of three sets of avenues to one-way operation will be ordered by Mayor Impellitteri as another part of the program to end the city's traffic ills.

The Louisville Orchestra, numbering fifty-two players, and Robert Whitney, conductor, gave a program of contemporaneous music last night in Carnegie Hall which attracted a large and very cordial audience.
CLEVELAND, Dec.29 Growing a new leg on a frog, just by giving it an extra supply of nerves, was reported today by Dr. Marcus Singer of Harvard Medical School.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 (AP) Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj told the Yugoslav Parliament tonight that the world was heading for a third world war.

About 75 per cent of expectant mothers who plan to have their babies at Grace-New Haven Community Hospital (University Service), now are requesting the rooming-in plan whereby they may keep their babies with them instead of having them cared for in the hospital nursery, Dr. Edith B. Jackson, Clinical Professor of Pediatrics and Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 29--A "confession" to the theft of the Coronation Stone, with more circumstantial evidence than some of the other theft claims, was sent tonight to a Glasgow newspaper.

Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, arrived by plane yesterday after having attended the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Canberra, Australia.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 Determinations of the age of rocks by the "cosmic clocks" incorporated in radioactive minerals since the beginning of the universe have provided evidence that the North American Continent has grown by irregular increments from the time the earth was formed and that continental growth is still going on.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 Governor Dewey will ask the 1951 Legislature to help ease congestion on the calendars of New York City's courts, where as much as three years is sometimes needed to get a case to trial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Bureau of the Budget has worked out a plan whereby Federal agencies dealing with defense manpower problems and procurement will be concentrated in thirteen regional offices or regional committees.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 29 During a heavy rainstorm that passed over the island of Attu in the Aleutian Islands on Sept. 12, radio astronomers from the Naval Research Laboratory successfully "observed" a total eclipse of the sun.
John Foster Dulles called upon all free nations last night to make collective security effective by developing their full power to counter-attack against any aggression by Communist "barbarians."
CINCINNATI, Dec. 29--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today that he had no great confidence in the judgment of many of the top military leaders of the nation.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 29 (AP) American and Dutch swimmers continued their domination of the aquatic part of the Canterbury Centennial Games at Christchurch tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Federal officials were stunned today at the announcement in Cleveland that the officers of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers had rejected the tentative settlement of the wage dispute agreed upon Dec. 21 in the White House.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to permit nine private bus companies now charging less than a dime a ride to begin collecting an interim fare of 10 cents next Monday.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 31 Communist forces launched heavier attacks yesterday against the right flank of the United Nations line in Korea, forcing withdrawals of as much as eight miles in some areas, an Eighth Army spokesman said. He denied, however, that the United Nations lines had been penetrated.
The dynamite in the right fist of Gene Hairston, Harlem middleweight, made short work of J.T. Ross of San Jose, Calif., last night in Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) Lloyds' Shipping Gazette reported today that cutbacks in the British Navy had left vast areas under British control virtually without seapower.

BALDWIN, Mich., Dec. 29 (UP) The nation's first Negro county prosecutor, preparing to turn his office over to a white successor, said today his record disproved Communist charges of race discrimination in the United States.

More than 150 delegates representing the professional, community and scholastic theatre from various states are expected to be on hand for the first convention of the National Theatre Assembly to be held at the Fulton Theatre, 210 West Forty-fifth Street, from Jan. 2 through Jan. 4, under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy.

A new purge of Soviet economists has begun, the Moscow Communist party organ, Pravda, reports. Its first targets have been two economists whose work failed to emphasize "the proletariat's struggle to overthrow capitalism, the possibility and necessity of the revolutionary way out from crises" under capitalism.

Presiding Justice John J. Bennett of the Court of Special Sessions will be sworn in as chairman of the City Planning Commission and four others will take the oath for city posts at ceremonies Monday at City Hall.
Dr. Richard Kovacs of 1150 Fifth Avenue, a specialist in physical therapy, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness at the age of 66.

Plans for the publication of a dictionary of modern American usage, designed partly to end confusion over current grammatical practices, were announced yesterday at the closing session of the Modern Language Association's sixty-fifth annual convention at the Statler Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 Four years of bitter strife among claimants to share in the $771,428 estate left by W.C. Fields virtually came to an end today when compromises were announced in Superior Judge William R. McCay's court.
Prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday dropped sharply in response to the overnight announcement from Washington that the Government was taking control over all rubber supplies.

The National Tube Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday announced plans to build a large new extrusion plant for the manufacture of high alloy seamless specialty tubes, as well as shapes and bars, at its Gary Works in Gary, Ind.

Five of the ten experts entered in the international tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings topped the field with scores of 1 after the second round, yesterday, according to a report from England.
The contrast between American attitudes toward the two defeated Powers, Germany and Japan, is brought into sharp focus by the eruption of Communist China as a violently aggressive force.

This country's top-ranking Protestant and Roman Catholic churchmen were called upon yesterday by The Living Church, Protestant Episcopal Weekly, to assert "real" moral and spiritual leadership by issuing a joint statement on the responsibilities of American churchgoers in the current national emergency.

PARIS, Dec. 29 At least a part military mobilization of the Soviet satellite states in the Danube Valley is evidently being carried out. Implications of this are that Moscow intends to attack Yugoslavia ...

The ban on exhibition of the Italian film, "The Miracle," in New York was lifted yesterday afternoon by License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey after he was informed that Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg was about to sign a temporary injunction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Storms caused industrial production to dip slightly in November for the first time since the fighting began in Korea but business generally was setting a record pace. The Federal Reserve Board gave that summary tonight, and it declared:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) American business plans a recordbreaking $21,900,000,000 expansion program in 1951 if it can get the materials.
A noticeable turning to prayer among the thirty-seven communions participating in the fifteenmonth United Evangelistic Advance campaign, which ends at midnight tomorrow, has been reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Government invoked rigid control today over the distribution and use of cobalt, a strategical metal vital to the production of jet engines and many other defense items.

SEOUL, Dec. 29 As United Nations forces and Koreans remaining in this city today tensely awaited a big drive by Chinese and Korean Communists massed to the north, a noticeable increase in confidence was apparent.

The security regulations issued on Wednesday by Vice Admiral Merlin O'Neill for waterfront workers complement measures adopted voluntarily last July by seamen's unions, management and the Coast Guard to protect the maritime industry in an emergency.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) Four more General Motors plants were added today to a rapidly mounting list of automobile factories shutting down temporarily because of critical material shortages.

ROME, Dec. 29 The Italian Government was waiting today for the green light from Washington to go ahead with its rearmament program and its parallel production program on behalf of the North Atlantic pact nations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP) Football's finest hour ticks off tomorrow when college gridiron greats battle it out for the twentysixth annual East-West charity classic.

Revival of the Coast Guard beach patrols that guarded the nation's Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coast shores during most of World War II was urged yesterday by Kenneth D. Johnson, dean of the New York School of Social Work and former special assistant to the Secretary of the Army.

Holiday travel was curtailed sharply yesterday by bad weather. Those who ventured onto the highways found driving hazardous as light snow, rain and a freezing drizzle swept over the metropolitan area; bus and rail schedules also were awry and the Pennsylvania Railroad had particular difficulty on its New Jersey commuter lines, canceling one train without notice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Farm prices rose about 4 per cent between mid-November and midDecember, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

HIGHMOUNT, N.Y., Dec. 29 Inaugurated less than a year ago, the Belleayre Mountain Ski Center sponsored by New York State was full of activity today as hundreds of enthusiasts whizzed down the snow-packed mountainside at an endless pace. Considering the snow, sleet and intermittent rain and fog, the skiing was grand.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29 The marriage of Miss Ann Virginia Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin George Thomas, to Lieut. John Paul Streit, U.S.A.F., son of Maj. Gen. Paul H. Streit of the Army Medical Center, Washington, and Mrs. Streit, took place this evening in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion.
The Federal Reserve has just unlimbered another gun in its campaign to combat price inflation resulting from the expansion of bank credit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Officially, William M. (Fishbait) Miller is chief doorkeeper of the House of Representatives; unofficially, he's odd-jobs man for his 435 bosses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Shipments of arms to nations participating in the Mutual Defense Assistance Program have been nearly doubled in the last six months despite the demands made on war materials and shipping by United Nations forces in Korea. This was announced today by Maj. Gen. Stanley L. Scott.

Only total mobilization or fullscale war will prevent the home building industry from continuing to produce dwellings in large quantities throughout the nation in 1951, according to Bernard Krinsky, secretary of Housing Associates, Inc.

STILL painting hard in his eighty-first year, the veteran artist John Marin now gives proof, in his recent oils and water-colors at the Downtown Gallery, that his spirits are unflagging.

A lot of discerning basketball fans, recognizing two mismatches in advance, steered clear of Madison Square Garden last night. Only 8,114 spectators, the smallest Saturday night turnout for a college twin bill since the sport was introduced to the Eighth Avenue ...

PANAMA--Four centuries after the King's Highway was cut through from the Atlantic to the Pacific and first made this region accessible to travelers, Panama will see the opening of tropical America's most modern luxury hotel.
The city expended $107,000,000 in 1950 to keep 200,000 underprivileged children in their homes or with close relatives, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard reported yesterday.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 30-- Sparked by Center Paul Horvath's 25 points and great rebound work, North Carolina State College defeated Colgate, 85--76, tonight to retain its Dixie basketball classic title before a record crowd of 12,200 fans. Navy beat Wake Forest, 66--46, for third place.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 1--Chinese Communists and North Koreans launched attacks along a wide front of the United Nations defense line in Korea today and an Army spokesman said they were surging ahead "at many points."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)-- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today that the nation's immigration laws were chaotic and that he would ask the new Congress to unsnarl and tighten them.

CAIRO, Dec. 31--Communism has come suddenly to the front in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, with the Administration proceeding to put into effect an ordinance passed a few days ago prohibiting Communist organizations and with railways just starting to move again after a three-day demonstration strike against the imprisonment of the reputedly pro-Communist railway union head.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--Secretary of State Dean Acheson called upon the American people today for faith that the country could and would accomplish "the great task before us"--the preservation of the free world.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 31 --In a clear bid to break down the Western world's antipathy for German men in uniform, Federal President Theodor Heuss today spurred a growing campaign for restoration of the honor of the German soldier.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 31 --The Alumni Association of Vanderbilt University has mailed to its membership a copy of a letter in which the University's chancellor ...

In a bone-crunching battle marked by a near-riot in the second period, the New York Rovers and the Boston Olympics battled to a 2-all tie in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.)-- The American Institute of Architects today suggested a ban on new home and plant construction in key United States cities likely to be targets in an atomic blitz.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved in a narrow range last week in trading typical of a pre-holiday period. Changes in active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Echange varied from a decline of 5 points to an advance of 25 points. The market registered net gains of 26 to 71 points in the preceding week.

"Pardon Our French," the fourth Olsen and Johnson musical to be presented here, will end its run at the Broadway Theatre on Saturday night after completing its 100th performance. Sometime this week the production's sponsors will decide whether they will reopen ...

The days will continue to pass and again the Tuesdays will somewhat resemble the Mondays. The presses will begin to roar at their stipulated times each night, continuing into the morning. There will be great technical ...
A college basketball matinee, a rarity in this section, will be presented at Madison Square Garden today, with two quintets risking spotless records. One, Clair Bee's Long Island University squad ...

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 31--The United States has decided to give up the idea of holding a general peace conference to determine the terms to be granted Japan, and now favors the conclusion of separate peace treaties between Japan and the fourteen nations that bore the brunt of the war in the Pacific.

TRENTON, Dec. 31--The big United States Steel Corporation mill coming to this area has officials, business leaders and the public in general keyed up over prospects of a great industrial future. Industry, business and home building are expected to spurt even as early as the construction period.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) --Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that newsprint "must be controlled now by the National Production Authority."

Times Square cast its glitter last night on a familiar scene--the birth of a new year. Thousands of New Yorkers, tied to a tradition that will not die, converged on the city's show place to greet 1951 with blaring horns and cheers.
Chuck Rayner scored his first shutout victory of the season as the New York Rangers blanked the Boston Bruins in their National Hockey league game at Madison Square Garden last night.
As bells, chimes and carillons pealed forth from cathedral and church towers to herald the arrival of 1951, millions of Christians silently prayed for peace in houses of worship in many countries.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 --Favored with its best snow conditions in three years, this Adirondack resort boasted a record influx of winter sports enthusiasts today. Snow, so scarce since 1948, has visited Lake Placid consistently the past two weeks and was still falling today.

ALBANY, Dec. 31--Thomas E. Dewey took the oath of office for a third term as Governor of New York at an informal ceremony in the Executive Mansion this afternoon preliminary to his formal inauguration tomorrow.
Recommendations for voluntary conservation of packaging materials by producers and users of containers were announced last week by the National Production Authority.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) --Rose Bowl excitement clamped its annual hold on this overcrowded city tonight and tomorrow 100,000 persons will swarm into Pasadena's famd old football dueling pit to watch the struggle between Michigan and California.

With thousands of young New Yorkers facing induction into the armed forces, the Federation Employment Service has prepared a comprehensive guide to the educational and vocational training opportunities open for men and women in the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has completed a deal involving the fifteen-story apartment building for eighty-nine families at 800 West End Avenue, which it had owned since the property was foreclosed in 1935.
READING, England, Dec. 31-- (AP)--Lieut. Col. Sir John Henry Maitland Greenly, industrialist, died tonight at Calcot Hill, his home near here. He was 65 years old.
The New York City of 1851; when THE NEW YORK TIMES began publication at 113 Nassau Street, had a population of fewer than 600,000.
THE NEW YORK TIMES starts its Centennial Year today. It will be 100 years old on Sept. 18, 1951.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)-- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report opposed today a blanket revival of Presidential wartime powers to reorganize Government agencies.

Gerald Barrack, outsteadying his opponent all the way, conquered favored and top-seeded Donald Thompson of Jackson Heights, in the final for the Eastern junior tennis championship yesterday at the Third Engineer Group Armory.

LONDON, Dec. 31--Measures for the defense of the far-flung British Commonwealth and the preservation of world peace seemed today to have been thrust to the forefront of subjects for discussion at the conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers convening here Thursday.

The city will have a rocky financial road to travel this year because of the international situation and the impact of a war economy, according to a report made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP)-- An editorial in the League Reporter of the A.F.L. said today that a "ragged regiment of isolationists" led by "Colonel" Herbert Hoover was fighting a "war to the death" against the Washington Administration's foreign policy.
A badly battered dove of peace rode atop the city's buses last night, but no one was sure how long harmony would prevail on two of the principal bus lines.
BOSTON, Dec. 31--The specter of inflation hovered today over the legislative leaders of New England's three northern states during final preparations for the biennial sessions opening next month.
The strongest concentration of anti-Communist guerrillas in Red China is in the southwest, chiefly in the provinces of Kweichow, Kwangsi, Yunnan, Szechwan and Hunan.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 1--Communists moved tanks and artillery up to the front lines in Korea yesterday and guns began to drop shells over the United Nations lines.

Prof. and Mrs. John A. Hanna of 25 Claremont Avenue, and Racing Beach, Falmouth, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margaret, to DeWitt Clinton Jones 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Quissett, Mass.

A gourmet who, as he said, "used to be a newspaper man myself," took two hours off the other morning from chores attendant on being an account executive for a public relations consultant to talk about avocados, artichokes, a ...
Many interesting exhibitions are scheduled for the first week of the New Year in metropolitan art galleries and museums.

Salesmen who really came into their own as a vital force in the distribution system earlier this year as a result of hard competition in many lines are facing 1951 with some qualms because of the stepped-up mobilization program.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 31--The sun may not shine for 12-year-old Antonio Cabrera Jr., of Mexico City, but nevertheless 1951 will be a brighter year for him.

Store realty continued to hold a major share of Long Island realty interest as the year ended. Sales were reported of a large taxpayer in Roslyn and of a threestory store building, with apartments above the ground floor in Bay Shore.

The American citizen of 1851 really felt himself in the midst of a period of breath-taking developments. He, or his father, had seen the steamboat appearing on the navigable rivers and even crossing the Atlantic Ocean. He had seen steam power widely applied in new factories.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31--Bullish sentiment predominated in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week. All deliveries of wheat, corn, rye and soybeans sold at new highs for the year with final trades Friday only slightly under the top level, and all at new highs since 1948.

The stock market closed the year of 1950 with THE NEW YORK TIMES averages around their best levels in nearly two decades in the heaviest trading on the New York Stock Exchange since 1933. Sales amounted to 524,799,621 shares, compared with 272,203,402 in the previous year. The record was 1,124,990,980 shares in 1929.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP)--Clemson College Tigers and the University of Miami Hurricanes held final limbering up drills today and were reported in tip-top shape for their meeting in the seventeenth annual Orange Bowl football game tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The much-sought-for new Republican place on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is likely to go to Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 31 --The South is looking ahead to the inaugural addresses to be delivered in January by six Governors,

"You are never too young to learn," a neat switch on an old saying, is applicable to little girls and fashion. As tastes may be formed at a tender age, why not begin with tots to lay the foundation for the future education in all.
Leaders in maritime industries have received unofficial assurances from City Hall that the city's longrange study of port conditions will be pressed vigorously after the first of the year.

Strong business conditions in the year just closed and confidence in 1951 prospects, tempered by gathering war clouds and some uncertainty on how the rearmament program and price and wage controls will work, are reflected in reports to THE NEW YORK TIMES by its correspondents in the twelve Federal Reserve districts.
The Metropolitan Opera will reach the midpoint of its season when it begins its tenth week next Monday evening, Jan. 8.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP)-- Robert C. Goodwin, executive director of the Office of Defense Manpower of the United States Department of Labor, warned today that 1951 would bring shortages of both jobs and labor as the nation's mobilization program expanded.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 31-- Members of the Rockland County Audubon Society in their annual bird count made within a fifteenmile radius of the county seat were amazed today by reports from a team of three that they were dive-bombed by a female goldeneye duck in the village of Rockland Lake.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 31-- Economy in State Government is the political watchword of the moment in Nevada, as in other parts of the southwest, with a Republican Governor taking over reins long in Democratic hands.
Defense plans for the area between Thirty-fourth and Fortyeighth Streets and Fifth Avenue and the East River are 70 per cent complete, a civil defense spokesman said yesterday.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS, in Korea, Dec. 30--Although troops and officers of the United Nations Army were confident they could hold firm here against the principal Communist drive to oust them from Korea, it was generally conceded a second Communist military move elsewhere ...
CONRAD, Mont., Dec. 31 (UP)-- Another Montana draft board resigned today to protest selective service policies.

Constant and courageous prayers are "mightier than atom bombs," Cardinal Spellman said yesterday in a pastoral letter read at all masses in the New York Archdiocese. At St. Patrick's Cathedral the letter was read at solemn mass by Msgr. William T. Greene, chairman of the archdiocesan music commission.
The Real Estate Auctioneers Association, one of the oldest auction sales organizations in the country, put into effect yesterday a new plan of operation and took a new name.

The romantic influence of the West is combined with present-day pace in the design and construction of a new group of informal ranch furniture now at Macy's. Designed by John J. Keal for the Furniture Guild of California, it is called Informal Ranch Modern.

LONDON, Jan. 1--Britain, along with the United States and France, received from the Soviet Union today a reply to the joint proposal for a meeting of representatives of the four powers in New York to discuss an agenda for a possible conference of foreign ministers.

While payments in some lines of business were slower in 1950 than in the previous year, the credit experience of most wholesalers and manufacturers showed considerable improvement. In the early months the rate of failures rose, but in the final six months it leveled off to virtually the same as a year ago.

WITH UNITED NATIONS FORCES in Korea, Jan. 1--As the Communist attack forced United Nations forces to withdraw to new positions closer to the capital city of Seoul, the Army imposed stringent censorship on news dispatches from the area.

Active public support of the series of proposed changes in the Multiple Building Law which have been prepared for presentation at the new session of the State Legislature was urged yesterday by the legislative committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

Employe relations practices are making progress in eliminating the gulf between employers and employes, the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday in a "Case Book of Employe Communications in Action."

There is little likelihood of a voluntary rollback of prices in the paper industry as long as costs continue to rise, trade sources disclosed last week. A check of key officials indicated there had been no indication of such action by any company.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1 (AP) Unbeaten Princeton had to fight overtime for its eighth basketball victory tonight, but managed to thump Rochester, 67--61.
On New Year's Day the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received seventy-three contributions totaling $1,452, including a $100 gift from A.E. Clegg of San Francisco.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico--This island, having gone through a year in which it was profoundly disturbed by an abortive revolution and, to a lesser extent, by the Far Eastern situation, finds itself in a relatively better economic position than at the end of 1949.

Relatives and friends of seven appointees to Mayor Impellitteri's official family filled the City Council Chamber at City Hall yesterday for noon-hour ceremonies at which the seven were sworn into office.
Economic conditions definitely indicate a rise in retail sales volume in the year ahead, according to J. Gordon Dakins, general manager and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON--Nothing that has happened since the deep split in the labor movement in 1936 has been of greater importance in the efforts to reunite the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations than the C.I.O.'s ouster of unions dominated by leaders following the Communist party line.

CHICAGO,--Economic activity in the midwest reached a high level in 1950, with an enlarged post-war productive capacity going at or near full blast most of the year in most important products. Employment reached an all-time high.

After passing the $20,000,000,000 deposit mark in 1950--for the first time in their 134-year history--the nation's mutual savings banks anticipate even further expansion this year as the mobilization program advances.
Two persons died yesterday as the result of a fire in a private home on Staten Island following a New Year's Eve party.

The necessity for restraining the use of credit in the face of a mounting inflationary spiral, which expanded more than $7,000,000,000 after the Korean outbreak, continues the major concern of bankers as 1951 begins.

WASHINGTON--It didn't take a conference between President Truman and Prime Minister Attlee last month to verify the existence of acute commodity shortages. These had become all too apparent as a result of the Government's vigorous stockpiling and industry's efforts here and abroad to anticipate the conditions their buying had helped create.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)--Before a crowd of 14,584 early birds, William G. Helis Jr's. swift-running Valpam rolled to an impressive victory in the $6,000 New Year's Handicap, feature of today's morning program at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON--War in the Far East, tension in the West and the declaration of an emergency at home in 1950 forced abandonment of virtually all of the United States tariff and trade agreement objectives.

Puerto Rico succeeded in 1950 in setting up in the securities markets of the United States a base of permanent financing for the "Operation Bootstrap" with which the Administration of Governor Munoz Marin has been directing expansion of the island's economy.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UP)-- The Columbia Broadcasting System was the new owner of television station KTSL today after selling its 49 per cent interest in television station KTTV to The Los Angeles Times.
New York State's employment service has found that it can increase the number of jobs it obtains for older applicants by making special efforts in their behalf.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 1 --Successful in four major state elections, the Association of Homeless and those Deprived of Rights, a catch-all label for a political party of Germany's discontented, will meet in Bonn later this month and attempt to form a national party.

Record toanages of scrap iron and steel--old automobiles and locomotives, obsolete farm implements, ships and the metallic wastes of industry--will be required in 1951 to feed the nation's hard-working steel mills and foundries.

The retirement of bonds before maturity in 1950 was more than three times larger than in 1949 and the largest total for any year since 1947. Increased refundings were made by all groups, But redemptions for public utility corporations accounted for more than half of the total of all bonds retired in the year.

The domestic aluminum industry, an important, cog in the nation's industrial machine for war and peace, produced at capacity last year and embarked on a huge expansion program that will raise its productive potential by some 70 per cent before the middle of 1952.
PHILADELPHIA--Business and industry are booming in the eightcounty Philadelphia metropolitan district, with employment and wages at all-time peaks.

WASHINGTON--A special study of investment trends, including an analysis of the differences between business men's programmed expenditures and those they actually carried through in expansion of plant and equipment, was completed by the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce late in 1950.

The eighty-eighth anniversary of the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation was marked yesterday at a two-hour service in the auditorium of St. Mark's Methodist Church, 49 Edgecombe Avenue. The document was signed by Abraham Lincoln on Jan, l, 1863.

PARIS, Jan. 1--Premier Rene Pleven told the French people today that the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents in Indo-China appeared ready to drag their country through the "horrors of war" in order to play their role in "a vast scheme for the domination and exploitation of Asia."

WASHINGTON--The Korean war threw the United States into a new fiscal era of rising Federal expenditures, taxes and debt. By the end of the year, taxes promised to break World War II records, with expenditures and the national debt approaching previous peaks. There was no hope for a balanced budget in the foreseeable future.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Oklahoma, the Goliath of college football and holder of the greatest victory streak in modern times, fell in the Sugar Bowl today before Kentucky, 13--7, on the passes of Babe Parilli and the superb line play of Walt Yowarsky. A capacity crowd of 82,000 watched.

Market yields of high-grade corporate investments fluctuated during 1950 within the narrowest range of recorded statistics. At the year's end, moreover, the market gave no signs of any readiness to return to the price and yield swings characteristic of the prewar period. Government bonds callable in seventeen years were yielding 2.44 per cent at year-end, and top-grade corporate credit of twice that term was yielding less than 2.70 per cent.

Despite other demands and means of merrymaking, Broadway's movie palaces drew their share of the holiday crowds over the long week-end and, as usual, did standing room only business during the last hours of 1950.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.--The South's post-war prosperity remained intact during 1950. Although Government restrictions on credit buying and building construction caused a slowing down in several business areas at year's end, the region generally entered 1951 with steadily increasing employment rolls and strong manufacturing gains.

The sharp increase in demand resutling in part from the military preparedness program, combined with the harvesting last year of a short crop in the United States, has changed the problem of cotton, nearly always one of surplus, to one of scarcity. With the United States Department of Agriculture, however, having removed all controls on the 1951 crop, an all-out effort probably will be made this year toward a substantial recovery in production.

ST. LOUIS--Industrial and business activity continued to move upward in this area during 1950, showing probable gains of 5 to 8 per cent at the year's end and prospects bright for a new surge under the impact of defense mobilization.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 1--Failure of the Dutch-Indonesian negotiations regarding the status of New Guinea resulted in Indonesian shares losing up to five points in minor dealings on the stock market. Elsewhere prices generally were well maintained although a slight reaction was noted in the bond market.
Two questions seem to us to be involved in the controversy over Commissioner McCaffrey's threat to suspend the license of the Paris Theatre for presenting the Italian film called "The Miracle."
As the Eighty-first Congress comes to a close today after two eventful years, its members can look back upon some very considerable achievements.
The New Year came in with good portent yesterday--with clear skies, warming sun and a minimum of New Year's Eve hangovers.

The Silk and Rayon Print Institute has been formed as a non profit organization for the improvement and advancement of industrial, trade and consumer relations in the industry, it is announced for publication today.
WASHINGTON--The United States "gave away" $2,978,000,000 in the first nine months of 1950 in support of a policy of containing aggressive communism and lent another $341,000,000 for the purpose.

Despite higher prices and larger industrial payrolls last year, the volume of currency in the hands of the public was slightly smaller than in 1949, largely reflecting the extension of checking services by banks.
Taxes edged wage costs out of first place for the first time in the history of the electric industry as they soared over the billion-dollar mark last year.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska--Military construction, which has been the largest contributing factor to the Alaskan economy since the United States entered World War II, continued to boom during 1950. This trend is expected to continue duning 1951.

KATHERINE MARY O'FALLON FLANNIGAN'S father was a revolutionist and a friend of the great Parnell. Her greatuncle, Denny Lennan, was a "hedgerow schoolmaster" and a singing tinker, a poet and a teller of tales.

MANILA, Jan, 1--A Philippine Government announcement today said President Elpidio Quirino had relieved Maj. Gen. Mariano Castaneda as Army Chief of Staff and had assigned him to the three-man mission to the United States seeking additional assistance for expaneded military services.

For almost every phase of civil aviation, 1950 was a good year. Commercial airlines of the United States, on the whole, had an excellent if not record year. Aircraft and aircraft engine production was good and got better as the year ended. Even the light private plane business increased.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 (AP)--Following is the text of the inaugural address of Governor Dewey today:
Under the pressure of another great national rearmament effort, the domestic steel industry, backbone of the economy in war and peace, expects to reach new production and expansion records in 1951.

Since the shipping industry traditionally is among the first to be mobilized and the last, at war's end, to be returned to private activity, the fate and fortunes of the merchant marine in 1951 depend upon international developments.

Effectiveness of the $2,000,000,000 increase in bank reserve requirements as a step to tie up $12,000,000,000 of potential bank credit was minimixed by the National City Bank yesterday because of the system of pegs maintained by the Federal Reserve System in the market for Government securities.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 1--Representatives of the Arab-Asian group in the United Nations and of the Committee of Three seeking a cease-fire conferred with both the United States and Soviet delegations yesterday in further efforts to end the Korean war.

With pensions more widely accepted as a prerequisite to better management-labor relations, developments in the pension field in 1950 centered principally in broadening the benefits and improving the administration of pension programs. Less controversy and publicity have been associated with such adjustments than in recent years.

Records were established last year in virtually every division of the domestic oil industry. Consumption reached a new peak and for the year it was about 11 per cent over that of 1949 when there was a slight decline from 1948.

WASHINGTON--In its continuing campaign to break down monopoly, the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice is closing 1950 with something close to a four-to-one record of victories. In the eighteen months up to December the division has won about forty cases to ten lost.

Until the imposition of controls on consumer credit in September, national requirements for such financing last year appeared to be heading for a record annual increase of $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000. But as 1950 closed the expansion had been held to about $3,000,000,000, leaving the total outstanding at approximately $20,000,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO--Hard hit West Coast ports, especially those in California, were revitalized by the Korean war and foreign trade with the Far East and elsewhere slowly worked its way ahead, showing some improvement in 1950 over the preceding year.

Recent downward adjustments, in the price of raw furs have encouraged dealers, manufacturers, and retailers to look for greater consumer buying of fur garments this year following disappointing results in 1950. Inventories are in better shape, although manufacturing operations suffered during the period of slow demand during the fall.

Chemical industries ended the year in a strong and active position, with extensive development work planned for the next twelve months. Prices were generally higher and some items had ad-- vanced as much as 300 per cent in price since midyear lows.
DES MOINES, Iowa--The outlook for meat on the dinner table is exceedingly good, according to the Department of Agriculture.

The full effect of advances in prices of men's clothing will be felt next fall unless price rollbacks intervene. Meanwhile, the outlook is for continued firmness, manufacturers said, with production for the first six months of his year running 10 per cent ahead of the same period in 1950.
A year of violent price fluctuations in 1950 forced the stock market to change its entire course on several occasions because of overhanging war clouds, both actual and potential.

Spokesmen for the food industry view prospects for the coming year with confidence despite the many uncertainties that lie ahead. While they realize that plans must all be based on international developments, they believe the industry is in a position to meet any emergency.

Under the impact of a steadily expanding defense program, industrial building activity is due to turn upward sharply this year, but housing construction work is likely to decline appreciably from the record levels of 1950.

WASHINGTON--Any illusions business and industry may have entertained regarding an "easy" way to move into defense production melted rapidly in the closing weeks of 1950. New life was injected into defense programs by the President's declaration of a national emergency, and related agencies which had been marking time on restrictions moved quickly to outline their programs.
BOSTON--New England closed out the year with prospects that the momentum of industrial activity would keep the region humming well into 1951.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1(AP)--The House Merchant Marine Committee, today ruled the Coast Guard guilty of "negligence" in a May 19 ammunition explosion that killed thirty-four men at South Amboy, N.J.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP)--Hank Lauricella swept Tennessee to a touchdown with three minutes to go today as the Volunteers whipped Texas, 20--14, in a battering, slashing Cotton Bowl game before a crowd of 75,349.

After a record decline of more than $1,632,000,000 last year, the nation's gold stocks will probably continue to decrease during 1951, according to present indications. The reduction last year compares with the previous record declines of $1,350,000,000 in 1943.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1--An iron-sinewed University of Michigan gridiron combination, outplayed for a full half, rallied spectacularly in the final minutes to inflict a decisive 14-to-6 defeat on California's Golden Bears in the thirty-seventh annual Rose Bowl game today.

Essential industrial production in 1951 will be limited only by the availability of materials and manpower, according to George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Unionized workers in the nation's principal industries won more than $2,000,000,000 a year in wage increases during 1950, but rising living costs and taxes ate up much of labor's gains in purchasing power.
Spanish hospitality, always extended so enthusiastically to guests, at this season includes an invitation to sample a slice of that savory meat pie, empanada.

Although total sales of all types of United States Savings Bonds during 1950 continued at about the same level as in the previous year, redemptions of the smaller Series E bonds exceeded sales for the first time since these "baby bonds" were offered in 1935.

ST. LOUIS--The Kremlin and Korea wrought a drastic change in United States agriculture in 1950. Even greater changes are in prospect for the new year as farmers prepare for all-out production for the second time in a decade.

Total retail dollar volume of the home furnishings industry, including television, radio and electrical appliances, exceeded $12,000,000,000 last year, according to unofficial but authoritative estimates. This topped 1949 by $1,000,000,000 and equaled the previous record year, 1948.

TRENTON, Jan. 1 (AP)--Officials of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and the New York State Thruway Authority will confer early this month to pick the route for a high-speed highway linking the two expressways.

LOS ANGELES--Spurred by a steady regional population increase, amounting to more than 8,000 persons a month in Los Angeles County alone, and by burgeoning military production, general business and industrial activity in Southern California rose to record levels in 1950.

Military requirements for textiles, stepped up by the Korean crisis, brought the volume of American cloth producers to almost boom proportion in 1950. Textile output for civilian needs showed substantial gains in the first six months of the year and the additional impetus of military buying raised mill profits to postwar highs.

The sale of wool from the free nations of the world to Russia should he stopped, according to Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. In a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES, Mr. Besse said that it was not logical to sell a material needed to clothe our expanding military forces to countries that are threatening world peace.

If the 1951 prospects for the American tourist industry are grim, the industry can find satisfaction in its performance during 1950. In the year just ended, tourism was hit twin blows by the weather and the state of international affairs. Strangely, the weather did the more damage.

NEW ORLEANS--Imports handled by the port of New Orleans in the first half of 1950 amounted to 1,841,500 tons and exports to 1,773,200 tons. This indicated a 4 per cent increase in imports and a 24 per cent decrease in exports. This trend, which continued into the second half of the year, was attributed to greater needs in the United States for sugar, molasses, bananas, copra, mahogany and rubber.
Five "New Year resolutions," extending basic conceptions of advertising's social responsibility, were offered yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau.

ALBANY, Jan. 1--A sweeping revision of all eligibility lists for civil service appointments and promotions in the State went into effect today, radically altering in many cases the Governmental job prospects of an estimated 100,000 persons throughout the State.
The communications world was preoccupied during 1950 meeting a seemingly endless demand for more and more service.

We have been hearing strong voices as the new year starts, and it is cause for rejoicing. Governor Dewey, who on Dec. 14 in a truly notable speech called upon Americans to drop their "defensive mood," again spoke bravely and wisely in his inaugural address yesterday.
"Second Threshold," a drama by the late Philip Barry, with revisions by Robert E. Sherwood, will open tonight at the Morosco Theatre. The curtain is scheduled to rise at 8 P.M.
WASHINGTON--Although 1950 was marked by more strikes than 1949, the number of persons involved and the man-hours lost fell considerably below that of 1949.

New issues of Philadelphia Plan trust certificates to finance the acquisition of railroad equipment will likely exceed the total of $270,969,000 sold in 1950, according to a year-end market survey by Rudolf Smutny, partner of Salomon Brothers Hutzler.

TOKYO, Jan.1 (AP)--Despite Gen. Douglas MacArthur's advice in a New Year's message that "if international lawlessness continues to threaten the peace," it will be Japan's duty to "mount force to repel force," spokesmen for two of Japan's leading political parties insist they think rearmament is not necessary.
Calendars and engagement books for 1951 are designed to be helpful to men and women with a variety of interests.

THE woods always appear to be full of game once the season has closed, for during the course of one day's rabbit hunting over the past week-end we counted seven deer and eleven grouse, and every bit of this forbidden game was within easy gunshot.
With East Indian motivation and American wearability, the "Flight to India" collection of resort fashions designed by Carolyn Schnurer is to be seen in Peck Peck shop windows.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., which on Sunday negotiated an 11-cent wage increase for the employes of six private bus companies, notified the Board of Transportation yesterday that it was seeking pay rises and "early effectuation" of the forty-hour...

The increasing impact of national mobilization will tell the indusarial and business story of 1951. The dual drive for greater defense production and for control of inflation is now entering its major phase.

The national economy for the last ten years, based on the Bureau of Labor Statistics cost-ofliving index (using the l935-39 average as 100), has been one of steady increases. This is particularly true for the eleven months of 1950, which shows only a few minor deviations from the uptrend.
Well, that's over, or rather, they are over. They have gone to join the memories of other Christmases and New Year's Days, gone forever.

With the settlement near the year-end of the 22-month-old wage dispute that also provided for a three-year moratorium on strikes, the railroad industry starts 1951 with high hopes that its job of meeting the nation's transportation needs in the difficult period ahead may be achieved without any serious disruption in operations.
Mutual investment funds have checked off 1950 as highly satisfactory. Company officials, for the most part, look forward with confidence to 1951, expecting it to be another record business year.

A YEAR ago knowing football men were saying that Tom Fears of the Los Angeles Rams was the best end the sport has pro duced since Don Hutson. Recently they were saying that Fears is better than Hutson.

A decline in activity was noted in the wholesale markets here last week but some special requests were received for merchandise for final promotions, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Many buyers are expected in the markets this week to fill in on spring requirements.
DETROIT--After the most successful year in its history, the automobile industry is looking forward to even greater production under the demands of the rearmament program.
Few years in the history of the United States have produced such prosperity as 1950.

The trend in women's apparel sales during 1950 continued downward from the peak year of 1948. Unit production declined in all major lines of outer apparel except blouses and skirts, Dollar volume was down in all categories except dozen price dresses.
We note with interest and approval the reappointment of Judge Bernard Ryan of Albion to the State Court of Claims.
BOSTON--Labor and management in New England enjoyed one of their must peaceful years in 1950 despite the difficulties of negotiating fourth and fifth round wage increases in many industries.

The outbreak of hostilities in Korea last year caused the first "softening" of the dollar in foreign exchange markets since 1943-45. Expectations of war profits from American orders by traders abroad and the accompanying "flight" of capital was reflected in the improvement of foreign currency quotations as 1950 came to an end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP)-- More than a score of important Presidential nominations will die upon the adjournment of the Eighty-first Congress tomorrow, a survey showed tonight.
TOKYO, Jan. l (AP)--Morimasa Nashimoto, member of the Japanese Imperial family and supreme war councilor in World War II, died today of a heart attack at the age of 76.

Civilian consumption of copper has been cut about 25 per cent, effective today. That drastic curtailment in use of the red metal tells in the fewest words the plight of users of copper. Later that tight situation will be reflected in shortages of copper-content equipment.

The work of American steel companies in the development of rich iron ore deposits in Venezuela has opened up a new sea route to United States Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports, with shipments of this ore due in this country soon, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday.
As the Chinese Communist armies begin their long-awaited drive south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel a blanket of silence covers the United Nations. Its General Assembly stands in recess.

The $65,000,000,000 life insurance industry had one of its most active years, investment-wise, during 1950. The net result is that the life insurance companies have had to maintain their increasing funds, held for policyholders, in a fully invested position, with a distribution that points to a slightly better average earning rate than has been the case in recent years.

The market carried on here for foreign dollar bonds and internal securities of foreign nations managed pretty well in 1950 to maintain its composure during a year of sporadic jitters. For some Latin-American nations it was a period of striking gain, with bonds of Chile, Peru and El Salvador selling at their highest levels in nearly twenty years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1-- After years of talk and study a contract has been signed between the State of California and an architect for preliminary plans for the first unit of San Francisco's World Trade Center.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 2 (AP)-- Release 778, issued by General MacArthur's headquarters at 11:50 A.M., Tuesday (9:50 P.M., Monday, Eastern standard time):
Fares on privately owned bus lines in the city have risen to ten cents, six months after the city's lines got their ten-cent fare. Wages have been or will be raised.

Large producers of rubber goods expect cutbacks to reduce output of finished goods in 1951, it was disclosed here by top executives of two large companies. However, compared with 1941, production facilities are much larger for the rubber industry, and a record high in the use of rubber was achieved in 1950.

MADRID, Jan 1--As Spanish authorities worked on this country's eleventh official census, they warned the public today that anybody who failed to appear on the census list would lose his right to draw a food ration or to vote.

Long Island University's unblemished record hardly was jeopardized as the Blackbirds romped to an 84--58 conquest of outclassed South Carolina and easily gathered their eighth straight yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
Wolfgang Unzicker of Munich and Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris were fourth-round winners yesterday in the international chess tournament at Hastings, according to a report from England.

ALBANY, Jan. 1--Governor Dewey in a third-term Inaugural Address devoted primarily to the world crisis urged today full mobilization of all the resources of the free world to resist Russian aggression. He warned that survival required "toil and more toil" and "sacrifice and greater sacrifice."

The 1951 annual volume of business of the materials handling equipment industry will exceed $2,500,000,000 if the Federal Government goes ahead with present national defense plans. This estimate, which includes all branches of the industry, was made by R. Kennedy Hanson, executive secretary of the Materials Handling Institute, Washington.

WASHINGTON--The booming foreign trade of Western European countries that devalued their currencies fifteen months ago and the reappearance of United States trade deficits with important rawmaterial areas have combined with increased domestic business activity to produce the most encouraging international trade and payments outlook since World War II.
Today's father likes to think of himself as thoroughly democratic in his family relationships but he's likely to border on the autocratic in the way he treats his youngsters.
Advertising volume during 1950 again topped $5,000,000,000 with indications that the final total would exceed $5,500,000,000, a gain of about $300,000,000 over 1949, and a new record high.

Enough shoes will be produced next year to meet the demands of the entire population, leaders in the industry predict. The quantities of leather taken for military footwear are not expected to ham-- per the industry's ability to meet civilian requirements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Democratic majority of the special House committee that investigated lobbying activity recommended today that Congress keep a constant check on the operation of laws governing both lobbying and the conduct of elections.
WASHINGTON--Worrying mobilization officials at year's end was the low ceiling on manpower. Manpower, they said, will set the ultimate limit on United States war potential.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Agriculture Committee of the National Planning Association urged today the immediate stockpiling of grains as a strategic reserve for the Atlantic Pact countries, even at the risk of inflating further the food prices in the United States.

Dr. Theodore Stuart Hart, wellknown specialist in cardiac ailments, died yesterday of a heart attack, after a brief illness, at his residence, 410 Park Avenue. He would have been 82 years old on Feb. 25.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1-- Northwood School of Lake Placid, N.Y., and Belmont Hill School of Belmont, Mass., moved into the final round of the third annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament tonight before 500 fans in Princeton University's Baker Rink.
Garlands of southern smilaz and poinsettia blossoms provided a red and green decor for the annual Debutantes New Year's Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The proposed Thruway bridge across the Tappan Zee between South Nyack and Tarrytown constitutes a "basic error" in planning the entire 535-mile superhighway, the Regional Plan Association charged yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1--With total deposits of $2,404,786,000, the First National Bank of Chicago maintained its ranking as the city's largest bank as it and other major downtown banks today released annual reports on 1950 operations.

KALIMPONG, India, Jan. 1-- India's political officer in Tibet, Dr. S. Sinha, has been expelled from Lhasa by pro-Communist forces now in control of the Forbidden City, according to the latest advices received in this Indian border town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--As General Eisenhower prepares to go to Western Europe on an assignment which has no parallel in American history, and cannot ever have been exceeded in difficulty and responsibility, these speculations as to what will follow can be ventured:

In a sharp attack on the New York State Department of Social Welfare, the Public Administration Service charged yesterday that the state "imposes" on the New York City Welfare Department a "vague relationship" that is "unhealthy, unnatural and illogical."

WASHINGTON--The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce in a joint survey of plant expansion planned for the first quarter of this year, report that industry will spend close to $5,000,000,000, the greatest outlay of the kind in the nation's history.

SEATTLE--On a dollar basis, 1950 promises to rank above any previous year in the Pacific Northwest. In over-all volume of production most indexes indicate that only the war years have shown higher marks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1-- Gabriel Pascal, George Bernard Shaw's chosen cinematic interpreter, has signed a deal with R.K.O. to produce three pictures at the studio here, the first to be "Androcles and the Lion," Pascal disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1--Television passed a notable milestone this New Year's Day with the first public test of phonevision, or payas-you-look TV. Phonevision is the Zenith Radio Corporation's system for giving television a "boxoffice" through its combination with the telephone.
Basic commodity prices have had a pronounced upswing since the outbreak of the Korean War. Superimposed on earlier advances, present price levels are their highest since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The Soviet Union's reply to the suggestions by the United States, Britain and France for a consultation on outstanding differences was received by the State... Department today, and there were unofficial intimations that the Moscow note was far from satisfactory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill to increase corporation taxes by $3,300,000,000 a year, chiefly through a 77 per cent levy on excess profits.

Cooperation between industry and colleges in providing practical training for present and potential business men made considerable strides last year. Hundreds of trade associations are now actively cooperating with colleges all over the country in offering business courses in concentrated day and evening sessions of a few weeks or months.

BALTIMORE--The Baltimore area had its best business year since World War II in 1950 and business interests expect 1951 to be even better, barring another widespread war. This expectation is based on the expansion of industry for fuller production for defense.

BERLIN, Jan. 1--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, predicted today an acceleration of measures restoring Western Germany to its place in the world community and announced the impending opening of talks on that area's contribution to Western European defense.

CAIRO, Jan. 1--The idea of a grand alliance for the defense of the Middle East has taken hold here in the past few days. There is evidence that the prevalent strong neutrality sentiment and isolationism found in the Arab world may be placed under attack.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 1 (AP) --Edward C. Ely, retired business man of New York and Norwich, Conn., and winter resident of Charleston, was killed today while hunting on James Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--President Truman returned to the Capital this afternoon aboard the yacht Williamsburg, ending a three-day cruise. The President and his party, most of whom were members of his official staff, docked at the Naval Gun Factory pier at 4:10 P.M.

Investors in real estate securities had on the average a profitable year during 1950, according to the Amott-Baker realty bond price averages.

Aside from volume records in many lines of durable goods last year, progress was made in reducing costs and in improving technical processes and designs. At the year's end, industry was prepared for a bigger role in national mobilization than in World War II.

HARTFORD, Jan. 1--Finances and civilian defense will be the major issues facing Connecticut's General, Assembly when it convenes Wednesday for the inauguration of Republican Gov.-elect John Davis Lodge and to start its fivemonth regular session. Mr. Lodge will succeed Gov. Chester Bowles, Democrat.
With the Korean crisis and rearmament stockpiling boosting imports to a record high, an historic shift marked the foreign trade of the United States in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP)-- The Federal Government's voluntary price control program is making slow progress, a survey showed today. Only a relative handful of big business firms were found either to have rolled back price increases or agreed to give warning that they were planned.

WASHINGTON--The "bold new" Point Four program for bringing help to underdeveloped areas of the world moved cautiously ahead in 1950, but it still has a long way to go before the results are noticeable.

Television receiver production last year hit a record level of 6,500,000 to 7,000,000 units, a gain of almost 100 per cent over 1949. Retail dollar volume also set a record of $2,000,000,000, approximately double the 1949 total.

The Broad of Education, to get the most for its money, should appoint a director to coordinate its vast building program, the Publice Education Association declared yesterday.

January and February will be the crucial period in the city's efforts to meet its quota of whole blood and plasma for the armed forces, Brig. Gen. Charles M. Walson, administrator of the Greater New York Red Cross Blood Program, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)-- "Fighting Mary" is taking down from her office walls the array of news cartoons that portrayed the high spots of her twenty-six years in Congress.
HONOLULU--Hawaii's economic condition, which was described by one economist early in 1950 as "unfavorable but not dangerous," improved markedly during the latter half of the year.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 2--The Communist enemy launched heavy attacks yesterday against United Nations lines in Korea, and Allied forces pulled back as much as six miles in some areas to prepared positions north of the Republican capital at Seoul.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP)--Sterling Smith, stocky guard from Greenville, S.C., tackled Miami's Frank Smith behind the goal line for a safety today to give the unbeaten Clemson Tigers a 15-14 victory, in the seventeenth annual Orange Bowl football game.

BERLIN, Jan. 1--Elaborate ceremonies at Fuerstenberg on the Oder today formally opened a fiveyear plan in the Soviet zone through which the people of Eastern Germany have been assured their area's economic output will be multiplied and rationing will disappear.

The nation's paper industry appeared certain to have set a new high in production of paper and paperboard, on the basis of incomplete figures for 1950.

Walbridge Smith Taft, a nephew of former President William Howard Taft and a prominent lawyer and yachtsman, died of heart disease early yesterday morning at his home, 1 Sutton Place South. He was 65 years old.
LONDON--When Sir Stafford Cripps drafted his last budget he outlined an economic policy for the 1950-51 fiscal year that would bar an increase in public spending.
PANAMA--All Central American countries except Panama and Honduras benefited by the high prices for coffee in 1950.
Ernest Ansermet, one of the finest and most sensitise musicians who note wields a baton, conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra as its guest leader last night in Carnegie Hall.

QUITO, Ecuador--Domestic business and international trade improved in 1950 in Ecuador. Larger crops and higher prices for cocoa, coffee and bananas are expected to bring the value of exports to $49,000,000 for the year.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 2-- A "statistically dead" child was still alive tonight after a plastic surgeon had removed 288 square inches of skin from the bodies of five men and a woman and transferred it to the severely burned body of 8-year-old Susan Latonick.

HONG KONG, Jan. 2--The dictatorial side of Mao Tse-tung's "people's democratic dictatorship" in Communist China has emerged in sharper perspective since the Peiping regime's military intervention in Korea.
PRETORIA, South Africa--Two related factors dominated South African economy in 1950--import control and the rising cost of living. At present there is likelihood of only a slight easing of either.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia--During the first year of its independence the new Indonesian nation in 1950 passed through a turbulent period both economically and politically.

TOKYO--The Japanese Commuunist party virtually went underground last year when Gen. Douglas MacArthur "purged" its twenty-four top leaders, including all members of the central committee, and ordered indefinite suspension of its official organ, Akahata (The Red Flag).
ZURICH, Switzerland--Though the Swiss tourist trade suffered from the wave of monetary devaluation in 1949, total revenue from it was higher than in 1949.

PARIS--The major emphasis of the Economic Cooperation Administration program here is now centered on increasing as rapidly as possible man-hour output and productivity generally in French industry, especially in plants vital to the rearmament drive.

MEXICO CITY--Mining production, Mexico's greatest source of wealth from exports, was slightly higher in 1950 than in the preceding year and the nationalized petroleum industry boasted of a substantial increase in output that was attained without the aid of foreign or domestic loans.

ALBANY, Jan. 2--The Court of Appeals reserved decision today on a move by W. WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--When Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the Democratic majority leader, delivered his farewell address to the Senate this afternoon, he appealed to his own Administration to give the American people "all the information which is possible without jeopardizing our safety and security."

ASUNCION, Paraguay--An era of relative political stability after a two-year period during which Paraguay had six Presidents was reflected in a generally improved economic and financial outlook in 1950.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an average gain of 3 per cent in December, compared with the same month in 1949, according to the survey yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

That the Communist-dominated American Labor party has reached the lowest point in enrolled membership in the fourteen years of its history, figures released by the Board of Elections showed yesterday.

Coast-to-coast television, with Hollywood programs being seen "live" in New York, appeared a virtual certainty for 1951 with the announcement yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company that it had placed an order for the use of such facilities.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2--President Juan Peron today pardoned his severest critic, Dr. Ricardo Balbin, who had been Argentina's No. 1 political prisoner since March 12, 1950. On Nov. 22 he had been sentenced to five years for disrespect toward the President.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Senate passed and sent to President Truman for final approval today a bill to set up immediately an integrated Federal-state civil defense system.

Thousands of aliens in New York registered yesterday, on the first day as required under the Federal Internal Security Act of 1950.

ALBANY, Jan. 2--A sharp difference of opinion with respect to the future course of state residential rent control has developed among top advisers of Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders. BRUSSELS, Belgium--Belgium maintained her high standard of living in 1950, finishing the year with the highest production and foreign trade figures in her history.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2-- Maxwell W. Becton, a founder and trustee of Fairleigh Dickinson College here, died today at his home, 140 Ridge Road, after an illness of several years. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Senate Democrats, with the Southerners holding decisive power, elected tonight a moderate Western-Southern leadership to guide them in the new Congress opening tomorrow. The all-out Fair Dealers were outvoted nearly 2 to 1.

TAIPEI, Formosa--Aided by the Economic Cooperation Administration, which has brought in adequate artificial fertilizers and helped with irrigation, Formosa has smashed every record for rice production made in the years of Japanese control.
LISBON, Portugal--There was general improvement in Portuguese economic life in 1950 in strong contrast with conditions in 1949.
WORTHING, England, Jan. 3 (Reuters)--Henry Baynton, Shakespearean actor who played Hamlet 2,000 times, died at his home here last night at the age of 58. He underwent a throat operation recently.

Zoe de Salle came back to her fashion audience yesterday, after an absence of several seasons, with a small but pleasing collection executed in her individual and timeless style. While she has not changed her style technique, the style of her dresses keeps right up with the times.

After an ownership of only a few days, Frederick Brown, operator, has resold the one-story taxpayer at Cross Island Parkway and Fourteenth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens, to an investor represented by the H.D. Lehds Company, broker.
The finest of our feathered friends went on display yesterday at the Greater New York Poultry Exposition, which opened for five days at Grand Central Palace.

In a sweeping reorganization of most of the top uniformed command of the Fire Department, Commissioner George P. Monaghan abolished yesterday the position of Chief of Staff and Operations, since 1946 the highest uniformed post of the department. Eighteen other "staff and operations" titles went into the discard.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP)-- Possibility that participation of the Pacific Coast Conference in annual Rose Bowl football games might be discontinued rocked the organization at its meeting today.

Three veterans of the Korean War, two of them convalescing from wounds, showed Marine Corps recruits yesterday the first North Korean flag captured by the Marines. The ceremony at the corps' recruiting headquarters, 346 Broadway, was held on the eve of a national drive for volunteers.
Brooklyn longshoremen returned to work yesterday afternoon at the Isthmian Line's Erie Basin Breakwater's terminal, after a one-day stoppage of loading operations of the freighter Steel Scientist.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3--Albert S. Howell, whose inventions contributed much to development of the motion-picture industry, died today in Ravenswood Hospital after a brief illness. He was 71 years old. He was co-founder of Bell Howell Company, Chicago, manufacturers of motion-picture and photographic equipment.
