WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- The Government got through the first half of the fiscal year of 1951 --marking the first six months of the Korean war--with a budget deficit of $599,354,042,85, the Treasury reported today.

Advancing prices on fresh meats and vegetables, the expense of setting the holiday table and the generally increased expenditures induced by Christmas have all combined to bruise household budgets. It seemed tactful, in consideration of this, to turn attention today to low-cost main dishes.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 3 --The office of the United States High Commissioner has formally decided to transfer its headquarters to Bonn and prepare for the establishment of an embassy at the site of the West German Federal capital, probably this summer.

Plans for a $6,500,000 aquarium at Coney Island have been shelved "until better days come along," Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society, told 1,500 persons at the society's fiftyfifth annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

Net current operating earnings of the National City Bank of New York in the year ended Dec. 31 amounted to $21,429,706, compared with $20,416,771 in 1949, according to the annual report published today.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 2--If a world war comes, Singapore and Malaya plan to be prepared and hope to withstand any outside attack that potential Communist enemies could mount in their present circumstances.

A series of weekly radio concerts by the Boston "Pops" Orchestra will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company, beginning Monday, Jan. 29, from 10 to 11 P.M. The move is in contrast with a general decline of serious music carried by the major radio networks.

Proceeds from a sale of secondhand comic books were contributed yesterday by a group of Brooklyn school children to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 3 (AP) --The United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed today a lower court decision which permitted railroads to restrict the hiring of Negroes as firemen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP)-- House food investigators reported today that a new chemical food control law might be needed to protect consumers from being gradually poisoned by the food they ate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3--The General Electric Company exhibited at the American Furniture Mart today its new ultra-modern New World Kitchen, which incorporates facilities for cooking, laundering, dining, living and playing.

ALBANY, Jan. 3--The State's Legislative Rent Commission agreed unanimously today on a new law to validate freeze regulations already promulgated by Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, and now under challenge in the courts.

ALBANY, Jan. 3--The State's lawmakers, convening here today for the 174th session of the Legislature, introduced 197 bills, including nine measures carrying out proposals urged by Governor Dewey in his annual message and six bills that reflected concern over safety on the Long Island Rail Road. On the opening day a year ago 262 bills were offered.

General Eisenhower leaves on Saturday to take up his duties as Supreme Commander of the Western defense forces. His assumption of that office marks the conjunction of a unique mission and the man chosen by twelve nations as the best fitted to accomplish it.

PARIS, Jan. 3--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's European tour of inspection, for which he will leave Washington by air Saturday, will include brief visits to the capital of each member country of the North Atlantic defense pact. The tour will be conducted to emphasize strongly his role as a supreme Allied commander responsible in equal measure to all twelve of the pact signatories.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday in an injunction action that would determine whether Edward T. McCaffrey, city License Commissioner, has the right to ban the showing in the city of "The Miracle," Italian-language film. The film recently won, as part of a trilogy, the Film Critics Award as the best movie import of the year.

PARIS, Jan. 3--The French Cabinet decided today to urge Washington and London to do everything possible to obtain the fourpower foreign ministers' conference for which they believed Moscow's note, broadcast yesterday, had left the door open. A draft proposal for a reply to the Soviet Union will be sent to the United States and British Governments.

Smooth-running Hugo Maiocco sent the 1951 indoor track season off to a flying start last night by equaling the fastest time ever recorded for 600 yards on a flat floor. The 23-year-old New York University pre-medical student raced home in 1:11.7 in winning the John J. Deignan Memorial 600 at the Metropolitan A.A.U. open meet at the Third Engineer Group Armory.
Broadway opening dates for two productions were announced yesterday.

Ambassador Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, pledged yesterday that this nation "will not abandon Asia to tyranny." He promised further that "we will help Western Europe build up its defenses."

Twenty-two men who worked in minor jobs for Harry Gross, reputed boss of a $20,000,000 gambling ring that it is charged shared profits with policemen, pleaded guilty in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn yesterday to charges of conspiracy and of bookmaking. They are to be sentenced on Jan. 30.

DETROIT, Jan. 3--Joe Louis took a long stride on the comeback trail tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3--All deliveries of corn, rye and soybeans and May and September oats sold at new seasonal highs on the Board of Trade as the result of a broad buying movement, and closing trades were about at the top.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--President Truman realigned the mobilization chain of command today to suit his new director, Charles E. Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- The volume of installment credit dropped $74,000,000 in November, marking the first decline for that pre-Christmas month since 1943, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Boro Construction Corporation, Harold Levine, president, which recently completed the onestory taxpayer building at 2815-29 White Plains Road, the Bronx, sold it to an investing client of Max Lubin, attorney, the builders reported yesterday.

For the first time since 1941 the Camp Fire Girls, Inc., is planning to revise its budget charts for youngsters, placing the accent on money management instead of "just plain thrift."

The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steelproducing company, announced yesterday the purchase of a large tract of land in the Paulsboro, N.J., area on the Delaware River, about ten miles south of Camden, as the site for a new major mill. It would be the third large steel facility on the East Coast.

Fred Wilt, the New York Athletic Club's crack distance runner, yesterday was announced as the 1950 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy. This award is presented each year by the Amateur Athletic Union to the "amateur athlete who, by performance, example and good influence, did most to advance the cause of good sportsmanship."

The Dodgers, who mailed out their player contracts a full month earlier than was their custom in the days of Branch Rickey's regime, yesterday announced their first two signers for the 1951 campaign. Clair Bee's Long Island University quintet risks its eight-game winning streak tonight when it tackles Bowling Green, twicebeaten in nine games, in the feature of the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the opener at 7:45 o'clock, New York University plays North Carolina.
Willard Ingham Emerson, a New York investment banker, has been appointed vice president of Cornell University in charge of development.

Bianchi, Republican of Manhattan, who was elected last November with American Labor party support.

To insure enough meat and potatoes for New Yorkers in case of a possible atomic attack, 250 key men in the food and transportation industries here are poring like military strategists over charts and pin studded maps.

The underwear industry, which during the last war produced 720,000,000 military undergarments "is prepared to top that record this time if called on to do so," Roy A. Cheney, president of the Underwear Institute, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3(AP)--The special House Campaign Expenditures Committee reported today there was apparently no basis for "questioning the accuracy" of the vote tabulation in which Mr. Macy lost to Mr. Greenwood.

The American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, which for many years have combated prejudice and discrimination and promoted better group relations in this country, will start a nationwide drive for $6,000,000 on Feb. 1 to carry out their 1951 activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--President Truman today appointed Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, who was defeated for re-election last November after an eighteen-year Senate career, as High Commissioner of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--Representative Claude E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, author of a bill that resulted in sale of six war-surplus vessels to Great Lake operators, said today, he felt the measure had brought only a step in the right direction.

A general tightness in free supplies, due to the reluctance of big packers to sell in the current period of price uncertainty, forced hide futures into new high territory on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Short interests seeking to cover their commitments found offerings scarce.

The best spring season for sales of bridal gowns in history was predicted yesterday by manufacturers at the opening of the first National Bridal Show in the New Yorker Hotel. The exhibition, open to the trade only, will run daily through next Thursday from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and rose 24 to 40 points.

Victories in the sixth round for Wolfgang Unzicker of Germany and Nicholas Rossolimo of France kept these two players in front yesterday in the international masters tournament at the annual Hastings Chess Congress, according to a report from England.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, announced today that he would open hearings next Tuesday on a bill he introduced today to authorize the construction of an aircraft carrier not to exceed 60,000 ton-displacement.

Delays in mail and parcel post delivery have slowed down New York business, caused losses, added to operational costs and compelled some companies to use more expensive methods of communication, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York charged yesterday on the basis of a survey of 357 concerns.

Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich urged all important city-wide organizations yesterday to join the campaign to recruit 500,000 civil defense volunteers to protect New York and its residents against the effects of any atomic bomb attack. The drive started yesterday throughout the city.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (UP)--Sir George Lenthal Cheatle, consulting surgeon and emeritus lecturer on surgery at King's College, died yesterday, at his home in Bushey, Hertfordshire. His age was 85. Research on the pathology of cancer, particularly breast cancer, was his best-known work.

The stock market ran into profit taking yesterday after an early burst of strength. Gains which ran to about a point in early transactions melted quickly and losses ensued, with the composite rate down 0.43 point at the close.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The Senate, with reservations, permitted John M. Butler, Republican of Maryland, conqueror of the veteran Democrat Millard E. Tydings, to take the oath as Senator today.

LONDON, Jan. 3--Possibilities for the improvement of relations between the Western nations and Communist China will be explored by the conference of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers, meeting here tomorrow.

A Government witness at the perjury trial of William W. Remington admitted in Federal Court yesterday that he had concealed his own Communist party membership in his successful application for a Navy commission in 1943.

Formation of the American Financial and Development Corporation for Israel, which will be in charge of flotation of an Israeli bond issue in the United States, was announced yesterday along with initial plans for sale of the issue. WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--President Truman signed the Excess Profits Tax Act of 1950 today and notified the country anew that the defense program would require still "more and much heavier" levies.

William Church Osborn, for many years one of the leading civic benefactors of this city and former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday afternoon in his home at 720 Park Avenue. His age was 88.

PARIS, Dec. 30--The Soviet press and some of its Cominform imitators are celebrating the promise that a new canal linking the Volga River at Stalingrad with the Don River at Kalatch will be opened to navigation in 1952--two years ahead of schedule.
LONDON, Jan. 4--The advance in the stock markets here today was more restrained than yesterday. The news from Korea induced a note of caution which was reflected in profit-taking in oils.

George Szell had the welcome inspiration to open the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall with the overture and three of the pieces of Mendelssohn's incidental music to "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

WHEN Enid Bagnold was only 19 years old her first book was published, a diary of her experiences as a nurse in a military hospital during the first World War. WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--A French industrialist and a woman who described herself as formerly his bitter enemy testified from the same platform today to the virtues of moral rearmament.
The reimposition of severe French censorship in Saigon obscures but cannot hide the increasing seriousness of the situation in French Indo-China.

The United Cerebral Palsy Association at 50 West Fiftyseventh Street is having Christmas all over again. Ever since it first issued an appeal for discarded Christmas cards on Dec. 29, the second "Christmas rush" was on.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 4--Cornelius C. Moore, prominent local attorney, today was elected president of the 147-year-old Newport National Bank at a special meeting of the board of directors.
Few men have made so rich and varied a contribution to their community as William Church Osborn. He brought vitality, intelligence and a deep sense of humanity to every civic task he undertook.

The "tidal wave of world politics" in the last year has brought "a deluge of new responsibilities" to the city's hospitals, Commissioner Marcus D. Kogel said yesterday in an annual message to medical boards and superintendents under his command.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--The Legislature was asked today to declare it to be the policy of the state that employers should not discriminate against persons subject to induction under the Selective Service Act.

After providing most of the skilands from the Pennsylvania Poconos to the Laurentians of Eastern Canada with their finest snow conditions in many years during the past week-end, the elements swept away the prospects for the next few days.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 4 --Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Sue, to John E. Dunn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dunn of Somerville, N.J. The wedding has been planned for June.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--A special House committee today reported widespread irregularities in the $11,000,000,000 G.I. education and training program administered by the Veterans Administration.

In view of the shortcomings of New York State's present correctional system for dealing with youthful male offenders, a sweeping reorganization of the system was proposed yesterday in a twoyear report made public by the Community Service Society.
The response to the call for 500,000 civil defense volunteers in this city has been "very good," Grover A. Whalen, Coordinator of Recruiting and Public Information, reported yesterday.
Youngsters and adults in many areas of the country sent their gifts yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to aid children mentioned in this year's appeal.

Mayor Impellitteri's day at City Hall yesterday included a greeting to the ninety-four member Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, acceptance of the honorary chairmanship of Brotherhood Week in the city, a proclamation for the Big Brothers and a salute to the "Catholic Man of the Year."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4-- "Canela," a screen story by Vincent Evans, has been purchased by Santana Productions, the Humphrey Bogart-Robert Lord company at Columbia, for filming next fall, with Bogart and his wife, Lauren Bacall, as the stars.
The Congress of Industrial Organizations took direct action yesterday to bolster wavering trade unions in Western Europe and to tie them to the side of democracy in the fight against communism.

DETROIT, Jan. 4--When Joe Louis battered Freddie Beshore into defeat in four rounds of their scheduled ten-round bout at Olympia last night he created a problem for his handlers and officials of the International Boxing Club.
The city administration and Westchester County gave their unqualified support yesterday to the plan of the State Thruway Authority to build its controversial bridge across the Tappan Zee.

Lilli Palmer is the new treat of TV. The actress, who currently is brightening the Broadway scene with her performance in "Bell, Book and Candle," made her debut in a regular video program of her own last night (6:45 P.M. on C.B.S. video) and she was completely beguiling.
Club owners of the National League will meet here next Thursday to discuss the radio and television problem which their minor league brothers insist is the cause of their attendance decline.
MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (U.P.)--World newsprint production capacity will pass its 1939 level of 10,578,904 tons this year for the first time, the Newsprint Association of Canada said today.

A $4,020-a-year provisional engineer in the Department of Housing and Buildings, who had banked more than $10,000 since 1947, was dismissed from his job yesterday after he refused to sign a waiver of immunity before a grand jury investigating his financial affairs.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--An agreement has been reached between the state and the Veterans Administration whereby the latter will complete the vacating of Halloran Hospital on Staten Island by Feb. 15 to make room for elderly mental hygiene patients who are being moved out of special quarters at the Sampson Naval Training Base in Geneva, N.Y.
Maintenance of high ethical standards in the selling and advertising of hearing aids will be the objective of a new program now getting under way among manufacturers.

Hailed as the largest, fastest and safest double-ended ferryboat ever built, the Pvt. Joseph F. Merrell, named for Staten Island's only Medal of Honor winner in World War II, was delivered to the city yesterday morning by the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Steel warehouses here are unable to fill as many as ninety to one hundred orders a week from defense plants because the "Defense Order" priority system is not geared to take care of needed replacements of distributors' stocks. Now warehousemen report that inventories are averaging about 40 per cent of quantities needed to properly fill current orders from essential users.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--More than 1,000 bills and resolutions were dropped into the legislative hopper of the House of Representatives on the opening day of the Eighty-second Congress yesterday. The precise count was 1,023. The total on the first day of the Eighty-first Congress on Jan. 3, 1949, was 622.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--Banks subject to the supervision of the State Banking Department had a banner year in 1950, William A. Lyon, State Superintendent of Banks, told the legislature today in his annual report. Profits, loan volume and deposits all were at record levels, he said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP)--The heroic story of the last stand of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, the Korean war's first Medal of Honor winner, was told officially and for the first time today by the Army.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Despite all the talk of a general war in Western Europe during 1951, the United States Government is not basing its rearmament or strategic plans on that assumption.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., Jan. 4 (AP)-- A powerful Australian crew scored a second straight victory over California's famed eight today to win the major rowing title in the Canterbury centennial games.

The stock market continued yesterday to operate from a purely technical standpoint and recovered a considerable portion of the losses incurred on Wednesday. As the market went to about the best levels in twenty years, the steel issues took command of the situation on the New York Stock Exchange and scored gains well in excess of the average.

Sally Victor offers lots of headliners at her millinery showing yesterday in her newly decorated showroom at 18 East Fifty-third Street. Just to indicate how "heady" they were we will name of a few of her 1951 ideas right at the start.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The House Small Business Committee said today that the lack of a coordinated anti-trust program was hampering the Federal Government's fight against monopolies.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP)--Algasir captured the feature before a crowd of 7,900 at Tropical Park today. The five-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III carried the colors of H.A. Kimball to a length decision over Whiffenpoof in a swift 1:04 4/5 for the five and onehalf furlongs.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 4-- Harry G. Haskell, a director and former vice president and member of the executive and finance committees of E.I. du Pont de Nemour Co., Inc., died in his home here today at the age of 80. He had retired from company activities other than his directorship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Administration's assurance that labor would have a voice in top policy making for shipping in time of full emergency was given to fifteen representatives of seafaring unions here today.
The city Department of Parks, which has just begun its ninth annual lifeguard training course, is experiencing considerable difficulty in finding enough lifeguards, it appeared yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the Exchange here yesterday was firm and closed 10 to 38 points net higher than on Wednesday.
DETROIT, Jan. 4--The core of America's industrial arsenal, the automobile industry, is waiting eagerly to be told what the Government wants in the national emergency.

A sizable group of admirers gathered in Town Hall last night to hear the recital debut of Frederick Griesinger, pianist, who is on the faculty of Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore. They showed much enjoyment of the performance and of three new selections offered on the program.

Stockholders of the Bates Manufacturing Company at a special meeting on Jan. 30 will vote on the directors' proposal to increase the authorized capital stock from 391,500 to 3,000,000 shares, primarily to permit the payment of a 350 per cent stock dividend.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 5--The Chinese and North Korean enemy drove at United Nations troops in Korea on two fronts yesterday after the recapture of Seoul, capital of the South Korean Republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Bills to put into effect Administration plans to speed a multi-billion dollar defense housing program will be introduced Monday immediately after President Truman delivers his State of the Union Message.

Although Erno Fabry, who created the contemporary furniture introduced yesterday by Fabry Associates, 6 East Fiftythird Street, has lived in this country for more than ten years, certain stylistic traits in his work reveal a Middle European background in design.

While most meats are unchanged in price since last Friday, beef is up from 2 to 6 cents a pound. Lamb is holding steady at retail, but on the Chicago live market a record high of $33.50 a hundredweight was reached yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4--Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade here today after an early advance had carried all deliveries of gran and soybeans except July and September wheat and July oats to new highs for the season, with the cash articles keeping pace with the futures.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 4 --For reasons having nothing directly to do with higher wages or better working conditions the managing board of the West German Metal Workers' Union has ordered a strike of its 500,000 members on Feb. 1.

Indeterminate penitentiary sentences up to three years were imposed yesterday in General Sessions on four young men who had pleaded guilty to petty larceny while they were on trial on charges of first-degree rape, first-degree robbery and third-degree assualt.

Servel, Inc., manufacturers of 450,000 gas refrigerators in this city, has started an extensive program to provide "safe and efficient" operation of the appliances in homes here, the Department of Health announced yesterday.

Besides disobedience of signals, which appears to have been the immediate cause of the wreck at Kew Gardens on Nov. 22, 1950, and at Rockville Centre on Feb. 17, 1950, our investigation revealed other facts and practices that are inimical to safe operation.

North American Aviation, Inc., manufacturer of airplanes and accessories, is geared for greatly accelerated engineering and production activities this year, J.H. Kindelberger, chairman of the board, asserted yesterday in announcing increased earnings in the annual report.
Conflicting policies were found yesterday among colleges here on the granting or denial of academic credit to students who enlist in the armed services.

It was to be expected that Sarah Churchill, daughter of Britain's wartime leader, Winston Churchill, who acted on the summer circuit in "The Philadelphia Story" and subsequently toured in the same play, eventually would make her Broadway stage debut.
Charles V. Rich, who retired in 1921 as an executive manager of the National City Bank, died on Wednesday in his home at 300 Park Avenue. His age was 69.

Miss Edith Ann Skillings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kingsley Skillings of 59 East Fiftyfourth Street, and Bass Rocks, Gloucester, Mass., was married to Lieut. Lawrence William Ward, U.S.M.C.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Lawrence Ward of Stanford, Me., and Boston, yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

William W. Remington used the official Communist party post office box in Knoxville, Tenn., as a mailing address while he lived in Knoxville in 1937, a Government witness testified yesterday at Remington's perjury trial in Federal Court.

An increase last week of 4,064,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies amounted to 116,695,000 barrels, compared with 112,631,000 a week earlier and 113,497,000 a year ago.

The commission for Chinese living outside of China, which has its headquarters in Peiping, has issued a call to organize strong united fronts against "imperialist oppression." Yesterday's Pravda of Moscow gives us the text. It appears that "inhuman arrests and mass exile by imperialists of our [Chinese] compatriots living abroad during recent years have...

The scene of many accidents and traffic jams, a stretch of Grand Central Parkway between Horace Harding Boulevard and Kew Gardens Loop, Queens County, is to be widened and resurfaced. Improvements costing $2,618,000 have been authorized by the state Department of Public Works and the work is to begin early in the spring. Completion is expected by the end of the year.

ONE player move which received little notice during the explosive winter baseball meet ings at St. Pete was the unobtrusive acquisition of Pistol Pete Reiser by the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Braves relinquished all claims on the Pistol and declared him a free agent. Thereupon Branch Rickey, desperate for some wartime insurance, grabbed him for the Pirates who already have lost two regulars to the armed forces and expect to yield still more.

"Riddles in the Sky," the January program at the Hayden Planetarium, describes many celestial phenomena from the origin of comets to flying saucers. Afternoon shows are at 2 and 3:30 o'clock Monday through Friday and hourly from 2 to 5 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, Admission for children 40 cents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, did not threaten to kick President Truman in the teeth, although it appeared as if he had during a few breathless moments of the White House news conference today.

With the beginning of the year the Saar entered upon a new phase of its existence. For fifteen years after the First World War the mines were controlled by the French and the Government was administered by the League of Nations.
The Public Service Commission found yesterday that recommendations of the Interstate Commerce Commission for restoring safe operation on the Long Island Rail Road were "inadequate."

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy banned yesterday the sale of advertising and "booster" space in journals of Police Department organizations published in connection with annual social functions. The practice of selling such space, the commissioner asserted, "opens the door to abuses."
The temple bells still play in Southeast Asia, but the people are singing new songs of freedom and independence, Mrs. Laura Boulton, a blonde explorer and musicologist, reported yesterday.

ALTHOUGH there are still quite a number of opponents of "preserve" hunting, the fact remains that each passing year finds this form of shooting attracting more and more of the so-called "one-gallus" gunners.

Adding half a point to his total as a result of a draw with Henry Golombek, former British champion, in the seventh round yesterday, Wolfgang Unzicker of Germany went into the lead in the international masters' tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings, according to a report from England.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 4--Another Cabinet crisis threatened Israel today on the question of the education of immigrant children.
Joseph F. Berlinger of 915 Hollywood Boulevard, Hollywood, Fla., a retired textile manufacturer, died Wednesday night in Hollywood, after an illness of several months.

Hank Bauer, the slugging exMarine of the Yankee outfield, dropped in on General Manager George M. Weiss yesterday from his home in Kansas City and forthwith provided the Bombers with news both good and perhaps not so good.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4--The appointment of former New York Mayor William O'Dwyer, as United States Ambassador to Mexico has helped to cement Mexico-United States relations and to accentuate the Good Neighbor policy.

KALIMPONG, India, Jan. 4-- Travelers from Tibet reported here today that an eight-man Communist delegation had arrived in Lhasa for talks with the Lord Chamberlain, or Kungko Khanpo, who was left behind to run the Government when the 15-year-old Dalai Lama left the Forbidden City for Yatung, last outpost of his domain, near the Sikkim border.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 4--The former Bell Aircraft plant at Marietta, Ga., which cost an estimated $73,000,000 and turned out nearly 700 B-29's in World War II, will be reopened by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation at the request of the United States Air Force.

Plans for the appointment of a Construction expert to speed up the city's school building program were announced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri. He spoke at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--Michael Kern, counsel for Harry Gross, reputed head of a $20,000,000 Brooklyn bookmaking ring, told the Court of Appeals today that bail of $250,000 had been imposed upon his client "for the purpose of extorting a confession."

There were two debuts last night at the Metropolitan Opera House as the Garson Kanin-Howard Dietz version of "Die Fledermaus" had its fourth performance of the season. Marguerite Piazza, New Orleans-born soprano, made her first appearance in the theatre in the role of Rosalinda, and Tibor Kozma, born in Hungary and a resident of this country for nine years, made his bow as a conductor.

An "all-out nation-wide cooperation of every kind of organization" with the Point Four program was urged last night by Dr. Frank C. Laubach, counselor and representative of the Committee on World Literacy and Christian Literature of the National Council of the Churches of Christ.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4--More than 250 members of Local 333-A, Tugboat Workers Union, went on strike here today in an effort to enforce wage demands.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--Speedy legislative approval of Governor Dewey's recommendations for putting this state on a war footing was forecast today. Except for a few details they are noncontroversial in nature.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Friday, Jan. 5 (UP)-- Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, commander of the United States Eighth Army, said today after visiting the new United Nations defense line south of the Han River that "everything is going fine up there."

NEWARK, Jan. 4--Judgments totaling $3,050,347 against a syndicate of twelve individuals and one business concern that sold two Delaware River toll bridges to Burlington County in October 1948, for $12,000,000 were approved today by Superior Court Judge Walter J. Freund.

Long Island University stayed unbeaten last night. But before Clair Bee's team toppled Bowling Green, 69--63, for its ninth straight triumph, Blackbird supporters among the 8,139 spectators at Madison Square Garden had quite a scare.

The one-story taxpayer building containing fifteen stores at 24-02 to 24-30 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, has been sold by Oscar Bregman, Arnold Steinberg and associates to Sahag S. Girithon and associates for cash above mortgages of $425,000. The property occupies an irregular plot about 115 by 259 feet. Louis Landsman was the broker. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

AN AIR BASE, in Southern Japan, Friday, Jan. 5--The Air Force's Combat Cargo Command continued to supply the withdrawing United Nations forces, despite yesterday's loss of the valuable Kimpo Airfield near Seoul. Today's schedule calls for forty-nine airdrops of supplies to troops in central Korea and the flying in of unspecified planeloads to Wonju Airfield, approximately fifty-five miles southeast of fallen Seoul.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)-- Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona, new Democratic leader in the Senate, appointed tonight members of the steering committee that will make the party's assignments to legislative committees. He was elected floor leader by the Democrats to succeed Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, who was defeated in the November election.

Special squads of picked detectives have been sent into the Greenwich Village and Lower Fifth Avenue sections to combat a series of burglaries that has occurred there in the last few months and, particularly, over the recent holiday week-ends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Archibald S. Alexander, Under Secretary of the Army, said tonight that new tanks soon to come off the production lines were expected to be "far superior to anything known in their class anywhere."

The announcement last month that the Navy was putting the 12,000-ton aircraft carrier Langley back into commission and then planned to transfer it to the French Navy was followed yesterday by the arrival from Paris of a forty-five man contingent of French naval personnel, who will be trained at the Philadelphia Navy Yard to operate the ship.
A typical family of four on the city's relief rolls soon will be receiving $10 a month more than it does now.
PADUCAH, Ky., Jan. 4 (AP)--The Tennessee Valley Authority will build a steam electric power plant on the Kentucky side of the Ohio River about 15 miles northwest of Paducah, it was announced today.

Methods of furthering the interests of the theatre on a national basis were recommended yesterday at the fifth and final session of the First National Theatre Assembly, convened by the American National Theatre and Academy, the Congress-chartered theatrical organization, at the Fulton Theatre.

TIENYEN, Indo-China, Jan. 4 (AP)--French forces began an offensive today. They moved from coastal positions into the mountains near the Chinese border to engage Communist-led Vietminh concentrations there or drive them away.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 4 --Progress toward a German contribution to the defense of Western Europe has been virtually halted by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's concern over West German public opinion, which is forcing him toward talks on unity with the Communist government of Eastern Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower warned today that sacrifices would be the price of freedom of the Western world and called on European nations to match the sincerity of purpose of the United States in devoting its resources to the common defense.
Yesterday being Thursday, known as "Maid's Day Out," many domestics in this area spent their time getting their Social Security numbers for the new household tax.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
Red Cross blood donor centers were crowded here yesterday with volunteers responding to an emergency appeal for blood to be flown to Korea.

Large American producers of bituminous coal are about ready to ask the Government to release fifty cargo vessels from the "mothball fleet" now needed to provide bottoms for meeting export coal demands of European and Japanese industries.

HARTFORD, Jan. 4--The first day of the Republican administration of Gov. John Davis Lodge passed quietly today, in contrast with the turbulent scenes in the State House yesterday when his inauguration was delayed many hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican of Oregon, said today he had asked the National Labor Relations Board to explain why it planned to seek court enforcement of its order against the International Typographical Union, A.F.L., in the long-standing cases brought by newspaper publishers and the printing industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--President Truman said today that this country probably would not bomb Communist China without a formal declaration of war by Congress. He made it clear, however, that the United States had no present intention of making such an attack.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 --Two representatives of the United States Government have arrived in Belgrade to examine the possibility of procuring Yugoslav strategic raw materials for the United States defense stockpiling program.

The news from Korea grows grimmer day by day. Once again, as in the beginning of the Korean campaign, the army of the United Nations is in retreat. It is in an orderly and fighting retreat, characterized by Secretary of Defense Marshall as being "almost exactly as anticipated."

Mr. and Mrs. R. McAllister Lloyd of 215 East Seventy-second Street and Happy Hollow, New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor, to William Lloyd Helm Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Helm of Gray Barn, New Canaan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, author of the World War II Nurse Cadet Corps Act, today introduced a long-range bill for nursing education. It contemplates expenditure of about $47,000,000 in its first full year of operation.

In the last fifty years the number of Jewish children enrolled in Jewish schools has increased from 45,000 to 266,609, according to the results of a survey completed by the American Association for Jewish Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--The nation's scheduled airline industry hit new highs in all divisions in 1950, the Air Transport Association reported today.

A raiding party from the office of Chief Inspector August W. Flath, using a policewoman as a decoy, made three arrests last night in a midtown Broadway cafe in which they charged a bookmaking business was being carried on at the rate of $100,000 a week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The president of a Chicago mail order house told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that he did not see how retailers could be expected to "hold the price line" when the Post Office Department was seeking an increase in parcel post charges.

New York bank loans to business broke the normal seasonal pattern last week, resuming their upward climb and advancing $53,000,000 to a new record total of $6,358,000,000. The rise in the week ended on Wednesday, brought the total of such loans outstanding 31 per cent above the level on Jan. 4, 1950.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4--A truce bringing labor peace to West Coast shipyards, at least temporarily, was reached here today by representatives of metal trades unions and the shipbuilding and ship repair industry.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4--Spokesmen for 300,000 trainmen and firemen who met separately here today indicated that when they reconvened tomorrow they would reject the tentative White House agreement on the twenty-twomonth rail dispute over wages and rules.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4--Careful study of the Russian text--rather than translated versions--of the Soviet note of Dec. 30, made it plain today that the Soviet Union, rather than restricting the proposed foreign ministers conference to demilitarization of Germany, had...

James Pryer Allen, veteran writer on lawn tennis and billiards for The Sun and other newspapers, died at 11:35 A.M. yesterday in Norwegian Hospital, Brooklyn. An hour and ten minutes later his widow, Mrs. Evangeline Rushmore De Nyse Allen, died on another floor of the hospital without having heard of his death.

Terms of the consent decree which will divide the film empire of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., into two separately owned theatreoperating and film producing-distributing companies, were approved yesterday by a three-judge Federal Statutory Court in New York.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 4--Small business requires special treatment under Government controls to insure full utilization of the productive power of smaller operating units, it was pointed out here today by members of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.
I believe that this movement among the Western democracies in which I now have been assigned a post, is one for the preservation of peace and nothing else.

LONDON, Jan. 4--Three days before Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's arrival in Europe as supreme commander of the North Atlantic Pact forces, Charles M. Spofford, United States chairman of the Atlantic Deputies Council, called today for more speed on the part of the Allies of the United States in filling the "great gap" still existing in Western defenses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--President Truman said today that all price and wage controls permitted by present law would be applied as soon as possible, but that food prices could not be held down satisfactorily without a change in the law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--During the week ended Jan. 3, member bank reserves increased $517,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Jay Thorpe's bridal shop, long noted for its formal and traditional styling, has sprinkled its spring collection with faintly tinted nets, laces, tulles and jeweled embroidery. At a press preview yesterday, gowns designed by Mme Josephine Oro displayed an airy and light quality both in fabric and style.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP)--The pacesetting Detroit Red Wings scored in the final period to gain a 1-0 shut-out over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight before 10,139 fans. The victory snapped a twogame losing streak for Detroit and marked the fifth shut-out for goalie Terry Sawchuk.

Ground-breaking ceremonies were held at noon yesterday in preparation for the construction of the Beekman-Downtown Hospital which will be erected at a cost of $4,500,000 at the plot at William, Beekman and Spruce Streets.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday the formation of a new $100,000,000 subsidiary to take over all pipeline properties and operations of the Sinclair companies. The new company will be known as the Sinclair Pipe Line Company.

Former Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor party, announced yesterday that he and John J. Abt, former attorney for the United States Department of Agriculture, had been retained by the Communist party to test the constitutionality of the McCarran Act.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 4--The three members of the United Nations Truce Committee today blocked out a tentative new proposal under which Communist China would be allowed to take part in a great-power conference on Far Eastern problems if it agreed to a cease-fire in Korea.

The Presidential orders which on Wednesday established the Defense Production Administration and the Defense Mobilization Board can best be understood if they are thought of as part of Charles E. Wilson's plan to make the Office of Defense Mobilization a going concern.

Admiral Television yesterday introduced its 1951 television and radio receiver line to distributors at a meeting in Chicago. Richard A. Graver, vice president in charge of electronics, said prices on important table models held unchanged.

Hides, natural rubber and the nonferrous metals were traded in smaller volume on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, but the hide futures market, under continued short-covering, moved into new seasonal high territory.
The House of Representatives is off to a bad beginning. On its very first day it has taken a reactionary step significant not only in itself but in what it portends for the future.

Eagle-Lion Classics, distributors of the British-made feature film, "Oliver Twist," yesterday received a resolution passed by the directors of the National Board of Review opposing "open or covert actions of intimidation, boycott or arbitrary censorship" aimed at the film.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 4 (U.P.)-- Veteran Jockey Johnny Gilbert was injured seriously today during the running of the sixth race at Santa Anita when his mount fell over another horse.
Directors of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of $2 a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock. The payment will be made on March 12 to owners of record on Feb. 13.

PARIS, Jan. 4--Although the French Cabinet was divided yesterday on precisely how to remove Communists or their sympathizers from key Government positions, a general program has been endorsed for dismissing employes at any sign of disloyalty. The exact steps, however, have not yet been formulated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--It is one thing to say, as the President did at his press conference today, that he does not need the specific approval of Congress "to send additional troops to Europe."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP)--The Government announced a project today to obtain oil tankers on a voluntary basis to meet defense requirements.
The Metropolitan gave its first "Rosenkavalier" last night, and the performance as a whole was exceptionally brilliant and entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Americans, generally speaking, were a bit healthier in 1950 than in 1949 or even in the 1945-49 average, the Public Health Service reported today. In a summary the agency said:
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 6 (AP)-- Release 790, issued by General MacArthur's headquarters at 11:45 A.M., Saturday (9:45 P.M., Friday, Eastern standard time):
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5--Dr. Philip Jaisohn, a physician and former adviser to the Royal Court of Korea, died today in Montgomery Hospital in near-by Norristown at the age of 82.

WONJU, Korea, Jan. 5--The United States Second Division is fighting a bitter delaying action against four North Korean divisions attempting to throw an enveloping movement against the United Nations forces in Western Korea.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5--The grain markets here fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today. They closed under the top prices as the result of heavy profittaking based on a material advance in the last six weeks and a bearish construction put on Senator Robert A. Taft's foreign policy speech.

ALBANY, Jan. 5--The State Banking Department announced today that approval had been given to a change of name of the Roslyn Savings Bank, of Roslyn, Queens County, State of New York, to the Roslyn Savings Bank.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5--A 6 per cent increase in freight rates will be sought by the country's major railroads, their traffic officers announced today, after a day and a half conference here. Railroad sources estimated such an increase would add about $400,000,000 a year to rail freight revenues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, moved today to rally the Congressional farm group for a fight against any effort to strengthen President Truman's authority to control food prices.
Thirty-eight hundred workers in twenty-four shoe-manufacturing plants went on strike yesterday to win "voluntary" wage increases of 15 cents an hour.

Extension of the Department of Sanitation's drive to prevent parked vehicles from interfering with the cleaning of streets has been stymied by the tardiness of the Department of Traffic in processing the necessary signs.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had asked the Board of Estimate to condemn 159 acres of slum property to advance nine low-rent housing projects. Action on sites for seven projects will be taken Thursday and the two other sites will be condemned in March.

Such was the last conference of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 6--Artie Devlin, Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' powerhouse, thrilled a record turnout of 7,500 tonight in winning the Harold Nelson Memorial jump over the Bear Mountain Hill surfaced with more than 125 tons of pulverized ice.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6 --Mr. and Mrs. Harry Allan Leigh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet, Ann, to James Alfred Figg Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Figg of White Post, Clark County, Va. An early spring wedding is planned.

Financial markets ushered in the new year with an outburst of strength and activity. Although some profit-taking tempered the advance at times, it did not prevent the upward movement from reaching the highest level in nearly twenty years. As the week ended with prices churning irregularly, traders awaited the President's State of the Union message which will be delivered tomorrow.

Dr. and Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour and Mrs. Busch Greenough are honorary chairmen of the committee, and Mrs. Leonard B. Leeming is chairman of the invitation committee.

TORONTO, Jan. 6--The New York Rangers struck for three quick goals in the first period tonight to fashion a 4-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. CHICAGO, Jan. 7--Grain prices continued their sensational advance on the Board of Trade last week. All deliveries of grain and soybeans sold at new highs for the crop year and a majority of them went into new ground since 1948.

PARIS, Jan. 7--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to Europe today without fanfare and immediately plunged into the work of organizing the defenses of the Continent he had helped liberate almost six years ago.

PARIS, Jan. 7--Gen. Charles de Gaulle pleaded today with the United States for its own good not to abandon Europe but to use its vast war potential, which could be done, he said, by a united effort overcoming national divisions. He spoke at Nimes.

ROME, Jan. 10--Sinclair Lewis, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1930, whose novels have for the last thirty years delighted millions of readers throughout the world, died this morning in a private nursing home on the outskirts of Rome. He would have been 66 years old on Feb. 7.

The Playwrights' Company will offer Sidney Kingsley's new play, "Darkness at Noon", this evening at the Alvin Theatre as its first production of the season. The Pulitzer-Prize author has staged his play, which is based on Arthur Koestler's best selling novel about the insidious forces of Communism.

An affable host to art and other educational and cultural groups in need of exhibition space, the American Museum of Natural History has turned over its vast Education Hall to the Sculptors Guild for an exhibition that opens today.

Final quotations were around the lows of the session and trading slackened considerably.

Civil defense officials abandoned plans yesterday to use part of the historic Governor's Room at City Hall for defense workers. At the same time, they made arrangements to convert a storeroom in the basement into a bomb shelter and emergency headquarters for Mayor Impellitteri and other officials.
The annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association will convene today at the Hotel Astor, with President W. Dickson Cunningham presiding. The time is 2 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)--A charge of bribery was leveled at the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from the House floor today but an investigating Senator said no bribery had been found.

Clarence W. Brazer, a dealer in stamp essays and stamp proofs, revealed yesterday that burglars had broken into his office between 5 P.M. Saturday and 2 P.M. Monday and had stolen $200,000 worth of essays and proofs.

Eastern skiing enthusiasm was heightened considerably last night as new snow brought good sport to many points listed heretofore in the "poor" category. In addition, the forecast of cold weather followed by snow tomorrow indicated the best week-end of activity thus far this winter.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 13--St. Peter's Prep of Jersey City captured the Metropolitan Jesuit High School basketball tournament title today by defeating Xavier High of Manhattan, 60--59, in overtime. WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP)-- Industry is having a hard time finding enough workers in some major cities but the labor shortage so far has not slowed defense production, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said today.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP)--The Arsenal Gunners, booting their way out of a holiday slump that threatened to end their bid for the English League title, advanced today by beating Middlesbrough, 3 to 1.

Those whose steps naturally gravitate toward the sailing division of the Motor Boat Show will find it bigger than before. There are about forty boats in it and they cover the small-boat field rather completely with prams, dinghies, one-design racing sloops and small auxiliaries.

Cooper Union's basketball team defeated Pratt Institute, 70 to 61, in a Greater New York Collegiate Conference contest at the Stuyvesant High gymnasium last night. Saul Giglio of the losers was high scorer with 28 points, three more than Cooper Union's Bob Kolb got. Cooper Union led at the half, 40-31.

The Society of Small Craft Designers will hold its annual meeting at the Palace Wednesday evening. Non-members not only are invited to attend but may take part in the discussions. The discussion period will follow the reading of a number of technical papers.

A NEW type of camera producing photographic images by means of electricity is announced by the Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories at Fort Monmouth, which sponsored the development of the camera during the past eighteen months.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 13 (AP) --The University of Kansas took top honors today at the Burdue University invitational debate tourney. Thirteen colleges and universities participated. The Kansas four-man team won first place and Orville Swander, a team member, was the individual victor.

CANTON, N.Y., Jan. 13--Skiing enthusiasm in this college town, always at a high pitch, literally reached the clouds tonight in anticipation of the big-time jump tomorrow on St. Lawrence University's new 60-meter hill.

Mayor Impellitteri, joining other mayors yesterday in proclaiming National Opera Day, declared in a nation-wide broadcast that he would do all he could to help opera in New York.

The sisters provide a gratuitous nursing service for the indigent sick in their homes without regard to color, race or creed.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations will hold its annual convention and luncheon in the Astor Hotel Wednesday. Arthur W. Wallander, City Director of Civil Defense, will speak on "Civil Defense for New York."

Postmaster Albert Goldman, chairman of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, and a 6-year-old polio patient dropped coins yesterday into a model of an iron lung at the Airlines Terminal on East Forty-second Street and started the March of Dimes "Flying Dime Bank" on a 10,000-mile air tour of the country.

Phil Rizzo, 146, and Georgie Flores, 145 fought to an eightround draw last night in the feature bout flat the Ridgewood Grove before a crowd of about 2,500.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 13-- Lady Beerbohm, wife of Sir Max Beerbohm, died today at their home in Rapallo, Italy. She was 74 years old. Death was attributed to a heart attack. She was Florence Kahn of Memphis at her marriage to Max Beerbohm in 1908.

Members of New York City's printing industry, and of related crafts and trades will observe this year's Printing Week, beginning today, with a program devoted largely to cooperative efforts in meeting the demands of mobilization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP)-- Large numbers of a new-model fighter planes have been ordered for support of Army ground forces under the Air Force expansion program.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court awarded Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Henry Gabaldoni, 24-year-old New York socialite, custody of her two children today. They have been held by her Peruvian husband, Luis Gabaldoni.

NEWARK, Jan. 13--Brooklyn College's basketball team notched its tenth triumph in fourteen games by defeating Newark branch of Rutgers University, 50--45, in the Newark Armory tonight. Buddy Lanigan, the Kingsmen's left forward, was the game's high scorer with 20 points.
LONDON, Jan. 13--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, new Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic powers in Europe, arrived here tonight by air from Norway to continue his flying tour of Europe's defenses.

New York Power Squadron this year will again launch a new class in piloting and small boat handling. It will begin on Jan. 22, at 7:30 P.M., at the Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, Manhattan.

In the marine insurance field at the show is a pictorial presentation of the major types of losses covered by the yacht and motor boat policy issued by the Automobile Insurance Company and the Standard Fire Insurance Company of Hartford. The insurance is against accidents due to fire and marine perils, including liability for loss of life or personal injury, damage to property and voluntary medical payments.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church, (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, will speak at a luncheon under the auspices of the National Laymen's Committee on Religion in American Life, at 12:30 P.M., Thursday, at the Roosevelt Hotel. DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP)--Police announced today the arrest of Pete Licavoli, 47 years old, a nationally known gambler, for questioning about an international gambling ring. Licavoli and six other men were picked up in a roundup by eight teams of detectives. The others ark William (Black Bill) Tocco, 54; Angelo Meli, 53; Max Stern, 37; Sol Bloom, 40; John Priziola, 56, and Nono Minaudo, 50.

Industrial alcohol can be produced from grain by a new mold process at less cost than by the traditional malt process, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The mold is called fungal amylase. A plant with a capacity of 12,000 bushels of grain a day could save more than $1,000 in each day's operations by shifting from malt to fungal amylase, according to the department.

Stock-car racing returned to the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx last night, with Chuck Arnold of Stamford, Conn., the victor in the 25-lap feature. Johnny Cabral of Paterson, N.J., was second and Reggia Atkins, Bridgeport, Conn., third. Arnold was clocked in 5:08.83 for the five-mile test.

The biggest boat at the Palace is a 48-foot Wheeler flying bridge yacht. It has an owner's cabin, guest cabin and crew quarters forward and, like all other 1951 Wheeler models, has a round bottom and flaring bow.

The Liberal party will hold a legislative conference tomorrow evening in the Ten-Eyck Hotel at Albany after recess of the Legislature, Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman, announced yesterday. Legislators of "liberal" viewpoint in both major parties have been invited to attend.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 1 to 10 points lower on the day. Talk of possible peace overtures in the Far East checked trading.

TOKYO, Jan. 13--The fat rear echelons must go. Brig. Gen. Bryan L. Milburn, in charge of the Headquarters and Service Command of General Headquarters, sent out a memorandum to his "obese personnel" today warning them they must be fit for combat or emergency duty.
