"Dulux" clear marine finishes, yacht whites and a range of colors are featured in the display of marine finishes for professional and amateur painters by the Du Pont Company. Du Pont is back at Booth 3 on the third floor and Harry T. Freer is in charge again.

The Hicksville evening branch of Long Island University, in Hicksville High School, will open Feb. 5 with curricula designed for undergraduates, graduate and nonmatriculating students. Veterans of World War II comprised 70 per cent of the first week's applicants to the branch.

BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 13--The engagement has been announced of Miss Eleanor Ochs Larsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Niels Hjalmar Larsen, to Alfred Faxon Latimer 2d, son of Lieut. Col. Lewis S. Latimer, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Latimer of Bronxville, N.Y.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--The second annual legislative dinner of the New York Council of Churches will be held at the Trinity Methodist Church here Tuesday at 6:30 P.M. Members of the State Legislature and Governor Dewey have been invited. The dinner will follow an all-day seminary on legislation.

The Richardson line of power boats contains five models this year. They are the 27 Sport Cruiser, the 27 Sedan, the 32 Sport Cruiser, the 32 Sedan and the 35 Sedan Cruiser. All are now in production and early delivery is promised.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Jan. 13-- Miss Patricia Bell Blake, daughter of Mrs. Frances Bell Blake of Montclair and Comdr. Theodore D. Blake, U.S.N.R., of Palo Alto, ...

As the United States, Great Britain and France moved last week toward their first clear-cut joint effort to restrict critical-materials exports to Iron Curtain countries, further tightening of this country's trade controls was in prospect, both immediately and in the near future.
ON THE WESTERN FRONT, Korea, Jan, 13 (AP)--Sound is the terror weapon of the Chinese Communist Army.

Representatives of America's oldest and largest engineering societies have taken the first official steps to help government and industry ease critical scarcities of technical manpower in vitally important national defense industries.

MIAMI BEACH--For the first time in years, Miami Beach hotels will be competing with the city's night clubs for the patronage of the former's guests. Last winter's test case and subsequent legislation permit the hotels to take out a $750 license under which they can have floor shows and dance music until 1 A:M. daily. Formerly, hotel dancing ended at midnight; floor shows were illegal.

Harmon Hoffman, who totaled 23 points, paced a rally in the last four minutes as Brooklyn Polytech's basketball team halted Hofstra, 73 to 68, at the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. last night. Polytech trailed at the half, 32--31. In the junior varsity preliminary, Hoistra beat Polytech, 84--61.

More than 21,000 members of the New York National Guard will spend an additional twelve days in field and armory training this spring in compliance with a directive issued by the National Guard Bureau in Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP)-- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that it is starting a $6,500,000 program to enlarge facilities at the Thirtieth Street station here in order that the Broad Street Station can be closed by the summer of 1952.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 13-- Playing before a capacity crowd the Dartmouth and Yale hockey teams tonight battled to a 2-2 tie in a fast and for the most part well-played game. All the scoring was done in the first two periods.

Supreme Court Justice James T. Hallinan installed the new officers of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Trial Counsel Association at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Brooklyn Club, 131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Economic Stabilization Agency has made budget plans for hiring up to 50,000 employes in less than eighteen months, indicating the scope of price and wage controls now contemplated.
Builders and realty interests last week got a sampling of the heavy burden of defense restrictions under which they soon must be operating.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP)-- Representatives-at-Large predicted today that their State Legislatures would rebel against President Truman's proposal that they be put into definite Congressional districts.
Martin Motors has eight new outboard engines this year, foremost among them the Martin "200," a twin-cylinder power plant in the 18-h.p. class that weighs about seventy pounds.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis of Garden City, L.I., on Jan. 2 in the Lenox Hill Hospital, this city. Mrs. Lewis is the former Miss Julianne Oppenheimer, daughter of Mrs. Leon N. Oppenheimer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Oppenheimer. The child will be named Robert Hensley.

The manner in which Western Europe affects the balance of economic power between East and West may be seen if a comparison is made between the actual production situation in 1950 and that which would have existed had the Soviet Union controlled Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP)-- Maj. Gen. James H. Burns, retired, the first lend-lease executive in 1941, was named a special assistant to Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall today to handle international security affairs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP)-- The Chinese Communists dropped a hint today they were having trouble in their so-called "reform movement" of Chinese Roman Catholics.

Roberts Industries, Inc., has a collection of small craft available for home assembly. They are prefabricated and include 8 and 10foot prams, two 12-footers, one a "car top" model, and a 14-foot runabout.

Committee 1 (Political and Security)--At Lake Success, voted by 50 to 7, with Philippines abstaining, in favor of five-point principles proposed by Truce Committee for Far East parley on Formosa and Communist China's membership after cease-fire in Korea.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP)--Will Harridge, president of the American League, and veteran pitcher Dizzy Trout of the Detroit Tigers will be honored at the eleventh diamond dinner of the Chicago Baseball Writers' Association tomorrow night.

Seven models, ranging from 31 h.p. up, comprise this year's line of Mercury Outboard Motors. One is the new "Cruiser," which, as its name implies, is particularly suitable for the heavy family boat, cruiser or workboat. Through a change in gearing, the energy of the Super Ten Hurricane powerhead has been applied to heavier duties. The motor weighs 70 pounds.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 13-- Holy Cross set back a hard-fighting Fordham basketball team, 75--63, tonight before 3,300.
DURHAM, N.H., Jan. 13--Today was "Sousa Day" at the University of New Hampshire.
EDITH WHARTON in "The Age of Innocence" deline ated an era, the tone of a house and the personality of Mr. Beaufort by stating that he dared to hang a Bougereau nude in his study.

The marriage of Miss Charlotte Davison Jacobs, daughter of Moses Jacobs of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mrs. Anne Cass Jacobs, to Jack Victor Berrent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Berrent of 473 West End Avenue, will take place today in the Hotel Olcott. The Rev. Dr. Martin Katzenstein of Philadelphia will perform the ceremony.
Three large apartment buildings in Jersey City, N.J., have been sold through J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers. The aggregate amount involved in the purchase of the properties was about $430,000.
THE most successful rebellion to occur within the ranks of communism so far has been the one accomplished by Marshal Josip BrozTito.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 13 (AP)-- Yale swimmers defeated Navy, 53 --22, today to win their sixty-second consecutive dual meet even though some of their finest men remained in New Haven, Conn.

A novelty is a surfboard for use with a 7.2 h.p. outboard motor to provide self-propelled aquaplaning. The motor is housed in a watertight "forepeak." An autonmatic valve shuts off the motor air intake if the contrivance capsizes. Cipollone's, Inc., is the builder.

The appointment of J. Paul Thompson as general manager of the United States Salvage Association has been announced by Clifford G. Cornwell, president. Mr. Thompson succeeds Capt. George S. Bull, who retired after thirty years of service with the association.

The Klepper Company, manufacturers of the Foldboats that have been around for years, has come up with a new model that is said to be unsinkable. It's a twoseater, 18 feet long, into which extra buoyancy has been built through a pair of air-filled tubes around the gunwales. Like other Foldboats, it can be collapsed for portability. It is suitable for paddling, sailing or with an outboard motor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP)-- George Preston Marshall put a $500,000 price tag on his share of the Washington Redskins today following reports that a wealthy transit company official here was interested in buying the pro-football club.
Demolition work has been started on the two old buildings occupying a plot of more than 11,000 square feet at the northwest corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street, in the lower edge of Times...

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 13 (AP) --The Government today announced the recent surrender of 200 Communist rebels--the first to lay down their arms since the Red revolt began three years ago. The announcement said the group surrendered on the eve of the Government's Jan. 4 deadline for amnesty ...
Myra Hess, giving her only New York recital of this season, packed Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon with a program consisting only of three sonatas by Beethoven.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP)--A fourth fireman died today from injuries suffered in a $1,500,000 river warehouse fire and explosion that was viewed yesterday by an estimated 5,000,000 television watchers in many parts of the nation. The blaze and explosion destroyed the five-story warehouse and office building adjacent to the Chicago River.

A plastic sport cruiser called the Dreadnaught 23 designed by M. Rosenblatt Son and built by the Dreadnaught Cruiser Company is one of the new-boat features of the show. It's built of resin-impregnated fiberglas cloth, which develops tensile strength three-quarters that of steel.
THE best indication of the current state of furniture design in Denmark is the annual Cabinetmaker's Exhibition held annually in Copenhagen's Museum of Decorative Art.
Characterizing the Republic of Korea as "a new nation brought to life by United Nations action," Mrs. Edith S. Sampson, an alternate United States representative ...
Original choreography by the dance groups of eight colleges was presented before 100 persons yesterday in a dance symposium sponsored by the Barnard College Physical Education Department.

The five-point program proposed by the United Nations Truce Committee for a cease-fire in Korea to be followed by a Far Eastern conference was approved yesterday by the Political and Security Committee.

Columbia's unbeaten fencing team notched its fifth victory in a row by turning back Yale, 15 to 12, on the University Hall strips yesterday. The Lions captured the foil and epee competition by identical 6-3 scores, but dropped the saber test, 6--3.

THE Republican high command has now launched its formal attack upon the Presidential conduct of foreign relations. This attack began with the demand for the ouster of Secretary Acheson--a demand which looks to the substitution of a parliamentary system of government for our Presidential system.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 13--In the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family here this morning, Miss Corinne de St. Aubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ovide de St. Aubin, was married ...
Cruising yachtsmen will be interested in the large-scale relief map of the intracoastal waterway set up at the Palace in the Texaco exhibit. It's on the third floor of the building.
In his message to Congress on Monday Mr. Truman said: "We are building much stronger military forces--and we are building them fast."
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 13 General Eisenhower, who came to Oslo yesterday in his tour of North Atlantic capitals, was off again this afternoon for London.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)-- Nina, Duchess of Hamilton and Brandon, who devoted her life to being kind to animals, is dead at the age of 72.
Two alert radio patrolmen were credited yesterday with saving the life of a 17-month-old boy when they administered first aid to him and gave him an antidote for a disinfectant he had swallowed.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 13-- The engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George H. McGlynn of their daughter, Florence Jean, to Lynn G. Goodnough Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodnough of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for March.
ALBANY, Jan. 13--A bill empowering the Legislature to call in the heads of State Departments each year and question them on their activities will be introduced on Monday night.

Cruis-Alongs, the relatively inexpensive motorboats brought out by M.M. Davis Son, Inc., a few years back, are in the show again. They come in two lengths, 22 and 24 feet, and are available either as complete units or with basic equipment only. Gray Phantom engines provide the power.

"Benjamin Franklin, Patriot," impersonated by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Seagle, rector emeritus of St. Stephen's Protestant Epis copal Church, will arrive here tomorrow at 10 A.M. to open "Franklin Birthday Week."

WIESBADEN, Germany, Jan. 13 (Reuters)--Brig. Gen. Charles F. Born, Deputy Operations Chief of the United States Air Forces in Europe, left here by air today for Washington to report for a new assignment. With him went Brig. Gen. Edward H. Alexander, commander of the Sixty-first Troop Carrier Wing, based near Frankfort, who is also being reassigned by Washington.

The one potential service man who is having an extremely difficult time just now planning his life is the reservist. He is the man who is liable to call to duty at almost any time, but in most cases is not informed of his position until he receives his orders.

The light-displacement 18-foot waterline planing sloop introduced a year ago is again included in the space of the Luders Marine Construction Company, whose other display is a standby of several years' standing, the L-16.

A full-schedule of deep-water yacht racing has been prepared for the coming tourist season by the Southern Ocean Racing Conference. The fifth annual Fort Lauderdale-Cat Cay race will open the schedule on Jan. 26, and on Feb. 10 the Lipton Cup Race will be held at Miami.
White flowers formed a garden setting yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church for the marriage of Miss Sheila Tucker Brown, daughter of ...
Golden Key Homes, builders and distributors of prefabricated houses, have moved their New York offices and showrooms to 1780 Broadway.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 13-- Mr. and Mrs. R. Tilton Pfeil have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary, to J. Richard Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Willis Lee of Bethlehem, Pa. Miss Pfeil is a graduate of Benedictine Academy here and is a member of the Elizabeth Town and Country Club. Her fiance is an alumnus of Lehigh University.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 (UP)--Baltimore's street-car and bus operators voted by an overwhelming majority today to strike for higher wages. Despite the vote, spokesmen for both the Baltimore Transit Company and the Amalgamated ...

WITH U.S. 2D DIVISION, in Korea, Jan. 13 (AP)--Ten hungry, shivering G.I.'s reached friendly lines yesterday after having slipped through Communist positions in central Korea's snow-covered mountains.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 13 (AP) --Attorney General J. Howard McGrath said tonight "we have the Communist fifth column well under control."

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 13--Two American and two Canadian rinks survived the quarter-finals today in the sixteenth annual bonspiel for The Douglas Medal at the indoor arena of the St. Andrews Golf Club.

Among the engine displays at the Palace are three high-horsepower, lightweight, high-speed Diesels in the space of the Cummins Engine Company. One is an activated, cutaway version of the new JS-600, so that boat owners may study the mechanical features of this four-cycle, full Diesel, sixcylinder, supercharged engine. The power plant has a maximum rating of 150 horsepower, turning at 2,500 r.p.m.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 13 (AP)--Miss Andrea Mead of Pico Peak, Vt., finished second to Anneliese Schuh-Proxauf of Austria today in the international Alpine ski combination event that drew 24 snow queens from six different countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Souvenirs of the White House--scraps resulting from the reconstruction now under way--will soon go on official sale to the public.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 13--Miss Marjorie Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Anderson of the Hegeman Lane colony here, was married this afternoon to Dr. Henry H. Bard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Bard of Pittsfield, Mass., in the Protestant ...

Rear Admiral Harry Browning Slocum, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Slocum of Washington, and Vallejo, Calif., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Anne Taylor, to Peter McMartin Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Richards of 1105 Park Avenue, this city, and McMartin House, Litchfield, Conn.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 13 (AP)--Germany took the first five places in the German national bobsled races today in competition with the best sled riders from five countries. The United States was not entered.

Facilities of the nation's colleges and universities which can be used to serve the needs of the armed services and the Federal Government for purposes of national defense are being inventoried by the Office of Education. This inventory is expected to bring together for the first time information required by the Government for defense and security.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13-- Three goals in the third period broke up a close hockey game at Smith Rink as St. Lawrence handed Army its second setback of the season, 4 to 2, in the feature event of a four-sport program at the Military Academy today.

Knowing that tickets for his performance of Verdi's Requiem on Jan. 27 are prohibitive in price for most students, Arturo Toscanini has invited five schools to send two honor students apiece to the concert as his guests.

The engagement of Miss Nancy Norton Sayles to William Allen Prior, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen A. Prior of Troy, Pa., has been announced here by her parents, Mrs. Eleanor Norton Sayles of Cohasset, Mass., and Thomas Dyke Sayles of Norwich, Conn.

FOR THIS WEEK: Taking inventory is as valuable to gardeners as to storekeepers. By checking quantities of leftover seed, fertilizer and spray materials, necessary amounts can be determined for this year and ordered early.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 13-- Class champion Skip Purcell, sailing Bottoms Up, and Roger Gilbert, at the tiller of Chili, each won three rags in today's frostbite regatta of the Dyer Dhow dinghy fleet at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Purcell finished ahead of his chief rival in the other races and captured the day's honors with 52 points.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Jan. 13-- A service in memory of Dr. Charles Henry Breed, headmaster of Blair Academy from 1927 to 1946, will be held tomorrow afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. L. Rodney Boaz, president of the Board of Trustees of the academy, will be in charge.

Seven models, ranging from 87 to 165 h.p., comprise the line of marine engines displayed by the marine engine division of the Chrysler Corporation. The smallest is the Ace, developing 87 h.p. at 2,800 r.p.m. The largest is the Royal Special, 165 h.p. at 3,600.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)-- Sixty-eight-year-old Jock Hutchison of Chicago came from behind today to shoot a 3-under par 69 and tie for the national senior Professional Golfers Association championship.

The annual eight days of prayer for the return of other Christians to the Roman Catholic Church will begin next Thursday. The principal series of services in the Archdiocese of New York will be held at 8 P.M. each day at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West Seventy--first Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 13--Archibald R. MacKennan has announced the engagement of his daughter, Jean, to Thomas M. Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton W. Marshall of Lane'S End, Shelbyville, Ky. A June wedding is planned.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reported yesterday the signing of leases with three new tenants, completing the renting of all space in its new home office building at Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street. The company uses the first thirteen floors and has rented out the remaining twelve.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 (AP)-- West Germany soon will restrict further duty-free gift shipments of coffee, cocoa and chocolate from abroad. The West German Government has prepared an order restricting the monthly quantity of coffee in gift parcels to one pound a person. At present the limit is five pounds. Cocoa and chocolate will be limited to two pounds each.

PITTSBURGH, Jan 13--The engagement of Miss Jean Louise Flood to John Paul Egan Jr., son of Judge and Mrs. Egan, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Henry C. Flood. The prospective bride is an alumna of the Ursuline Academy here and Pennsylvania State College for Women. Her fiance was graduated from Shady Side Academy, Yale College and the Harvard Law School.

Worth Street will have a new and modern office front and merchandising space when the new home of Greenwood Mills, Inc., selling house for Greenwood Mills of Greenwood, S. C., are completed late in May.

More than $1,000, representing pre-Christmas mite box donations by the students at Manhattan College, has been distributed to charitable organizations, Brother C. Basil, Moderator of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, has announced. The Little Sisters of the Sick Poor received the largest amount, $300.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--President Truman's new budget, calling for the largest peacetime expenditures in the country's history, was off the presses today and ready for submission to Congress on Monday.

NOT so long ago actors received the heretic treatment when they deserted the "living" stage for the cellu loid theatre. By last year, movie performers could attain the same status by emoting in front of television cameras.
More foreign exhibitors are in the current show than in any other. There are five British firms represented, a group of builders from the Netherlands and two from Canada.
GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Jan. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Bertram P. Shover have made known the engagement of their daughter, Doris Ann, to Wilber M. Brucker Jr., son of former Governor Brucker and Mrs. Brucker.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 13 (AP)--Bucknell limited the Rutgers basketball team to one field goal in the first fifteen minutes of the second half today and went on to trounce the Scarlet, 74--56.

The President's economic report to Congress on Friday filled in the picture of what the new mobilization will mean to the American people economically. His high defense counselors supplied the details on military manpower.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (UP)--Marshal Sir John Slessor of the Royal Air Force left by plane tonight for New York.

The Young Women's Christian Association of New York City will soon begin a decentralized neighborhood program for children and teen-agers in the Harlem River Houses, 207 West 151st Street, in cooperation with the city Youth Board and the New York Housing Authority.

The Cerebral Palsy Society of New York City, Inc., 50 West Forty-seventh Street, raised $273,116 during its pioneer city-wide campaign, Jack Hausman, president, said in his 1950 report yesterday. More than 200,000 of the sum, he said, already has been distributed to nineteen facilities and agencies in the city area for cerebral palsy treatment and work.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 (AP)-- Finance Minister Abolghassen Forouhar resigned today, accused of not driving a hard enough bargain with foreign interests for Iran's oil riches. He was replaced temporarily by his under-secretary, Abdul Baghi Shoaei.

A.R. True, Inc., of Amesbury, Mass., an exhibitor of long standing at the boat show, features a 23-foot-cabin auxiliary sloop powered with a 16-h.p. Gray marine engine this year. There's also a Lightning, built to class specifications, of course, and an 18-foot Rocket of the firm's own design. Also included are a 14-foot Knockabout for beginning sailors and an 8-foot pram.

TORONTO, Jan. 13 (UP)--Adam Brown, veteran Scottish-born left wing with a penchant for scoring crucial goals, tallied in the third period tonight to salvage a 3-3 tie for the last-place Chicago Black Hawks against the Toronto Maple Leafs.
IN 1942, in the office of a famous judge, the conversation turned to Rab Saadia Gaon, head of the rabbinic academy at Sura, in Mesopotamia, who had died one thousand years before.
The Salvation Army said yesterday that thirty-four of its members, including four officers, had lost their lives in Korea, the United Press reported. Commissioner Donald McMillan, Eastern ...

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 13 (UP)--Defense Minister Francisco Forteza said today that Congress will be asked to authorize the purchase of two escort destroyers that the United States has offered to sell to this country.

Julius Yudell and Max Jacobson, both formerly with Lane Realty, have organized their own company under the name of Regency Realty Corporation, with offices at 120-84 Queens Boulevard, in Kew Gardens. They will specialize in commercial properties. Mr. Yudell is president of the new company and Mr. Jacobson is executive vice president.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--Governor Dewey has asked the Legislature to reconstitute the State Defense Council and to invest it with virtually all the powers that a military commander could exercise under a declaration of martial law.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 13-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Doyle of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Allen Doyle, to Sgt. Norman Kenneth Erickson, U.S.M.C., son of Mrs. Axel G. Bergman of Fairfield, Conn., and ...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13 --Mr. and Mrs. Hubert A. Pattison have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gerry, to Thomas Barker Grimshaw of San Francisco, son of Mrs. Ira L. Grimshaw of Claremont, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, and the late Mr. Grimshaw.

CALL Robert Rossen a writerproducer-director who can combine business with pleasure. En route home from Europe aboard the Queen Mary after a three-month sojourn abroad, Rossen discussed an idea with Leonard Bernstein.

Prof. M.E. Barker of the University of Arkansas dispelled widely held beliefs as to what makes clothing comfortable when he recently addressed the Sixth Southwest Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Jules S. Freund, since 1945 executive director of the Retail Labor Standards Association of New York, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 56. He resided at 295 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The "meat grinder" strategy of the United States in Korea commenced to take slow effect last week as the Chinese Communists lost substantial--though not crippling-- casualtes in their drive on Wonju.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 13-- Guards on all arterial highways leading from New York City would prevent a mass exodus in the event of a bombing attack on the metropolis, Orange County civilian defense auxiliary police were told here last night.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13--The results of an unusual road test recently completed at La Plata in southern Maryland are being awaited with interest by New York and other states considering special taxes or other control measures for heavy trucks.

A Louis XVI tulipwood marquetry grand bureau plat, of late eighteenth century design, was sold for $500 yesterday in the collection of art property of Charles Armour of this city. Total receipts for 194 lots in the collection dispersed at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, were $26,320.
John Alden Carpenter will be 75 on Feb. 28. The Chicago, St. Louis and Indianapolis Symphonies will all mark the anniversary by performance of his music.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 13-- have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia, to Peter Rawson Bickelhaupt of New York, son of Capt. Ivan A. Bickelhaupt, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Bickelhaupt of Washington. The wedding will take place in the spring.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13--The Yugoslav Communist leaders are prepared to collaborate with all Socialist and progressive movements in the West as a third force to help preserve peace.
HAVANA, Jan. 13--The first international conference on ACTH and cortisone was held today in the amphitheatre of Calixto Garcia Hospital of Havana University.
Further improvement of the upper East Side area in the neighborhood of Manhattan House, twenty-story apartment structure being completed by the New York Life Insurance Company, is in progress.

Western Connecticut builders, Inc., report the sale of a home in Indian Field Park, their development in Greenwich, Conn., to Comrie Watt of Yorkers, N.Y. Mr. Watt has purchased a threebedroom home on Circle Drive, overlooking the Milbrook Golf Club.
OCCASIONALLY a young people's novel with breadth and depth helps meet the shortage of mature stories for the younger teens.

CHADDS FORD, Pa., Jan. 13-- The engagement of Miss Jean Whitney Marston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Trowbridge Marston of Oakdale, Chadds Ford, to Alan Sanford Glendening of Wilmington, Del., son of Mrs. Frank Leslie Fraser of New York and St. Petersburg, Fla., and Harold Sanford ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13-- --Though there should be no minimizing the influence within their grasp, Republicans on Capitol Hill appear to be suffering from a familiar Democratic complaint--division within the ranks.
The Eighty-second Congress met promptly at noon on Jan. 3 as provided in the Lame Duck Amendment to the Constitution.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stewart McManus of Honolulu, of the engagement of their daughter, Sally Lei, to A. Edward Fitkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis C. Fitkin of Allenhurst, N.J.

America's educational leaders are deeply concerned by the future of the independent college and university. Their apprehension was expressed last week when representatives of 650 liberal at is colleges met in Atlantic City for the annual conference of the Association of American Colleges.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 13-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Webster Janssen of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Bennett, to Dr. Roland Anderson Fletcher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Cecil Gray Fletcher of Bronxville and Hillsdale. The wedding has been planned for the spring.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan, 13 (AP)-- Union school teachers today deferred until next Tuesday the scheduled start of a strike against Minneapolis public schools. The teachers, demanding higher wages, had called the strike for 7:30 A.M. Monday, but agreed to a delay at the request of District Judge Paul E. Carroll. The Board of Education had petitioned the court for an order restraining the teachers from striking.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13-- The undefeated Columbia basketball team, displaying amazing shooting accuracy, swept into a tie with Pennsylvania for the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead by trouncing Yale, 90--48, on the Payne Whitney court tonight.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 13-- Miss Sarah Elizabeth Du Bois, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy, I. Du Bois of West Orange, was married here today in St. Luke's ...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 13 (AP)--Bad flying weather forced postponement of a Southwest Conference basketball game here tonight between Rice Institute and the University of Arkansas of Fayetteville.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 13--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William T. Thomas of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy, to Robert Wilkinson Castle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Castle. Miss Thomas studied at St. Lawrence University. Her fiance, an alumnus of the Cherry Lawn School in Darien, Conn., is attending St. Lawrence.

The third apartment building in a group of six has been completed in Rega Park Apartments, an 800family project under construction by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company at Woodhaven Boulevard and Dry Harbor Road, in Rego Park, Queens. Tenants will start moving into the building tomorrow.
DETROIT, Jan. 13--Manager Robert A. (Red) Rolfe signed his 1951 contract with the Tigers today for a reported $42,500--second highest managerial salary in the American League.
The Atomic Energy Commission guardedly announces that atomic bombs are to be tested on an Air Force Bombing and Gunnery Range in Nevada 5,000 miles square.
Tomorrow is draft registration day for doctors, dentists and veterinarians under 50 years of age who were exempt from the first medical muster Oct. 16.

SAVANNAH, Jan. 13--The engagement of Miss Alice Battey Bryson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sheffield Bryson, to Marion Avant Woodbury of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Llewelyn Easterling Woodbury of Wilmington, N.C., has been announced by her parents. An April wedding is planned.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 13-- Elizabeth will give two months' pay to all municipal employes entering military service, according to a plan approved by City Council. The measure will become effective upon approval by the state division of local government.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13 (AP) --Princeton's swimming team won all but one event today in trimming Columbia, 59--16, in the Eastern Intercollegiate League opener for both teams in Dillon Gym pool. The lone Columbia winner was Dick Auwater, who took the 200yard backstroke. Princeton had four second places in addition to its eight firsts.

Conversational finished a good third, five lengths off the pace.

EUREKA, Calif., Jan. 13 (UP)-- A light earthquake was felt here at 12:32 P.M., today. Although it swayed buildings, no damage was reported. The seismographic station here reported the disturbance was centered in the Pacific Ocean about twenty-five miles off Humboldt Bay.

Buying at the winter New York Lamp Show in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday was brisk for all 355 exhibiting manufacturers. At least one big retail organization began placing large-scale "scare" orders in metal goods.

NINE years ago Joseph Stalin and Adolf Hitler were loyal allies. Eight years ago they were bitter enemies. Three years ago Joseph Stalin and Tito were loyal allies. Today they are bitter enemies. The Soviet dictator, who has slaughtered most of his personal friends, hasn't had much success in keeping the affection of his official friends, either.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--The class name of the new fast cargo ships to be built by the Maritime Administration will be "Mariner," and the first group will, in addition, bear the nicknames of the states, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Stockholders of the Empire Trust Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved a proposal to declare a stock dividend providing one additional share for each seven held. The action will increase the bank's capital from $3,500,000 to $4,000,000.

CARMEL, N. Y., Jan. 15 (UP)--The second degree murder trial of Herbert Gehr, a television director who killed his wife July 10 when she led a divorce raid on his mountain cabin, will go to the jury tomorrow.

Yesterday probably marked one of the most successful customer, employe and stockholder relations days in the history of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. No sooner had the mailmen begun delivery of about $28,000,000 to more than 980,000 stockholders of the Bell System than

Ezra Stone has signed contracts to stage Bernard Evslin's dramatization of "The Man Who Corrupted Hadleyburg," a short story by Mark Twain, With this matter settled, Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, producer of the project, said yesterday production activities would start "almost immediately" in preparation for a New York opening late in March.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15-- Curiosity surrounds the speech that James Francis Byrnes will make tomorrow when he is sworn in as the seventy-eighth Governor of his native state of South Carolina.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--President Truman asked Congress in his budget message today to provide free life insurance of $10,000 for all service men.

YONKERS, Jan. 15--Charles B. Driscoll, author of the syndicated column, "New York Day By Day," since the death in 1938 of O.O. McIntyre, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital here of a heart attack. His age was 65.

The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report wisely chose the day preceding the President's Budget Message to suggest that Congress get to work on some more of the Report's recommendations for saving money,

In a new personnel shift in the high uniformed echelons of the Fire Department, Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan yes, terday appointed Acting Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott as Chief Fire Marshal and head of the Bureau of Fire Investigation.

LONDON, Jan. 15--Informal discussions among the Commonwealth Prime Ministers have failed to produce an agreement between India and Pakistan on the future of the disputed state of Kashmir, a communique from 10 Downing Street disclosed tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--Heavy general buying developed in all grains on the Board of Trade here today as the result of what traders regarded as a highly inflationary Presidential budget message to Congress. Closing trades were

When the military committee composed of Allied and German representatives meets for the second time today to discuss a German contribution to the defense of Western Europe it will be able to work in an atmosphere clarified by two statements of Chancellor Adenauer.

Reflecting the substantial increase in sales, the net income of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with last November rose to $20,143,810 front $15,133,416 in the same six months of 1949.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)-- The government has agreed to lend $73,425,000 to Lone Star Steel Company, Dallas, Tex., to expand its plant near Daingerfield, Tex.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)-- The Defense Department said today "replacements for casualties and battle weary soldiers" would start reaching Korea "in quantity" by early March, and a smaller number would arrive in February.

The new "emergency" rent control law signed late last March by Governor Dewey looked forward hopefully to an "orderly transition from and termination of emergency controls without undue dislocations, inflationary price rises, or disruption." Preliminary policy, under the 1950 law, was of a hold-the-line nature. Meanwhile a fair-return policy was to be studied.

The high command of New York City's Air Warden Service--568 men and women zone and deputy zone commanders--took the oath of office last night and were told that they represented the top field echelon of the city's Civil Defense forces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Harold E. Stassen declared tonight that there was trouble behind the Iron Curtain, afflicting even the Soviet Army, but pleaded for continued rearming and urged a revised ...
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 15-- United Nations delegates from fifteen countries today began a new attempt to complete a two-yearold draft treaty on freedom of information.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP)-- The Defense Department identified today 566 casualties in the Korean war, including 35 dead, 65 wounded, 16 injured and 450 missing.

The toilet goods industry--estimated to have set a new record in retail volume of more than $800,000,000 during 1950--is expected to continue gaining during 1951 despite serious problems arising from the defense program. Volume in 1949 was a record figure of $770,800,000.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States rose $10,145,000, or 2.6 per cent during December to a total of $393,522,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The increase over the previous month's figures is considered seasonal. Since 1925 there have been twenty increases and six decreases in the month of December. Total accept

Representative members of the social and theatrical worlds attended the Anta Theatre Ball given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the American National Theatre and Academy Fund Campaign.

Some further increase in money rates is essential if banks are to obtain a fair and reasonable return on their stockholders' invested capital, the Chase National Bank declared in its annual report yesterday. Signed by Winthrop W.

Cocoa bean futures advanced 100 points, or 1 cent a pound, in brisk trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. This is the limit of daily price range permitted under the Exchange's rules. Trade and commission-house buying in the face of a tight supply situation induced the price rise, trade interests reported.

Now on display in the State of Maine's window at Rockefeller Center are two frozen food products from that region. They are lobster newburg and lobster thermidor, made by the Spruce Head Kitchens. And because Maine takes almost as much jealous pride in its lobsters as in its potatoes, there probably couldn't be a stronger recommendation for these items.

Observance of Printing Week began here yesterday with a new emphasis on the power of the printed word, and a warning that the force of ideas--the "propaganda bomb"--can work as effectively for communism as for democracy when freedom of choice is lacking.

The formation of the Phoenix Industries Corporation to invest in "special situations," principally in the industrial and merchandising fields, was announced yesterday by Walter S. Mack Jr., who has been elected president of the newly organized enterprise.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 15--High official quarters declared today that the "basic policy" of the Chinese Nationalist Government here is to "defend Formosa--come who may."
Eighty thousand New Yorkers braved the chill winds that whistled through the financial district yesterday to watch the first March of Dimes parade swing up lower Broadway to City Hall.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--Joseph B. Elliott, vice president in charge of consumer products in the R.C.A.Victor division, Radio Corporation of America, today urged appliance and television receiver dealers to take immediately ten concrete steps to maintain good volume when inevitable merchandise shortages set in soon. He spoke before

A news magazine correspondent, who William W. Remington said "might have been" a Communist, later apologizing fOr so saying, testified in the defendant's behalf yesterday at Remington's perjury trial in Federal court.

Three organizations and twentyeight individuals, including novelists, playwrights, publishers, producers and clergymen, joined yesterday with the American Civil Liberties Union and the Authors League of America in urging the Board of Regents not to revoke the license of the controversial Italian film, "The Miracle."
UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 16 (AP)--Eighth Army communique 129, issued at 12 noon Tuesday (10 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15-- Leaving their carpentry tools at home, shipwrights reported for work today at four shipyards in the San Francisco Bay area. They struck the plants last week in a drive for a basic wage of $2 an hour.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--A record tonnage of limestone and nearrecord tonnages of iron ore and coal were moved on the Great Lakes in the 1950 shipping season, John T. Hutchinson, president of the Lake Carriers Association, reported today.

A renewed lease on life was taken yesterday by the stock market. It reacted favorably in the late trading to the outline given by President Truman on the spending program for the stepped-up armament effort. The rally in the

David S. Meister has resold the two store and showroom buildings at 550-52 and 554 Fifth Avenue to the Nina Bujola Realty Corporation, represented by Mandel Permutt, attorneys. Abbott Adams were the brokers.
Two months and a half have passed since bills were introduced in the City Council requiring a thirty-day waiting period for policemen filing retirement papers.
WITH U.S. 2D DIVISION, IN KOREA, Jan. 15 (AP)--One of Maj. Gen. Clark L. Ruffner's first orders to his new command, the Second Division, was to shave off their fifteen-day-old beards.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)--About 900 members of the Transport Yorkers Union, C.I.O., took an hour and a half off today to vote authority to their executive committee o call a strike against the Pan American World Airways.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)-- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee, said today that he was "shocked to find that the President's budget "provides for the 'Fair Deal' under the guise of defense spending."

The Government's purpose in the anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses is not to foist practices on the industry or to denounce or uphold certain trade practices, but only to enforce provisions of the Sherman laws relating to the maintenance of competition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--The Administration's foreign policy leader, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, may offer a concession later to those demanding that President Truman consult the Senate before sending troops to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Highlevel Defense Department officials and military chiefs were as one today in declaring that there was no special significance in the flying trips to Jppan and Korea of various top-ranking United States military leaders.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and A.G. Becker Co., Inc., will place on the market today an issue of 60,000 new shares of convertible preferred stock of City Stores Company, a holding company directing the operation of eight department stores in major cities and two chains of apparel specialty stores.

The Government's purpose in the anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses is not to foist practices on the industry or to denounce or uphold certain trade practices, but only to enforce provisions of the Sherman laws relating to the maintenance of competition.

An official publication of the Board of Education yesterday sharply criticized last June's Regents examination in American and world history as failing to contain questions on improving democracy and as overlooking "many fundamental areas of inquiry."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Albert Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador to tthe United States, called upon Secretary of State Dean Acheson today to bring him up to date on the increased effort by the Italian Government to contribute its share to the joint defensive machinery being erected by the North Atlantic Treaty powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--President Truman submitted to Congress today in his budget message an estimate of nearly $10,956,000,000 for additional aid to peoples sharing the "common peril" of Communist aggression and for supporting activities.

Virginia Thomas, who made her recital debut in Times Hall last night, has a mezzo-soprano voice of natural beauty and a flair for musical sentiment. The Scranton (Pa.) girl's audience filled most of the hall and gave its approval with loud applause. Paul Meyer was the piano accompanist.
HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 15-- French-Vietnamese ground and air forces were today bitterly resisting the biggest Vietminh attack yet launched against the northern approaches to Hanoi.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 15--A makeshift bomb exploded this morning in an automobile owned by George Donahue, 42-year-old trustee of Local 1,247, International Longshoremen's Association, in what the police said was "definitely" an attempt on his life.

College basketball will be making its final Garden stand for more than three weeks tonight as Manhattan College meets De Paul and unbeaten Long Island University tangles with Duquesne at the big Eighth Avenue arena. Not until Feb. 8 will the collegians return to the "big top," the hiatus being caused by midyear examinations.

Police Sgt. George M. Killen, one of eighteen members of the department ordered to appear yesterday morning before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating gambling, turned in his retirement application on Sunday night, Assistant District Attorney Julius A. Helfand announced yesterday.

The current expansion policy of Bankers Trust Company which emphasizes "retail banking" activities, indicates no lessened interest in the types of business with which the bank has been traditionally associated, S. Sloan Colt, president, says in his annual report.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15--An indication that "good design" is becoming more international in scope may be seen in the 1951 version of the Good Design Exhibition that opened here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick recommended state rent regulation changes today that would enable many landlords to get rent increases up to 15 per cent. In addition he proposed relaxing the restrictions on evictions.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 (AP)--Radia Station WJW reported today that it was maintaining normal operations despite a strike by its ten announcers. The walkout by members of the American Federation of Radio Artists, A. F. L., had kept the station off the air for more than three hours this morning.
A special exhibit showing proposed changes in the Throgs Neck-Ferry Point section of the Bronx will open to the public today in the Veterans Hall of the Bronx County Courthouse.
Night baseball still has a prominent place in the American League schedule, released yesterday, with a total of 197 after-dark contests on the slate.

ACCORDING to the usual standards of estimating the relative value of news, the winter golf tour is not fundamentally important. The cast of characters doesn't change essentially and the same little group of top-flight performers attends to the winning. But every once in a while something out of the ordinary happens and the full glare of the spotlight focuses on the divot-diggers.
The National Biscuit Company, the first corporation to announce the result of operations for 1950, yesterday reported a preliminary net profit of $21,110,431 after taxes and all charges.

LONDON, Jan. 16--The stock markets here ended the bookkeeping account today on a firm note. Early losses by some recent favorites on profit-taking were recovered. Oil and rubber shares were particularly bright.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--More than 70 per cent of all children in the elementary schools of the nation do not have physical education as part of their school program, August Pritzlaff, director of health and physical education for the Chicago Public Schools, today told a press conference here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath threatened drastic action today against the Brotherhood of Trainmen, whose members have renewed "wildcat" strikes in Birmingham, Ala.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman today asked the Senate to confirm Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, former Army Deputy Chief of Staff for Plans, as Chief of Staff, Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers, Europe (S.H. A.P.E.), under General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. General Gruenther is already in Europe serving in that post.
With the turn of a valve in a neat, rectangular one-story building at 134th Street and the Hudson River, natural gas from the Texas-Louisiana oil fields began flowing into Manhattan yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 16--Within the near future, Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner, said today, the march of events may force the abandonment of the principle of a free economy in Western Germany and make necessary the control of all raw materials essential to rearmament.

Issues of common and preferred stock valued at more than $19,000,000 are to be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings include new shares of preferred stock of Food Fair Stores, Inc., and of San Diego Gas and Electric Company, ...

CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 16 (AP)-- Herbert Gehr was acquitted today in the slaying of his 31-year-old wife, Andrea. Mrs. Gehr was killed as she accompanied detectives seeking divorce evidence to the mountain cabin where her husband was week-ending with another woman.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 17-- United Nations troops fought the Chinese and North Korean Communist invaders yesterday right across the Korean peninsula on a 100-mile front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Raymond M. Foley, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, asked today for quick enactment of the Administration's Defense Housing Bill, but it was apparent, as Senate hearings opened, that the program faced stormy weather.
After fourteen years of litigation the Government's anti-trust case against the Aluminum Company of America was said to have reached the final stage yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 16--Rising slightly as they sweep forward over the brow, Rose Valois' attractive spring hate are designed on what she names the "envelope line."

The rush of New York youths to join the colors in all branches of the armed services continued yesterday.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced disciplinary action yesterday against twenty employes. His office said eighteen of them had failed to sign civilian defense enroll- ments, which include loyalty oaths.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16--Conversations between the Western powers and the Western Germans on the latter's contribution to European defense proceeded at a faster pace at the second meeting of the military committee today.

The major radio and television networks, resuming their contract negotiations with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, agreed yesterday to set up a joint subcommittee with the union to study the question of employment among musicians in broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Democratic leaders of the Senate promised today to give its entire membership the right to express itself formally on the issue of sending American troops to help stand guard in Europe against the Soviet Union.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16-- Harvard's basketball team won its first Eastern Intercollegiate League game and broke a fourgame losing streak in the process by beating Dartmouth, 68--52, tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 16--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower left here for Lisbon today with an open mind on the will of the West to resist aggression.

HARTFORD, Jan. 16--The Fact-Finding Commission on Connecticut Education, organized nearly two years ago by former Gov. Chester Bowies, has spent more than double its original allotment of $40,000 in that period and may be discontinued, it was disclosed today.

Uncertainties overhanging the international situation and the doubt still existing regarding the Government's raw materials control plan caused a mixed movement in the commodity futures markets yesterday.

Dr. Eleanor deForest Baldwin of 7 Gracie Square, Assistant Professor of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. She was 46 years old.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Jan. 16 --How successfully cancer, arthritis and heart diseases may be treated with hormone compounds was examined further today at the International Conference on Steroids in Experimental and Clinical Medicine.

The prospect of a premature winter overflow of Catskill and Croton reservoirs has become a source of worry to the city's water officials. The effect might be a critical shortage next winter rivaling that of a year ago, it was explained yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 16--The shortage of up-to-the-minute jet aircraft is the chief worry in Britain's rearmament program, Defense Minister Emanuel Shinwell revealed today.

"Gotham Yankee: A Biography of William Cullen Bryant," by Henry Houston Peckham, will be published by Vantage Press on Feb. 10. It is the first Bryant biography in forty-five years. Mr. Peckham is the author of five other books, including "Creative ...
Five of eight members for its technical advertising council were appointed yesterday by the PanAmerican Coffee Bureau. The others will be appointed when nominated by the National Coffee Association.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 16--Incentive pay for maintenance workers and standardization of costs were urged by speakers today at the Plant Maintenance Show.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Senate Judiciary Committee was scheduled to move again tomorrow to create within its own membership a Senate counterpart of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

HONOLULU, Jan. 16--Charles K. Fujimoto, chairman of the Communist party of Hawaii, became the third defendant today to be acquitted of charges of contempt of Congress before the United States House Un-American Activities Committee hearings into communism in Hawaii here last April.

One of the most important things the Legislature can do for New York City at this session is to revise the law covering our Parking Authority so there can be no doubt about selling bonds to build off-street parking space.

A series of Sunday afternoon violin and piano recitals, called "Musical Talent in Our Schools" and featuring students from schools in the metropolitan area, will be broadcast over WQXR, radio station of THE NEW YORK TIMES, starting in April.
A six-foot former bellhop was accused yesterday of working a shakedown racket on 115 persons since last November by threatening to arrest them for minor offenses in Grand Central Terminal.
The first city-wide test of airraid sirens since World War II will be held at noon on Saturday, Jan. 27, and each Saturday thereafter similar tests will be conducted at the same hour.
Members of the city's printing industry continued their observance of Printing Week yesterday with working sessions that pointed up the craft's high capacity for meeting demands of mobilization.
The cotton futures market on the Exchange here was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 14 points higher than on Monday, with old crop months showing the most strength.

YONKERS, Jan. 16--A bitter denunciation of the top police executives of this city was voiced publicly today by the Police Association of the City of Yonkers, Inc., comprising the rank and file policemen from patrolmen to captains.

How color can be used to create a fresh effect is competently illustrated in a series of seven model rooms opening today on Bloomingdale's fifth floor. Six of the rooms stress the contemporary style and one is built around traditional furnishings.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 16-- James Francis Byrnes, in his inaugural address as Governor of South Carolina, declared today that our forces should be withdrawn from Korea unless the United Nations pronounced Communist China an aggressor, authorized American bombing of Manchurian supply bases and joined a blockade against China.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Industry's ever-increasing demand for engineering college graduates has forced employers to seek women engineers for the first time because of a shortage of this type of production personnel.

ALBANY, Jan. 16--Legislation increasing from $50,000 to $100,000 the maximum amount which any estate, trust or fund may invest in a common trust fund was introduced in the Legislature today under the sponsorship of the State Banking Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP)-- Millard F. Caldwell, confirmed by the Senate today as Civil Defense Administrator, said a few hours later that $3,000,000,000 spent on bomb shelters right away would not protect even 1 per cent of Americans from a bombing attack.

An industry-wide attack on the shortages of needle and supervisory skills and on the lack of standards in piece goods was under way yesterday at the convention of the International Association of Clothing Designers.

The annual exhibition of oils, water-colors, caseins, sculpture and graphic art, held by the Audubon Artists, will open with a preview reception this evening in the galleries of the National Academy. At this event the prizes and awards will be officially conferred.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The finest thing the United States has brought into international relations is equality in negotiations among large and small nations, W. Averell Harriman, special assistant to the President on foreign affairs, today told a youth forum ...

WASHINGTON, Jan.16--Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, will state his views of the price control problem tomorrow night for the first time and is expected to promise the speediest practical action.

The Port of New York Authority, which maintains sixteen bridges, tunnels, airports and other facilities in New York and New Jersey, has the fifth largest police force in the two states.
EDWALL, Wash., Jan. 16--A Northwest Airlines twin-engined passenger plane carried ten persons to their deaths today as it crashed in a snowstorm near and eastern Washington farmhouse.

One of the brightest spots in federal activities during the past few years has been the high quality of medical services given veterans. As contrasted to a pre-war medical program of admittedly low standards, our veterans since 1945 have had medical care "second to none."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Palatine Stable's Grass Fire raced to his third straight triumph in the $5,000 Tropical Purse today at Tropical Park closed one of the most successful winter meetings in its history before a crowd of 10,452.

BUFFALO, Jan. 16 (AP)--Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, warned newspaper publishers today that they had a "real problem" in fighting television's effect on the reading public.

The New York Public Library, described last night by Dr. Robert I. Gannon, former president of Fordham University, as "one of the great channels of civilization," announced that it had received $155,000 toward its campaign funds for support of the Reference Library.

Scientists and engineers will make even greater contributions to the nation's welfare in the years to come if they participate more actively in public life to insure freedom for research and management, Milton C. Whitaker, veteran chemical engineer and educator, declared last night.

Plans for modernizing a Fifth Avenue landmark in the midtown area were disclosed yesterday when Henry Goelet, realty operator, reported his purchase of the former Tiffany Building at the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Street in a series of deals involving about $8,500,000.

Paul Paray, one of the most accomplished musicians and orchestra leaders that we have heard in recent years in America, came to Carnegie Hall last night as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, making his first appearance in the hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The General Federation of Women's Clubs announced today its second annual community project contest, to be titled, "Build Freedom with Youth."

LONGVIEW, Wash., Jan. 16-- West Coast longshoremen headed for home today after a five-day caucus here at which the delegates, as one of their final actions, voted to fight to maintain the hiring halls as presently constituted.

GALVESTON, Tex., Jan. 16 (AP) --The National Collegiate A.A. Football Rules Committee today debated reinstatement of the fair catch rule and found a number of reasons why it should not be restored in its old form.
BOSTON, Jan. 16--Boston port leaders generally agreed today that increased exports of grain through here were needed as a basic cargo that would attract other shipments and increase port volume.

A two-story garage building on plot 75 by 92 feet at 431-35 West Sixteenth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, was resold by Frederick Brown to a client of James N. Wells' Sons, Inc., brokers. Maurice Iserman was the attorney for the buyer and Joshua Bernstein for Mr. Brown.
Private financing transactions totaling $33,434,000 were announced yesterday.
Big Don Newcombe, all 248 pounds of him, dropped in at the Brooklyn Baseball Club offices yesterday and became the fourteenth Dodger to sign.

Regional offices of the National Production Authority at 42 Broadway were flooded yesterday with inquiries from builders and architects concerning the new restrictions affecting nearly all major types of commercial construction work.
Frederick C. Remington, 80year-old father of William W. Remington, testified at the latter's perjury trial yesterday that he knew his son was never a Communist.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16--Delegations close to the efforts to end the Korean war appeared increasingly certain today that Communist China would neither reject flatly nor accept flatly they peace program sent to Peiping last Saturday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 16--The United Nations will begin its first major session in South America next month and will concentrate on a problem that has many of the smaller countries worried--the effect of the international crisis on programs to aid underdeveloped regions.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 16-- Announcement has been made by Mrs. David Duncan of the engagement of her daughter, Ann Mary, to Clarke Freeman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman.

ALBANY, Jan. 16--Governor Dewey today called for immediate legislative action to permit clearing of dangerous storm-felled timber from the State's Adirondack forest preserve and the sale of logs that are removed.

From a humble beginning as a purely neighborhood institution, the Irving Trust Company, which opened for business in 1851 with a capital of $250,000, reaches its hundredth anniversary in March with capital of $117,600,284.

Trial of the State Insurance Department's action to have the International Workers Order, fraternal insurance organization, dissolved as Communist-dominated will begin next Monday, Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg ruled yesterday.

TRENTON, Jan. 16--Judge and Mrs. Charles P. Hutchinson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Ellen, to Michael Charles Guarino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Guarino of Verona. The wedding will take place soon.

ALBANY, Jan. 16--The State Senate upheld today a report of its Judiciary Committee rejecting a petition calling for the ouster of Senator William J. Bianchi of Manhattan, who was elected Nov. 7 on the Republican and American Labor party tickets. The vote was 38 to 15.

The United Corporation's transition from a utility holding company to an investment concern is scheduled for completion in 1951, according to its president, William Mace Hickey, who was in San Francisco yesterday on a trip.

For the third time since Sunday Coast Guard and naval surface and aircraft went racing to sea yesterday to aid a vessel in distress.

The defense budget of approximately $52,000,000,000 for this fiscal year and of $60,000,000,000 for the fiscal year starting next July 1 will "buy" armed forces about 3,462,000 strong, organized in eighteen Army divisions and numerous other units, ninety-five air wings, twenty-five aircraft carriers and two and a third Marine divisions.

A leading producer of refrigerators and other major appliances has just stopped all production of home freezers, a company spokesman disclosed yesterday. He said increasingly critical shortages of steel, copper, nickel and other vital materials forced the concern to make the move.

A 22-year-old youth who came here last July from Roxbury, Mass., was booked early today at the West Forty-seventh Street Station on a charge of burglary involving thousands of dollars in loot the police found in his room.

PARIS, Jan. 16--Another note to the Soviet Union is expected to be dispatched by the Western powers shortly, and the French Government was making preparations tonight as if it expected conferences to open both on Germany and on settlement of the Korean war.
Sweden has cabled Ingvar Bengtsson permission to prolong his visit to this country, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Natalie Satin Rachmaninoff, widow of the great Russian pianist and composer, Sergei Rachmaninoff, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital of a heart attack after a day's illness. She wag seventy years old.

Premier Pleven of France is to come to Washington at the end of this month to discuss with President Truman "various important questions of mutual interest."

The first glimmerings of apprehension about "the bomb" are beginning to appear among some nursery school youngsters and cowboy play is beginning to blend in confused fashion with games about war and soldiers.

Newmyer of the Mayflower, Washington.

The city is considering a plan to transfer the maintenance of its vast traffic signal system from the Police Department to private contract.
The nation's gasoline supplies last week increased 1,901,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

A trio of first-rate musicians-- Leopold Mannes (piano), Bronislav Gimpel (violin) and Luigi Silva (cello)--gave a concert last night in Times Hall, devoting themselves to two masterworks of the trio repertoire and two works that are more or less novelties.

A group of paralyzed war veterans protested yesterday against Veterans Administration plans to move paraplegic patients out of Halloran Hospital on Staten Island.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 last, Benjamin Abrams, president, told stockholders yesterday in his annual report.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Development of the public power potential of the Niagara River in the interest of the mobilization effort was pressed upon Congress today by Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberals of New York.

Net earnings of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York for 1950 amounted to $1,609,152, compared with $1,634,748 in the preceding year, James G. Blaine, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.
The Long Beach Unified School District of Los Angeles County Calif., yesterday announced that it would receive bids on Feb. 6 or an issue of bonds for $11,300,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Two bills designed to assist public prosecutors in obtaining convictions of big-time gamblers and their henchmen were introduced in the Legislature today with the blessing of District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Brooklyn.

The tightening of margin requirements only took a momentary toll in the stock market yesterday. The list easily absorbed opening selling, and prices pushed forward with vigor to raise composite averages 0.76 point, although much larger gains were made by a wide variety of issues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- An $87,000,000,000 program to buy the arms needed now and to build a producton base for 50,000 warplanes and 35,000 tanks a year was disclosed today by the Defense Department.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Bituminous Coal Operators Association is expected tomorrow to offer the United Mine Workers of America a voluntary wage increase of 20 cents an hour.

United States Public Health officers began yesterday to take throat washings of persons arriving from abroad who have been infected with influenza.

A citizenship training program designed to give the country's service men and women a greater understanding of democratic concepts and procedures will be prepared next month by the armed forces in cooperation with the Columbia University Teachers College.

Extended scope of driver vision, improved riding qualities and a more efficient engine cooling system are among the important advances in the 1951 line of cars presented yesterday by Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation.

Emergency orders for scarce industrial materials and supplies are finding so few takers that some out-of-town companies are planning to open special buying offices in hotel rooms here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Israel has asked the help of the United States to see that Germany carries out her obligation to indemnify Jews for Jewish property stolen during the Nazi era.

Mrs. Stella Spalding Presbrey, widow of Frank Presbrey, founder and for thirty-five years president of the advertising agency that bore his name, died yesterday at her residence, 815 Park Avenue, at the age of 90.
Vegetables retain the highest proportion of vitamins and minerals when cooked by the waterless method. Second best results are obtained with a pressure saucepan.

Schultz, executive vice president of the Willmark Service System, Inc., on completion of the company's annual nation-wide survey of retailing's selling and system technique and performance during 1950.
Tammany supporters of Mayor Impellitteri moved yesterday toward an attempt to oust Carmine G. DeSapio as leader of Tammany and to substitute a man approved by the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Amid a welter of conflicting rumors about prospects for a general price freeze, automobile makers told the Government today that they were cutting output this quarter 20 to 25 per cent below the rate of a year ago.

One of the world's largest collections of printed research material is located in the building behind the lions at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue in New York City. There, at any time of the library day, can be found hundreds of people checking on some fact or some condition, present or past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Legislation to meet a pinch in farm labor resulting from the 60 per cent jump in cotton production scheduled for this year was the subject of a conference opening here today's at the Willard Hotel. The cotton goal is more than 16,000,000 bales as against 10,000,000 grown last year.

Roadmen are asking for a wage increase of 35 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today a supplemental loan of $15,000,000 to the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., a Canadian enterprise and the largest private concern in Brazil.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Congress has just turned out a new history of its members--the first since 1927--in which the criminal records of some one-time members are left out.

The Palestine Economic Corporation, the oldest American industrial development company in Israel, last night celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary with a dinner attended by 350 persons at the Essex House.
The New York Infirmary Building Fund reported $145,170 in pledges yesterday at the second winter campaign meeting. The amount brings the total sum raised toward the $4,200,000 goal to $3,162,674.

The present abundance of water in the city's reservoirs serves to emphasize the delicate balance between oversufficiency and under-sufficiency that must exist in New York City's reserves until the opening of new water sources increases the regular daily supply.

Custom made fashions by Lydia Kessler were presented yesterday in her new shop at 42 East Fiftyseventh Street. The group included daytime and evening dresses, suits and coats from Miss Kessler's ready to wear collection.

Uncertainty continues to mark the skiing picture for Eastern, United States as reports last night indicated high temperatures and diminishing bases. The weekend forecast of cold weather with a limited amount of snow is not encouraging.

Production of newsprint in North America last month totaled 514,331 tons, the highest for any December on record, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday. This figure brought continental output for 1950 to a new high of 6,282,182 tons, an increase of 206,327 tons, or 3.4 per cent over 1949 production.

Everybody, including the New York baseball writers, who voted him the player of the year, believes that Eddie Stanky is the regular Giant second baseman for 1951. But Secretary Eddie Brannick yesterday announced the signing of three more keystone boys.

Investigation into the college basketball betting scandal that broke on Wednesday seemed to have simmered down yesterday to a hunt for two vaguely defined characters supposed to have been involved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Only the Administration's case for its Defense Housing Bill had been presented as hearings by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee were recessed today without any definite date set for resumption.

Emmett (Rosy) O'Donnell, who headed the Far East Air Forces Bomber Command, returned today from six months' direction of the strategic bombing in Korea and said that in his opinion every available weapon should be used against Communist aggression in Asia.

At the end of 1950 just 4,368,540,652 square feet of land, or nearly half of the total of 8,930,854,440 square feet in New York City were tax-exempt. These figures were disclosed by a study, whose results were announced yesterday, made by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan.

Arthur W. Wallander, the city's civil defense director, appointed yesterday a committee of nine members of the Advisory Council on Defense to study the possibility of lifting the ban on police, fire and ambulance sirens when the installation of 565 fixed sirens is completed late in March.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18--Thomas Jefferson McGinty, admitted part owner of a recently closed gambling casino near Cleveland, told the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today that he had joined three other local gamblers in investing $800,000 in the Desert Inn at Las Vegas, Nev., where games of chance are legal.

Several solutions to the problem of furnishing the casual ranch-type house will be presented on Monday when Macy's opens its annual midwinter furniture show. Although the groups to be introduced have a kind of relaxed informality, the similarity stops there. For one is pine, another angled iron, a third is rugged oak, and a fourth, the most elegant, is fashioned of fruitwood and chestnut.

ROME, Jan. 18--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower plunged today into his work of investigating Italy's will to fight if attacked and to contribute her share toward the common defense of the West against Soviet imperialism.

Robert Cox, 21 years old, of Valley Stream, L.I., was acquitted in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday of disorderly conduct charges brought by a policeman who had been accused by Mr. Cox of having beaten him brutally on New Year's night in Times Square and later in the station house.

New orders for equipment and supplies for civilian defense programs throughout the country will more than compensate many manufacturers for losses of nonessential civilian business as a result of cutbacks under the decree recently issued by the National Production Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Federal Trade Commission today charged twelve manufacturers of twine and cordage products with unlawful restraint-of-trade practices.

The new luxury liner Independence will be greeted in the harbor on Monday by Mayor Impellitteri and an official welcoming party and by the usual water and whistle display.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP)-- James H. Duff, a stalwart among Pennsylvania Republicans and a man to watch in the 1952 Presidential contest, made his political debut in Washington today as a United States Senator.

LONDON, Jan. 18--Independently of United States military aid to Western Europe, the other North Atlantic Pact powers are transferring arms and equipment to each other. The biggest single transfer to date is now taking place--the equipment of a Dutch infantry division with Canadian war stocks.

Raoul Dufy, famous French painter, appeared yesterday at the exhibition of his American paintings that is being held at the Louis Carr Gallery, 712 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Admission is 60 cents.

IT has become commonplace in recent years to compare the war-torn world of this century with the peaceful one of the last. Yet the difference in the degree and frequency of strife and violence is only comparative. When the nineteenth century began the Napoleonic Wars were going full blast. When it closed the Boer War was just well started.
The voluntary industry plan to relieve traffic snarls in the congested garment area is a complete failure and mandatory rules are seen as the only means of correcting the condition.

The amalgamation of the United Service Organizations and the Associated Services for the Armed Forces was ratified yesterday at a joint meeting of the boards of directors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The merged organization will use the name U.S.O.

Howard McGrath.

Shake-ups in the Fire and Police Departments yesterday sent fortyseven firemen back to fighting fires and fifty-two policemen back to "normal police duty."

John L. Davis, who recently retired as assistant director of sales for the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, manufacturers of linotype machines and other printing equipment, died on Tuesday in his home at 210 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 65.

Sales and earnings of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation in the final quarter and full year of 1950 were the highest in its history, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Thomas S. Nichols, president.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP)--Fair enforcement of price controls and rationing is impossible to attain, John Holmes, president of Swift Co., said today. Mr. Holmes made his remarks, which he said were not "in a critical spirit," at the annual stockholders' meeting of the nation's largest meat packer.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 43 points yesterday. March liquidation increased near the close.

The Rubel Corporation has sold its coal and oil terminal at 200 Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn, to Juliansons Realty Company, which has leased the property to the Premium Coal and Oil Company. The terminal, fronting on Newtown Creek, covers about 100,000 square feet of land.

Simultaneously military authorities here are stepping up a mass exodus operation to near-by islands to clear some of the clogging human traffic from this vital last-defense area.

The twenty-ninth semi-annual local Lamp Show ended in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday with orders exceeding expectations. Although some scare buying occurred, most bookings were on a conservative basis.

Profit taking yesterday nipped an early attempt of the stock market to rally and final quotations were irregularly lower than on Thursday. Interest throughout the session was confined almost entirely to low-price issues, the key industrial stocks getting scant attention.
